name: Korean wolf
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Canis lupus coreanus is 95 to 120 centimeters long and weighs between 12 and 80 kilograms. The nose is long and pointed in relation to the broad head, and the forehead is broad and somewhat sloping. It has large, strong teeth and jaws adapted for crushing bones. Their ears are relatively small and short, always pointing upward. Their legs are long and thick, and their long tail is hairy and extends to their heels, and unlike dogs, it doesn't curve upwards, but downwards.  The color and density of their fur varies depending on the climate and environment of the latitude they live in.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: lives in family groups of 5 to 8 animals. They have a hierarchical social structure centered on a male alpha male - Habitat: They have a generally wide range of behavior for foraging. They range from open pastures in the tundra to deserts, savannah-like grasslands, and forested areas.- Prey: Medium to large ungulates (mammals with even hooves), such as deer and goats, to small prey, such as hares and birds.- Mating occurs in January and February and is monogamous, with females choosing one male to mate with. The gestation period is 60 to 62 days, and they give birth to 5 to 10 young in April and May.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: It is estimated that only 200,000 to 250,000 individuals remain worldwide.  It has been extensively trapped and hunted for its damage to people and farms, and its population has declined rapidly due to the loss of prey species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: During the Japanese occupation (1910-1945), the population of wild wolves declined sharply due to the sea rescue program. The last wild wolf in Korea was killed in Seoul National University Park in 1997 and is no longer found in South Korea.- Overseas: The species is considered locally extinct in Europe and some parts of the world, but its wide range and relatively stable populations have earned it a Least Concern (LC) rating from the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN).

name: Sika deer
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The head and body are 140 to 180 centimeters long, the ears are 15 centimeters long, the hind feet are 45 centimeters long, the tail is 14 centimeters long, and the shoulders are 100 to 130 centimeters high. The antlers are 50 to 80 centimeters long in males. They are among the largest members of the deer family in Korea, with males about 1.5 times larger than females. The color of their fur ranges from chestnut brown to reddish olive, with white spots on the neck and back.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults shed their antlers in January and February, young individuals in March, and the change from summer coat to winter coat begins in September and October. In winter, a mane appears on the neck of males.- Habitat: Inhabits forested areas, ranging from lowland to alpine areas - Diet: feeds mainly on leaves, bark, moss, and grass - Mating occurs in September and October, with a gestation period of about 210 to 223 days, giving birth to one to two young at a time. The young reach sexual maturity after four years.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Indiscriminate hunting, coupled with the Joseon Governorate's saltwater remediation program, led to a sharp decline in the population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Thought to have been extirpated during the Japanese occupation of Korea (1910-1945) as a result of sea salvage programs. Currently domesticated in various parts of the country, with other subspecies (Taiwanese and Japanese) introduced artificially in Hallasan, Jeju Island. Internationally: Distributed mainly in Japan, northeastern China, and the Russian Federation; assessed as Critically Endangered (EN) in China.

name: Ussuri black bear
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 138 to 192 centimeters, the hind feet are 21 to 24 centimeters long, the tail is 4 to 8 centimeters long, and the body weight is 80 to 200 kilograms. The face is long, with a broad forehead, rounded ears and a short muzzle. They have a long mane on their neck and shoulders, and glossy black fur all over their bodies, sometimes with brown or reddish-brown coloration. Their overall body size is small compared to other bears. The characteristic V-shaped white half-moon pattern on the front of the chest varies greatly in size between individuals, and in some cases, there is no pattern at all.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: It has a highly developed sense of smell and hearing, but not vision. Its sharp claws act as non-slip grappling hooks when climbing trees and rocky cliffs, and it is faster on flat ground than on mountains. They hibernate in winter and live an average of 25 years.- Habitat: They live in rocky forests at high elevations or in mixed forests, which are a mixture of two or more types of forests that are rich in resources.- Food: They are omnivorous, preferring hard fruits and acorns, and will also eat animal food such as nectar, insects, crustaceans, and bird eggs and young.- Gestation period is 200 to 240 days, and they give birth to one to four young in January and February.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Once abundant and distributed throughout the Korean Peninsula, its population declined dramatically due to poaching for its tusks and the Japanese occupation of Korea (1910-1945). The population has since declined due to habitat loss and continued poaching.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Once reduced to 5 individuals throughout South Korea, the population has increased to 85 individuals in the last 20 years due to the restoration project in Jirisan. Since the restoration project, the distribution area has expanded beyond Jirisan to Deoksan Mountain and Gaya Mountain. - Overseas: The subspecies is distributed in the Ussuri region of Eastern Siberia.

name: Red-black myotis
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Myotis rufoniger is a medium-sized bat with a body length of 4.5 to 7.0 cm. The wingspan is 4.2 to 4.5 cm, about the same as the body length, the hind feet are 1.1 to 1.3 cm long, and the tail is 4.3 to 5.2 cm long. The body is covered with matte orange fur, and the wing membranes protrude slightly outside the legs and are attached to the hind feet. The edges of its ears, hind feet, and body are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It hibernates earlier and emerges later than other bats, with an average lifespan of about 25 years. It is nicknamed the golden bat because of its orange-colored fur.- Habitat: Nocturnal, resting in old trees and forests during the day in summer, and hibernating in caves and abandoned mines in winter.- Prey: Mosquitoes, moths, and arthropods are captured and eaten using ultrasound.- Breeds in summer, with females mating before hibernation. Fertilization does not occur immediately after mating; females store sperm in their bodies and fertilize in the spring. She hibernates pregnant and emerges from hibernation to give birth to one to two young in June or July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the loss of hibernation sites due to deforestation for the construction of forest roads and the closure of entrances to natural caves and abandoned mines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rare throughout the country, with a small number of individuals, about 500, found in Chungcheong-do, Jeolla-do, northern Gyeongsangbuk-do, and Jeju Island. - International: Found in Japan, China, Taiwan, Laos, and Vietnam.

name: Siberian musk deer
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 70 to 100 centimeters, the hind feet are 23 to 26 centimeters long, the shoulder height is 50 to 70 centimeters, and the weight is between 7 and 15 kilograms. Both males and females are hornless, and males have about 5 centimeters of canine teeth protruding from their mouths. The fur around the eyes, cheeks, and behind the ears is white, and the lower jaw is grayish white. A white stripe runs from the eyes to the left and right sides of the neck, across the front chest, and down the inside of the front legs. The head is smaller than the body, and the body is covered in thick, hard, black-brown fur. Their hooves are small and their limbs are short, and males over three years old have a well-developed musk sac between their navel and genitals.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Very acute hearing, sensitive to the slightest sound, and emits a low 'wet wet' sound in times of danger. Lifespan is 10 years or less, but in captivity they can live for 20 years - Habitat: Found in coniferous or broadleaf forests on rocky, high mountains above 1,000 meters. They are usually solitary or live in small groups of two to three individuals, consisting of a mother and her young.- Food: They prefer lichens, but also eat young herbaceous plants and fruits.- They mate in November and December, and females are pregnant for about 180 days, giving birth to one to two young at a time. They give birth in May or June.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The musk scent from the musk sacs of the musk deer is widely used in perfumery around the world, and in Asia it has been widely used as an aphrodisiac and sedative in traditional Chinese medicine. This has led to frequent hunting and habitat loss, which has reduced the species to below its minimum viable population (MVP).

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: The current domestic distribution is found in Gangwon-do and parts of the DMZ, with an estimated population of around 50 individuals. - International: There are seven species worldwide, with populations in Russia, Mongolia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, China, and Far Eastern Russia.

name: Long-tailed goral
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Naemorhedus caudatus is a medium-sized mammal of the cattle family, with a body length of 105 to 130 centimeters, ears 12 to 13 centimeters long, horns 13 to 14 centimeters long, hind feet 30 centimeters long, tail 11 to 16 centimeters long, and a weight of 25 to 35 kilograms. The fur on their foreheads and cheeks is dark grayish brown, grayish white, and black. Most of its fur is grayish brown, but some of its tips are dark brown. Its winter coat is soft and dense. Its sturdy hooves and two well-developed toes allow it to climb rocks quickly.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The average lifespan is 10 to 15 years, and both sexes have cylindrical horns. The thickness and spread of the horns distinguishes the sexes, as does the white spot on the chest and the long white hairs on the inside of the tail.- Habitat: Inhabits high mountainous forests, especially rugged terrain with steep rocks. Adult males are solitary, mothers and their young live in small groups of two to three, and during the winter months they move down valleys to live in larger groups.- Diet: Herbivorous, feeding on young leaves, vegetation, and fruit.- Sexual maturity takes about three years and breeding occurs every one to two years, with mating season from October to December. Gestation period is from May to July, with a gestation period of about 200 to 220 days, giving birth to one offspring.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population has declined due to habitat loss and degradation caused by forest development and habitat destruction, poaching, and heavy snowfall due to climate change, and it often dies in isolation due to heavy snowfall, especially in the Gyeongsangbuk-do region.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Samcheok-si, Yanggu-gun, Hwacheon-gun, Hwacheon-cheon, Uljin-gun, Gyeongsangbuk-do, DMZ, Seoraksan, Odaesan, Wolaksan, Taebaeksan, Sobaeksan, Soksan, etc. in Gangwon-do; - International: 4 species worldwide, inhabiting mountainous and alpine regions such as Tibet, the Himalayas, southern China, and the Amur.

name: Eurasian otter
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal has a body length of 65 to 110 centimeters, hind legs of 30 to 50 centimeters, a tail of 30 to 50 centimeters, and a weight of 5 to 14 kilograms. Its head is flat and rounded, with a rounded nose. It has whiskers around its mouth that act as antennae and developed fangs. Their fur is white under the chin and dark brown in color overall, but the lower part of their body is more light brown. Their soft fur is excellent for waterproofing and keeping warm.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Nocturnal, with good vision, hearing, and smell; lives in families with territorial ranges of 7 to 15 kilometers within streams; habitat: Lives in streams and lakes with abundant reeds and vegetation along the water's edge, where food is plentiful; uses rock cavities at the water's edge and crevices under tree roots as homes.- Food: Fish are the mainstay of their diet, but they also eat a variety of other foods, including amphibians, crustaceans, and algae - Mating usually occurs in the water in January and February, with a gestation period of 63 to 70 days, and they give birth to two to three young at a time in May and June.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include habitat destruction, water pollution, and fishing nets. Poaching for its fur, which is particularly warm and waterproof, has led to a dramatic decline in its population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Widespread throughout the country, inhabiting territories centered around water systems; - International: Widespread along rivers in Europe and Asia, excluding Siberia, from Europe to Kamchatka, Sakhalin, northeast China, eastern India, and the Himalayas. The IUCN considers otters to be an indicator species for the health of local water ecosystems.

name: Eurasian lynx
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The lynx has a body length of 84 to 105 centimeters, a hind foot length of 20 to 23.2 centimeters, a tail length of 19.5 to 20.5 centimeters, and a weight of 15 to 38 kilograms. Its head is large and its ears are triangular with black tips. The cheeks have long whiskers, the eyes are short oval when constricted, and the irises are light yellow in color. The tips of the auricles have brush-like hairs. Its body is patterned in various ways, and its fur is grayish white or reddish brown. It has dark spots on its legs and back, which are more pronounced in summer and fade in winter. They have strong legs, relatively wide paws, and a short, clipped tail.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It typically lives 12 to 15 years and is usually solitary. It sprint at high speeds over short distances.- Habitat: Lives in high-altitude, rocky forests, usually active after sunset and before sunrise.- Prey: roe deer, deer, young boar, musk deer, hares, pheasants, jays, chickens, and mice.- Mates from February to April, with a gestation period of 9 to 10 weeks, and gives birth to 1 to 5 young at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The sensitivity of the lynx to its environment makes it difficult to reproduce, and poaching for its fur has caused its population to decline dramatically.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: -Domestic: Very few individuals are believed to survive in the North Korean provinces of Hamgyong and Jagang. No official records have been found in South Korea. -International: Found from Europe to Siberia, China, and Mongolia, mostly above 40° north latitude.

name: Korean red fox
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal has a body length of 60 to 78 centimeters, hind feet 12 to 18 centimeters long, tail 40 to 47 centimeters long, ears 7 to 9 centimeters long, and weighs about 5.9 kilograms in males and 5.2 kilograms in females. Their mouth and nose are slender and long, and their ears are large and stand up. Their fur is dark brown or reddish in color, and their legs are long and thin. The backs of their ears and the tops of their feet are black. Young cubs have a dark gray or pale black coat mixed with other colors.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The average lifespan is 6 to 10 years, with a maximum lifespan of 15 years. Males are solitary, while females live in families and groups. It is characterized by scatting on tree stumps, flat rocks, open areas, and travel corridors for territorial marking and communication: They live in rocky or earthen burrows in mountain forests, grasslands, and near villages. They dig their own burrows, but they may also steal burrows from other animals.- Food: They are omnivorous, eating mice, rabbits, birds and their eggs, frogs, fish, plant fruits, and insects.- They mate in January and February, with a gestation period of 50 to 60 days, and give birth to four to six young at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The indiscriminate illegal trapping for fur, coupled with secondary poisoning caused by foxes eating rodenticide-poisoned rats during the rat eradication campaigns of the 1960s, are thought to be the decisive factors in the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It was frequently observed until the 1960s, but is believed to have been extinct in Korea since 1980. Currently, a restoration project is underway centered on Sobaeksan National Park since 2012. - International: There are 12 species of foxes worldwide, and the Korean species is widely distributed in the northern hemisphere, mainly in Eurasia, North Africa, Canada, and the United States.

name: Ussuri tube-nosed bat
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 4.1 centimeters long, has a wingspan of 2.7 to 3.4 centimeters, and weighs between 4 and 8 grams. It has a tube-shaped nose that protrudes outward. Its body is covered with long hairs with a woolly undercoat. The color of its back is brown or dark brown, its belly is white, and its wing membranes are dark brown. Its wings are short compared to its body length, and the wing membranes are attached to the tips of the outer toes of its hind feet.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The little free-tailed bat has a communal system in which several females share the care of their young. In the fall, when the young are sexually mature and independent, the communal colony dissolves. Habitat: Found primarily in forests, they use large bark and tree cavities for shelter. During the active season, it rolls up leaves to hide.- Food: It feeds mainly on insects such as mosquitoes and mayflies.- Mates from June to August and gives birth to one to two young at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss due to forest clearing and logging is a major factor in the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: It has been difficult to observe since the 1960s, but it was recognized as living in Korea by the National Biological Resource Center in 2011. It is currently known to be found in Sobaeksan Mountain in Gyeongsangbuk-do, Wolaksan Mountain in Chungcheongbuk-do, Hwacheoncheon-gun in Gangwon-do, Pocheon-si in Gyeonggi-do, and Jeju-do.- Overseas: Distributed in Hokkaido, Japan, Ussuri, Russia, and Northeast China.

name: Amur leopard
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Panthera pardus pardus orientalis is a large cat with a body length of 106 to 180 centimeters, a hind leg length of 20 to 32 centimeters, a tail length of 70 to 100 centimeters, and a weight of 32 to 48 kilograms in males and 25 to 42 kilograms in females. The head is large and round, with round eyes, a pointed nose, and short, rounded ears. The whiskers are short. Their body is lean and strong, and their fur color is yellow or yellowish-red with black spots on the body, legs, and tail. It has tan hairs on its back and in the center of the pattern on the sides of its body. Its claws are half-moon shaped and very sharp. It has a long tail, more than half the length of its body.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is agile in its movements and has a quick gait. It can pick up speed at a moment's notice, making it well suited to hunting agile animals such as mule deer and elk.- Habitat: Lives in alpine forests and is active after dark.- Prey: Roe deer, rabbits, wild boar, pheasants, badgers, raccoons, and voles.- Mates in January and has a gestation period of about 100 days, giving birth to two to five young at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population declined dramatically during the Japanese occupation of Korea (1910-1945), and is believed to be extinct on the Korean Peninsula due to the demand for fur and habitat destruction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Once recorded throughout the country, but now thought to be extirpated from the Korean Peninsula. In 1999, the species was confirmed in the Gaema Plateau region. - International: About 20 individuals are thought to survive in the Baekdu Mountain area. It is widely distributed in China, Central Asia, Siberia, Africa, India, Myanmar, Sri Lanka, Malaysia, and Java.

name: Siberian tiger
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Panthera tigris altaica is 140 to 280 centimeters long, with a hind foot length of 31 centimeters, a tail length of 60 to 97 centimeters, and a body weight of 100 to 250 kilograms. The upper surface of the body is generally tan with about 24 black horizontal stripes, while the lower surface is white with pale horizontal stripes. The tail also has about eight black ring-like horizontal stripes. It's the largest of the big cats that live on the Korean Peninsula.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It molts twice a year, in March and September. It marks its territory by making claw marks on trees, spraying secretions, and rubbing itself, leaving behind its fur and body odor.- Habitat: Lives in deep mountain jungles, reed beds, and rocky areas, preferring dense forests near water.- Prey: Wild boar, deer, and other prey.- Range: It mates from November to March, with a gestation period of about 100 days and two to five cubs at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population plummeted during the Japanese occupation of Korea (1910-1945) due to sea water salvage projects, and is now thought to be extinct on the Korean Peninsula due to indiscriminate overfishing for leopard pelts.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: The last record of the species was captured by the Japanese at Daedeoksan Mountain in Gyeongju in 1922, and it has not been found in South Korea since; in North Korea, a small number of individuals are believed to inhabit Hamgyong Province.

name: Yellow-throated marten
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It has a body length of 59 to 68 centimeters, hind legs of 10 to 14 centimeters, a tail length of 40 to 45 centimeters, and weighs between 3 and 4 kilograms. Its head, face, legs, and tail are black-brown with a single black band running from behind the ears. The neck is light yellow, the nape is darker, and the lower jaw is white. The back is light brown, turning black towards the tail, and the belly is a light apricot color. It has a long tail that makes up more than 60% of its body length.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It marks its territory with a secretion from its anal glands. It has tough hairs on the soles of its feet that make it agile and quick on slippery surfaces.- Habitat: It lives in dense coniferous forests at altitudes below 1,000 meters. They have a wide home range of up to 60 kilometers - Food: They live in groups of two to five individuals and hunt in packs. They are omnivorous, feeding mainly on fruit and nectar, but also occasionally on rodents, birds, elk, roe deer, and wild boar fawns.- They mate in February or June-August, with a gestation period of 270 to 285 days, giving birth to two to three young at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species was once common in the central part of the Korean Peninsula, but since the 1980s, its population has been declining due to deforestation, lack of habitat, and poaching, including the construction of mountain roads. It is also a frequent victim of roadkill from cars while traveling long distances.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the inland mountainous areas of the country; - International: Distributed in Asia, Sudan, China, Indonesia, Pakistan, Russia, Taiwan, Vietnam, and other countries.

name: Least weasel
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is 12 to 16 centimeters long and has an elongated body that stretches from head to rump. Its ears are short and rounded, and its eyes are set at an angle. Its fur is dark reddish-brown in color, with white on its chin, belly, and inside of its hind legs.  Its legs are short, and its toes are small and slender, covered in fur. They molt in the winter, changing their color to white. Its tail makes up 30% of its total length.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is the smallest known species of carnivorous mammal. It hunts mostly during the day and lives independently: It can be found in a variety of habitats, including woodlands and grasslands. They live in burrows, rock crevices, tree hollows, and other places where they can hide. Prey: Small rodents are their main food source, but they have also been known to hunt amphibians, reptiles, insects, crabs, and birds that are larger than themselves.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This animal has a short life expectancy in the wild because its small size makes it easy to be targeted (and eaten) by predators such as owls and snakes.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: First known from Musan, Hamgyongbuk-do, North Korea, it is distributed throughout the country except Jeju Island and Ulleung Island, but its exact habitat and population in South Korea is unknown. It is believed to be distributed in Odaesan and Seoraksan in Gangwon-do Province, Cheongdo County, Gyeongsangbuk-do Province, Seongnam-si, Gyeonggi-do Province, and Jirisan, Gyeonggi-do Province.- Overseas: It has been found in a wide range of areas, including Eurasia and North America.

name: Northern fur seal
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Callorhinus ursinus is about 1.5 to 2.1 meters long and weighs about 270 kilograms in males and 60 kilograms in females, with males being about 4.5 to 5.0 times larger than females. The head is strong, with a thick neck, and the body is thick in the middle and pointed at both ends, similar to a spinning wheel. The fur appears black when wet, but can vary in color. The legs are shaped like fish fins, which makes them perfect for swimming. The front fins are relatively long, and the hind fins can be rotated forward, allowing them to walk on land. The tail is short, and when males reach full maturity, they develop a mane that extends from the neck to the shoulders.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Breeds on islands along the east and west coasts of the North Pacific Ocean north of 42° N. latitude and offshore areas. In winter, it migrates south to waters as far north as 34° N. latitude. In the water, it can swim fast, reaching speeds of up to 25 kilometers per hour. A single male that wins a competition becomes the leader of a group and leads several females. They live mainly in cold waters and spend most of their time at sea. Only during the breeding season do they gather in schools on remote islands and rocky coastal areas.- Food: Squid and small fish such as herring, pollock, and sardines, mostly from far offshore.- Mating occurs in June and July, with a gestation period of about 11 to 12 months, and they give birth to one pup at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Excessive overfishing of fish has reduced food resources, resulting in poor habitat, and environmental changes such as El Niño have adversely affected their survival. Illegal trapping for fur is also a factor in their decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Formerly common along the east coast, but now migrates to the eastern seas in winter and occasionally appears in the southern Bering Sea and the southern western Pacific Ocean; - International: Has a wide distribution range in the waters around the Sea of Okhotsk and Bering Sea. The main colonies are San Miguel Island off the coast of California, with about 200 individuals, and the Kuril Islands, with about 30,000 individuals.

name: Spotted seal
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is the smallest member of the seal family, measuring between 1.4 and 2.0 meters in length and weighing 90 kilograms. It has a high, rounded head and a short neck. Its body is pale silver-gray, with a bright white belly. It has darker spots on its back than its fur. Its legs are fin-like, so they don't have much support in the water.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The spotted seal, also known as the spotted or long-spotted seal, is listed as a natural monument. They are monogamous pairs of males and females, with an average life expectancy of 29 years for males and 32 years for females, and are territorial. Habitat: Due to their global migration, they have a wide range of habitats with no specific habitat, and their habitat varies by season. They live in icy waters from winter to early summer, including the breeding season, and move inshore from late summer to fall.- Food: They feed on fish, macro-plankton, large crustaceans, octopus, and cephalopods.- Mating occurs from April to October, and they give birth to a single calf in March or April. The gestation period is about 11 to 12 months, and the mother nurses the young for three to four weeks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Indiscriminate hunting for fur and fishing gear, coastal pollution from port development and ship traffic, and habitat destruction are the main causes of the decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: There are about 300 individuals in the Baengnyeong Island area of the west coast. It is also distributed in Garorim Bay and the East and South Seas throughout the country. It is the only one of the 18 species of seals in the world to inhabit the Korean Peninsula and is a seasonal migrant.- International: Due to their nature, seals are seasonally migratory and distributed over a wide area of the world. They spend the winter in the waters of the Kamchatka Peninsula and Okhotsk, with some appearing on the Korean Peninsula, and return to the North Pacific in the spring.

name: Leopard cat
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This cat has a body length of 45 to 55 centimeters, hind feet of 10.5 to 12.2 centimeters, a tail length of 15 to 40 centimeters, and weighs 3 to 5 kilograms. They can be distinguished from cats by the white spots behind their auricles, and they have grayish-white cheeks with three brown stripes. Two rows of black and brown markings and a white pattern run from the forehead to the back of the head. Its fur color is mostly tan or reddish brown, with many irregular spots on its body. Its claws are very small but sharp, and its tail, which is about half the length of its head and body, has seven faint grayish-brown spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Average lifespan is 10 to 15 years, with teeth starting to fall out around 8 to 10 years of age - Habitat: Lives in forests, fields, and vegetated areas around human settlements. They are nocturnal and live along streams and use large fallen trees in the forest, rock crevices and holes in the ground for shelter.- Prey: Rodents, birds and insects, but they prefer rodents as their main food source. Adults will also hunt elk, boar cubs, and other animals larger than themselves. They are also good swimmers and sometimes hunt for fish.- They mate in March and April, with a gestation period of about 56 to 70 days, and give birth to two to three cubs at a time. Both sexes raise their young together.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The use of powerful rodenticides such as "Pradol" after June 25 has caused secondary damage to top predators, such as deer and foxes.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout the country, except for Jeju Island and some islands, but accurate population estimates are difficult. - International: Distributed in Russia, China, Siberia, and Japan.

name: Steller sea lion
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Males average 2.8 meters in length and weigh about 566 kilograms, while females average 2.3 meters in length and weigh about 273 kilograms. They are characterized by a large, broad head and snout, and small eyes and auricles relative to the head. Except in mature males, the snout and crown are not distinctly separated and there is no forehead. Mature males have a fleur-de-lis-like projection on the skull that separates the crown from the snout. During the breeding season, males have a long mane around their neck and shoulders, and their fur is dark brown or tan in color on their backs and darkens toward their belly. They can grip the ground with their hind legs, allowing them to walk or run on the ground.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Polygamous, with a single male having multiple females. It is nicknamed the king of the sea because it is the largest mammal in the carnivorous sea lion family. They can swim at speeds of 25 to 30 kilometers per hour and dive to depths of 110 to 146 meters.- Habitat: They live in groups year-round in the ocean around their breeding grounds, and come ashore on land, such as reefs and islands, to sleep during the day.- Diet: They eat fish, cephalopods, clams, shrimp, crustaceans, and the young of other seal species.- They mate from May to July and give birth to one to two pups at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations have declined due to lack of food, bycatch, habitat destruction and pollution from expanding fishing, and death by entanglement in fishing nets is a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Inhabits the coasts of Jeju Island, Dokdo, and Ulleungdo. It has no breeding grounds in Korea and migrates south from its breeding grounds around Sakhalin and the Kamchatka Peninsula. It is found from winter to spring, with rare juvenile males in the west coast and mainly adult males in the east coast. - Overseas: Distributed along the west coast of North America near 66° N. latitude, including San Miguel Island in California, northern Japan, Sakhalin, the Kuril Islands, the Sea of Okhotsk, and the Kamchatka Peninsula in Russia.

name: Ognev's long-eared bat
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Plecotus ognevi is a medium-sized bat with a body length of 4.2 to 6.0 centimeters, a wingspan of 3.4 to 4.5 centimeters, a tail length of 3.2 to 5.5 centimeters, and a weight of 2 to 5 grams. It is a medium-sized bat with relatively long ears. The bases of the left and right ears meet just past the forehead, and the muzzle is short and the nostrils are open, with a comma (,) shape. Its face is light brown, and its fur is long and soft, dark brown or light brown. On its back, it has three colors: light brown, beige, and olive, and on its belly, it has two colors: light yellow and brown. Its tail is long compared to its body, reaching more than 90% of its total length.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Nicknamed the "long-eared bat" because of its long ears compared to the rest of its body. If they are unable to hibernate reliably during the winter, they may die from excessive physical (energy) exhaustion.- Habitat: Lives in tree cavities, caves, and houses, and hibernates in abandoned mines or caves with high humidity during the winter.- Food: A diet of insects such as butterflies, moths, and robbers, hunting for food by flying at slow speeds in forested areas.- Mates in July and August, and delays implantation of fertilized eggs during hibernation, giving birth to a single pup in April or May after emerging from hibernation.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Because its habitat is limited to mountainous areas, caves, and abandoned mines, its population is declining due to the destruction of its habitat by road construction and forest development.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the central and northern parts of the Korean Peninsula, mainly in the mountainous regions of Chungcheongbuk-do, Gangwon-do, and northern Gyeongsangbuk-do.

name: Siberian flying squirrel
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Pteromys volans is a nocturnal small mammal with a body length of 14.6 to 16.3 centimeters, a tail length of 9.75 to 12.1 centimeters, and a weight of 80 to 120 grams. It has very large eyes compared to other rodents, and its ears are wide and short. They usually have two colors, gray and brown, which change to a pale silver-gray in winter. The belly is white, with a wing membrane (nasal membrane) that extends from the ankle of the front paws to the knee of the hind paws. The tail is flat and shorter than its body length.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: gliding from tree to tree using wing membranes is its ecological characteristic. It can travel 20 to 30 meters, sometimes more than 100 meters, in a single glide.- Habitat: Natural forests with broadleaf trees, mixed forests with different tree species, and plantations. Most use tree cavities as nests.- Food: Bark, leaves, seeds, and fruits, but also caterpillars and bird eggs.- Mates in March or April or July or August, giving birth to two to six young at a time. Females have multiple mates with multiple males.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to deforestation, dam construction, habitat alteration, and pesticide poisoning to prevent disease.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: It has a nationwide distribution except for the islands of Jeju and Ulleungdo. It is known to be particularly dense in the dense forests around the Donggang River. It serves as an indicator species for the health of forest ecosystems. - Overseas: Distributed in eastern Russia, northern China, and the Hokkaido Islands of Japan.

name: Golden eagle
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 66 to 90 centimeters, wingspan is 180 to 234 centimeters, and weight is 2.8 to 4.6 kilograms in males and 3.6 to 6.7 kilograms in females, with females being larger on average. They are dark brown overall, with tan coloring from the back of the head to the neck. Young birds are white in the center of the wings and inside the bill. The bill is curved downward like a hook and is black with a pale gray base. It's one of the largest birds of prey in the world and can hunt cranes, livestock, and medium to large mammals. They have long wings and are covered in feathers all the way down to their ankles, except for their toes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: When active, it lifts its wings slightly upward to form a vague V-shape; - Habitat: It builds nests in recesses in rock walls or on the branches of trees, piling dry branches and leaves or stems of various plants around its breeding area. In winter, they live in streams, plains, coastal areas, or flatlands - Prey: Rabbits, squirrels, pheasants, and ducks - Pairs form in January and February and lay eggs in March and April. They lay 1 to 4 bluish-white eggs. The incubation period is 44 to 45 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 77 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss is the main threat, with additional threats including lead poisoning and collisions with power lines and wind turbines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In winter, small numbers occur in Cheorwon-gun, Gangwon-do, Paju-si, Gyeonggi-do, Yeoncheon-gun, Seosan-si, Chungcheongnam-do, Yeongam-gun, Jeollanam-do, Gumi-si, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Busan, etc. In the past, there were breeding records in Gyeonggi-do and Gangwon-do, but breeding has not been confirmed in recent years. - Overseas: Widely distributed throughout the old and new North Korea.

name: Spoon-billed sandpiper
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This 14.5-centimeter-long bird has a black bill with a spatula-shaped tip. In summer, its head, chest, and back are reddish-brown in color, with dark brown stripes on its chest. In winter, the upper part of the body turns a pale gray color, at the same time the eyebrow line and breast turn white. The legs are always black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A migratory bird that passes through Korea on its spring and fall migration from breeding grounds to wintering grounds, with very small numbers passing through the country. Habitat: Breeds in grasslands around estuaries, lakes, and marshes, and prefers sandy mudflats such as reclaimed land, salt ponds, small settlements, estuaries, and coasts during the non-breeding season.- Food: During the breeding season, they feed on insects such as moths, mosquitoes, flies, and spiders, and on marine invertebrates such as midges and small shrimp along the shore at stopover sites.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining rapidly due to habitat loss from reclamation and development of tidal flats on the west coast of its stopover area and overfishing in its wintering grounds, with an estimated breeding population of 490 individuals based on an analysis of data from 2014-2019.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Very small numbers occur on tidal flats and estuaries along the west and south coasts during spring and fall migration. Only a few individuals have been recorded in Yubu Island and the Nakdong River estuary, and only 25 individuals have been recorded from 2017 to 2020. - International: Breeds on the tundra coast of Far Eastern Russia, and after breeding, migrates along the East Asian coast via Russia, Japan, North Korea, China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan to overwinter in Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Thailand.

name: Chinese egret
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 65 to 68 centimeters long and weighs 390 to 540 grams, with a white body and cloudy yellow eyes. During the breeding season, the beak is yellow, the legs are black, the feet are yellow, and a long tuft of decorative feathers develops behind the head. When breeding is over, the bill turns blackish-brown and the feathers disappear. The legs turn yellowish green.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is characterized by its active feeding behavior, such as chasing prey by jumping and stabbing repeatedly underwater: Breeds on uninhabited islands along the west coast, inhabiting mudflats and salt flats along the coast. It feeds singly or in small groups, but during the fall migration season, large numbers form flocks.- Prey: It feeds on fish, crabs, shrimp and other crustaceans, midges, etc. in shallow water in mudflats or marshes near the sea. It can be observed feeding in the summer at the tidal flats at the southern end of Ganghwa, the estuary of the Han River, Myeongdong Island, Cheonsu Bay, and Cheonsu Bay.- It arrives at the breeding grounds in April or May, collects dry branches such as myeongju and wormwood on the shrubs or on the ground, builds a nest, and lays 2 to 5 pale blue-green eggs. The incubation period is 21 to 26 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 36 to 40 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are habitat loss and degradation due to reclamation of tidal flats and estuaries and development of uninhabited islands. Other threats include human disturbance such as fishing and egg collection in breeding areas, lack of nesting resources due to lack of vegetation, and intra- and inter-species competition on uninhabited islands.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed from the west coast to the southern coast, rarely on the east coast. It breeds on uninhabited islands along the west coast and is observed from spring to fall in tidal flats, agricultural fields adjacent to tidal flats, and estuaries.- International: Distributed in Japan, Hong Kong, Taiwan, Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines, Malaysia, Singapore, Burma, and Indonesia during the non-breeding season.

name: Red-crowned crane
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird with a body length of 136 to 150 centimeters, a weight of 7 to 12 kilograms, and a wingspan of 220 to 250 centimeters. It has no feathers and reddish skin on its forehead, top of the head, and in front of the eyes. The body is white, with a black throat and neck area, and white behind the eyes, ears, and back of the head. The beak is pale yellow with a bright tip, and the second, third, and fourth wing feathers and legs are black. This characteristic makes their rump appear black when they walk. In young birds, the head, neck, and upper surface of the body are light brown. The rest of the feathers are white, with tan tips.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: In February and March, males and females face each other, point their bills to the sky, and repeatedly call in courtship behavior.- Habitat: In wintering areas, it feeds mainly in agricultural fields or mudflats, and uses frozen reservoirs, river sandbanks, etc. for roosting. In breeding areas, it inhabits marshes or super-marshes where reeds and cattails grow. - Food: In Korea, it mainly feeds on grains in rice fields, yulmu fields, corn fields, etc. in civilian-controlled areas. It also feeds on insects, loaches, tadpoles, midges, midges, moles, and rodents.- It lays two eggs around April and May. The eggs are incubated by both sexes and hatch in about 32 to 33 days, and after hatching, the young are cared for by the mother bird for about six months.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Its population and distribution are shrinking, with habitat loss being the biggest threat. Other threats include human collection and consumption of eggs, pesticide poisoning, and collisions with power lines in flight. Habitat loss has led to an increasing number of individuals arriving in the remaining habitat, increasing the risk of mass mortality due to disease.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: The main wintering areas are the demilitarized zone and civilian-controlled areas, including Chulwon-gun, Gangwon-do, Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do, Paju-si, and Ganghwa-gun, Gangwon-do; - Overseas: Breeds in Hankah Lake in southeastern Russia and Northeast China, and overwinters in central China. There is a year-round population in Hokkaido, Japan.

name: Peregrine falcon
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 36 to 49 centimeters in males and 45 to 58 centimeters in females, the weight is 0.4 to 1.1 kilograms in males and 0.6 to 1.6 kilograms in females, and the wingspan is 79 to 114 centimeters. The black pattern under the eyes is large and distinct, the eye rims are yellow, and the irises are reddish-brown. The upperparts of the body are dark blue-gray, and the underside is white with black horizontal stripes. Males and females are almost identical in color, but young birds have brown backs and bold, dark brown vertical stripes on their bellies.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: During the breeding season, the male delivers the prey he catches to the female in mid-air near the nest. It is one of the fastest birds, reaching speeds of up to 300 kilometers per hour when snatching prey. Its English name is the Peregrine Falcon, which means wanderer, and individuals in northern North America can travel 25,000 kilometers per year. In Brazil, Argentina, and other countries, they have adapted to cities, breeding in skyscrapers and flying through forests of buildings.- Habitat: Domestically, they breed on uninhabited islands and steep coastal cliffs. It rests and forages on high terrain, such as treetops and rocky areas, looking downward to rest and feed.- Prey: It feeds on birds such as pheasants, ducks, plovers, and pigeons, and most of its prey weighs between 50 and 500 grams.- Breeds in recesses in rocky cliffs along the coast, and does not build nests. The breeding season is from February to June, with three to four eggs laid at a time from late February to March. The incubation period is 29 to 32 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, is 35 to 42 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The global use of organochlorine pesticides such as DDT from the 1950s to the 1970s led to population declines due to the accumulation of pesticide residues, and an increase in reproductive failure due to thinner eggshells. After DDT was banned in 1970, the population is believed to have increased, but there are still threats such as habitat degradation, poaching, trapping for falconry, and collisions with structures.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout the country, mainly on coastal islands and migratory flyways. Domestic populations are small, and during the breeding season they are often found on uninhabited islands along migratory routes, mainly along the southwest coast. - International: One of the most widely distributed species, occurring throughout the world except for the Amazon basin, the Sahara desert, the steppe regions of Central and Northeast Asia, and Antarctica.

name: Black stork
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird, 90 to 100 centimeters long. Its body is black with green and purple sheen, reddish around the bill, legs, and eyes, and white on the chest and belly. The slightly raised feathers on the back of the head are visible at close range. When flying, some of the lower wing feathers on the inside of the body are white. Young birds are greenish-gray around the bill and eyes, and their legs are greenish-yellow. The upperparts of the body have little green sheen, and the neck is scattered with small white spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A wintering bird that migrates through the peninsula. It arrives in mid-October and can be seen until late March.- Habitat: It lives in agricultural areas, rivers, estuaries, reservoirs, streams, and grassy wetlands.- Food: It feeds on fish, amphibians, and reptiles.- Nests are very large, often made of twigs on rocks or trees, and are often used for several years. The breeding season is from mid-March through May, and they typically lay about three to four eggs at a time. The incubation period is 32 to 38 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 63 to 71 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include habitat loss and degradation due to development and pollution, reduced prey resources, trapping, and collisions with structures.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: There are records of breeding in Andong City in the past, but there have been no breeding records since 1968. Very small numbers winter in the lower reaches of the Nakdong River in Busan, Cheonsu Bay, and Jeju Island.- Overseas: Distributed throughout East Asia, South Africa, Southwestern Europe, and Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Black-faced spoonbill
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A medium to large bird with a body length of 60 to 78.5 centimeters. Its body is entirely white, with a black bill and legs. Its long, spatula-like bill has many wrinkles on its upper surface, which, like human fingerprints, are unique to each individual. During the breeding season, they have a long decorative collar behind their head and a yellow breast band. Young individuals have a pinkish-gray bill, no wrinkles, and black wing tips.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Breeds on uninhabited coastal islands and lives in mudflats, river mouths, reservoirs, and coastal freshwater marshes; also feeds in coastal rice paddies during the breeding season.- Prey: Small fish, shrimp, crabs, frogs, tadpoles, and larvae.- More than 90% of the breeding population breeds domestically. Nests are built in branches, rock crevices, or on the ground. The breeding season is from April to July, with 2 to 4 eggs laid in April and May. The incubation period is about 25 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, is about 40 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: International conservation efforts have increased the population from about 300 to 6,600 individuals over the past 30 years, but habitat is declining due to mudflat reclamation and coastal development along the west coast. Other threats include fishing line damage, egg collection, introduction of predators into breeding areas, increased pollutants, and disease outbreaks in colonies.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Breeds on uninhabited islands along the west coast and off the coast of Incheon Metropolitan City, with most breeding sites in Incheon Bay and Gyeonggi Bay. During the migration season, they use coastal wetlands such as Ganghwa Island, Yeongjong Island, Songdo tidal flats, Sihwa Lake in Ansan City, Hwaeong Lake in Hwaseong City, and Saemangeum reclaimed land. In winter, a small number overwinter on Jeju Island, with Seongsan-ri, Jongdali Coast, and Hadori Fish Farm on the east coast being the main overwintering sites.- Overseas: A small number breed in China, northeastern Russia, and North Korea. It also breeds in Kyushu, Japan, Hong Kong, Vietnam, South China, the Philippines, and Thailand, including its largest wintering area, Tainan, southern Taiwan.

name: Steller's sea eagle
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird of prey with a body length of 88 to 105 centimeters, a weight of 5 to 6 kilograms in males and 7 to 9 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 195 to 245 centimeters. It's characterized by its large beak and wedge-shaped bill. The feathers in front of the eyes are yellow. The forehead, shoulders, back, upper crown, and tail feathers are white, while the rest of the body is dark brown. When flying, the back of the wings appear rounded and widen towards the wing tips. The young bird's body is black overall, with a white bill but brownish edges, and the first and second wing feathers are partially white.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The largest of the large birds of prey in the Haliaeetus family.- Habitat: During the breeding season, they live in forested coastal areas and rivers, building nests on cliffs, hillsides, and trees along the coast. During the winter, they live mostly in rivers, but have also been found along lakeshores and coasts.- Prey: They feed mainly on fish, but also on small mammals and birds such as ducks and gulls.- They build large nests of branches up to 2.5 meters wide and lay eggs in April and May, with one to three clutches, an incubation period of 38 to 45 days, and an incubation period of 70 days to raise the hatched chicks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the development of forests adjacent to the coast and the loss of habitat to human activities. Lead poisoning from lead bullets, river pollution, and hunting are additional threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Wintering bird, irregularly found on coasts, estuaries, and large reclaimed areas throughout the country; - International: Breeds on the coast of Okhotsk, Kamchatka, and Sakhalin; during wintering, distributed in Ussuri and Japan. It is estimated that about 6,000-7,000 individuals remain worldwide.

name: Nordmann's greenshank
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 28.5 to 34 centimeters long and weighs 125 to 170 grams. Its long, thick bill is slightly curved upward, black at the tip and yellowish at the base. Its legs are greenish-yellow, and compared to other shorebirds, it has shorter legs compared to its body. The summer plumage has black spots on the head and chest, and the upper surface of the body is a dark grayish-brown color. The irises are dark brown. The winter plumage has pale stripes on the head and neck, and the upper surface of the body is pale gray. When flying, the legs stick out slightly behind the tail.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: During the breeding season, the white spotted pattern on the back and wings becomes brighter and more pronounced, and a black crescent-shaped pattern develops on the underside of the neck. Compared to other shorebirds, it is characterized by having shorter legs than its body. Habitat: During migration and wintering, it uses coastal mudflats, river mouths, and salt flats. Breeding sites include leafy oak forests, coastal lowland marshes, and mudflats.- Food: Crustaceans, fish, and mollusks.- Breeds on the ground or in trees from late May to mid-June, laying about four eggs at a time. Young birds fledge in July or August. The eggs are blue-green in color with dark spots.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss due to mudflat reclamation and coastal development along the west coast is the main cause of the population decline, and habitat in Russia is also being degraded by oil industry-related development. Poaching and pollution of coastal wetlands are other threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It is a migratory bird that passes through Korea during spring and fall migration, and a small number of them arrive at Yeongjong Island, Songdo tidal flats, and the Nakdong River estuary in Gyeongsangnam-do on the west and south coasts. During migration, they pass through China, Japan, Taiwan, etc.

name: White-bellied woodpecker
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: At 46 centimeters long, this is the largest of the domestic woodpecker family. Its body is black overall, with white on the belly, back, and the inside of the undersides of the wings (underwing feathers). Males are distinguished from females, whose heads are entirely black, by the red coloration from forehead to back of the head, and the red cheek lines (stripes on the cheeks) on their faces. The beak is black and the legs are dark gray. The black-cockaded woodpecker, a related species, is easily distinguishable from the knackbill by its all-black body.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The Korean subspecies is Dryocopus javensis richardsi, which is distributed only on the Korean Peninsula and Daemado, and is the most northerly subspecies of the Knackbird subspecies.- Habitat: It lives in mixed hardwood and coniferous forests of fir, pine, pine, oak, chestnut, and other hardwoods, and forests with old trees between 100 and 300 years old are the main habitat.- Food: It feeds on large beetle larvae by stripping the bark and digging holes. In the fall, it also eats plant foods such as dogwood berries.- Males and females build nests together in holes in dead or semi-dead trees. The breeding season is from April to August, and the eggs are white and are laid in clutches of 2 to 5 at a time, with the male and female taking turns incubating for 14 days. Generally, more males than females lay eggs.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species uses dense forests for habitat, making it vulnerable to habitat loss due to forest development. Forest loss and degradation is also thought to be a major contributor to the decline of the domestic population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In Korea, it has been observed in some limited areas, including Gyeonggi-do National Arboretum, Suwon, and Busan, but it has not been confirmed since 1981 and is presumed to be locally extinct. In North Korea, it is known to inhabit some areas such as Kaesong, but there is no accurate information. - Overseas: Distributed in India, Myanmar, China, Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei, etc.

name: Scaly-sided merganser
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 52 to 62 centimeters long and weighs 1.1 to 1.4 kilograms. It has a red bill with a yellow tip, red legs, and grayish-brown irises. The male's summer plumage is greenish-glossy on the head and neck, with a long dangling feather. They have black scales on the back and sides, white on the chest and underparts, and gray on the back. The female's head is light brown with a shorter bill than the male. The male's winter plumage is similar to the female's, except that it has a larger white area on the upper wings and a pattern of scales on the sides of the body, which is absent from the female's summer plumage.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The global population is estimated to be between 3,600 and 6,800 individuals.- Habitat: During the breeding season, it uses fast-moving streams with dense understory vegetation and surrounded by dense forests. During the winter, they use mid- and upper reaches of undisturbed, fast-moving streams, and also overwinter in lakes and reservoirs.- Food: They feed primarily on small fish and aquatic invertebrates.- Breeds from May through August, laying 8 to 10 eggs at a time. They breed in tree cavities in forested areas along rivers. The incubation period is 31 to 35 days, and the young birds leave the nest within 48 to 60 hours of hatching and accompany their parents. They become independent after about eight weeks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In Korea, the population is believed to be declining due to development such as river channelization. Other causes of population decline include deforestation in breeding areas, human disturbance, illegal trapping, and heavy metal enrichment.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A wintering bird, small flocks are locally distributed around rivers, reservoirs, and coasts in mountainous areas such as the South Han River, North Han River, and Daecheong Lake; - International: Breeds in Ussuri, northeastern China, and overwinters in southern and central China, southeastern Russia, and Japan.

name: Mute swan
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird with a body length of about 152 centimeters, a wingspan of about 2.4 meters, and a weight of about 6.3 kilograms in males and 5.1 kilograms in females. The body is white in both sexes, except for the skin in front of the eyes, the base of the bill, the large hump at the base of the upper bill, and the lower bill, which is black. The rest of the upper bill is reddish-yellow, and the legs are gray.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The hump on its bill gives it the name humpback whale. It is easily distinguished from other swans by its bright orange bill and black hump.- Habitat: Inhabits estuaries, reservoirs, lakes, and the lower reaches of slow-moving rivers.- Food: Submerges its head up to its neck in water to feed on aquatic plants and aquatic animals.- Builds nests in marshes with well-developed aquatic vegetation, using aquatic plants and soil. Breeds in April and May, laying 2 to 5 eggs at a time. The egg-laying period is about 40 days, and the incubation period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 120 to 150 days. The eggs are white with a bluish-green color.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In east coast lagoons, where large numbers of individuals once occurred, degraded habitat due to development has led to a dramatic decline in the population. In domestic lakes and wetlands, where few individuals currently occur, degraded habitat due to development is a major threat to the domestic wintering population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Wintering in estuarine reservoirs and rivers throughout Korea. Hwajinpo Lake, Gyeongpo Lake, etc. were the main staging areas, but it is currently difficult to observe. From 2010 to 2023, a small number of individuals have been observed in Sihwa Lake, Paldang Lake, Namhan River, Cheonsu Bay, Nakdong River estuary, Yeoncheon County, Gyeonggi-do, and Jeju Island, etc.- Overseas: Distributed throughout Europe, Central Asia such as Turkey and Kazakhstan, south-central Russia, China, Mongolia, Japan, and India.

name: Oriental white stork
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
