Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird has a body length of about 110 centimeters, a wingspan of about 195 centimeters, and a weight of 4.4 to 5 kilograms. When perched on the ground, the back of the wings and the rump appear black, but only the wing tips are black, and the rest of the body is white. Males and females are the same color, so it's hard to tell them apart in the wild. The beak is black and long, with red on the legs and around the eyes. When it flies, it stretches out its neck.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: During the breeding season, the bird makes a "tinkle, tinkle, tinkle" sound by striking its bill. Reintroductions of artificially propagated individuals have been underway since 2015, and the first breeding between reintroduced individuals was confirmed in 2020. In 2023, the first natural breeding between a reintroduced individual and a wild stork was recorded.- Habitat: Inhabits large open fields or wetland waters, such as reservoirs, estuaries, grassland, and agricultural fields.- Prey: Fish, amphibians, reptiles, and insects.- Breeds in trees and dead vegetation, and also in artificial nesting towers. Breeds from April to August, and usually lays three to four eggs at a time. Eggs are white in color and are usually laid by the female during the day. The incubation period is 31 to 35 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 63 to 70 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has been overharvested because it lives near human settlements and is therefore less wary of humans. Habitat loss due to development and reduced food resources due to pesticides are some of the causes of the population decline. For individuals reintroduced through domestic reintroduction programs, collisions with utility poles and power lines have been identified as a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: It was a nationwide breeding bird until 1950, with some populations breeding in the north and wintering in Korea. After the disappearance of the last breeding pair in 1971, a small number of birds winter in Cheonsu Bay, Haenam, Jeju Island, Suncheon Bay, Nakdong River estuary, Nakdong River in Daegu, Upo Swamp, Taehwa River in Ulsan, Sacheon City, and Jumunjin, Korea.

name: White-tailed eagle
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird of prey with a body length of 74 to 92 centimeters, a weight of 3.1 to 5.4 kilograms in males and 3.7 to 6.9 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 193 to 244 centimeters. It is characterized by a white bill and a large yellow bill, and is brownish in color overall. Its head is tan and lighter in color than the rest of its body. The tail is short and rounded rhombic. The wings are rectangular when viewed from below, with the front of the wing and the back of the wing almost parallel. The beak and legs are yellow, but young birds are blackish-brown. In juveniles, the bill is black, the head is darkest with a dark brown color, and the outside of the white bill is blackish-brown. The back and wing feathers are light brown with blackish-brown edges.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The white-tailed eagles observed in Korea are mainly young individuals. Most of them do not reach maturity until five years after hatching.- Habitat: Solitary, mostly in areas with large water surfaces such as coasts, small settlements, lakes, and estuaries.- Prey: Small mammals, birds, and fish, especially salmon and trout.- Breeding season: Mid-March to May.- The bird lays one to four eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 38 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 70 to 90 days. Nests are built by stacking branches on top of each other in forests or on cliffs along the coast. During the breeding season, they line their nests with animal feathers.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to its preference for open areas with water bodies, habitat loss due to development of rivers, coasts, lakes, reclaimed land, and estuaries is thought to be a major threat. In addition, there are cases of heavy metal poisoning by preying on small animals and fish that have ingested lead used in hunting and fishing.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Winters in reclaimed land and large rivers near the coast, including the Han River estuary, Imjin River estuary, Sihwa Lake, Cheonsu Bay, Nakdong River estuary, and Gangneung Namdaecheon. Inland, it is also observed in the Cheorwon Plain, Chungju, Asan, and Andong. It is observed nationwide, but the population is not large. It is very rarely found as a migratory bird in the Black Sand Island and Hongdo regions, and there are breeding records in Black Sand Island. This is the southernmost known breeding site of the white-tailed eagle. - Overseas: Widely distributed across the Eurasian continent from Far East Asia to Europe. It breeds in Greenland, northern and eastern Europe, Russia, and northeastern China, and overwinters in Central Asia, the Mediterranean region, Southeast Asia, southeastern China, and Japan.

name: Swan goose
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A large geese with a length of 81 to 94 centimeters and a weight of 2.8 to 3.5 kilograms. The front and back of the head and neck have a clear color difference. From the forehead to the back of the neck is a chestnut color, and from the cheeks to the front of the neck is a pale brown. The chest and belly are brown, the back and wing tops are dark brown, the lower tail feathers are white, and the legs are orange. The beak is black with a white band at the base, which is absent in young birds.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is the parent of the domesticated goose and has the longest bill, neck, and legs of all geese. Habitat: It is found in river mouths, mudflats, rice paddies, and lakes, and breeds on islands in rivers and streams and in depressions on small islands.- Food: It feeds on the leaves, stems, and roots of aquatic plants, such as sedge, a perennial member of the sedge family that grows on tidal mudflats, and stalks and roots of aquatic plants, such as stalks of the rice family, such as fallen grain and rice in coastal rice paddies.- Nests on the ground in a bed of dry grass stalks. The eggs are creamy white in color and are laid in clutches of 4 to 6. The female incubates the eggs for 28 to 30 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The degradation and loss of wetland habitat is a major cause of population decline. In Korea, habitat loss due to the construction of estuary dams, reclamation of estuaries and tidal flats, and dredging of reservoirs, as well as the reduction of aquatic plants for food due to deepening of water depths, are thought to have had a negative impact. In addition, there are threats such as poaching, habitat loss and degradation due to agricultural land development and livestock grazing, and egg collection, and as wintering habitat decreases, individuals are concentrated in a limited area, making them vulnerable to poisoning and disease.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In the past, there was a wintering population centered on the coast of Sinjeong-ri, Mugan-gun, Jeollanam-do, and Cheonsu Bay, Chungcheongnam-do, but in recent years, most of the population migrates through Korea to China, where only a small number winter. The Imjin River and the lower reaches of the Han River are the largest breeding areas, and other limited breeding areas include the lower Nakdong River, the Geumgang Estuary, the Yeongsan River Basin, and the Junam Reservoir.- Overseas: Widely distributed across the Eurasian continent from Russia to Europe. It breeds in Greenland, northern and eastern Europe, Russia, and northeastern China, and overwinters in Central Asia, the Mediterranean region, Southeast Asia, southeastern China, and Japan.

name: Saunders's gull
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 29 to 32 centimeters, the wingspan is 87 to 91 centimeters, and the weight is 170 to 220 grams. The summer plumage is black on the head and white only around the eyes. The winter plumage has a white head with dark patterns on the ears and crown. The bill is black, the neck, belly, and rump are white, and the back is light gray. When perched, the white spots on the wing tips are clearly visible, and the legs are red. It's hard to tell males from females in appearance, with males being slightly larger than females. Young birds have a brown third wing feather and part of the wing coverts, and a brown band on the tip of the bill.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristic: During the breeding season, the entire head turns black. In 2022, drone photography of a breeding colony at the Songdo New Town landfill was analyzed and found to contain 11% of the world's breeding population (1,456 breeding pairs).- Habitat: Found in flocks of a few individuals or up to several hundred in coastal areas with tidal flats and river mouths. Generally breeds in coastal salt marshes, deltas, etc. and all breeding sites in Korea are landfills.- Prey: Crabs, midges, small fish, etc.- Breeds in groups, building nests by collecting dry stems on the ground. The breeding season is from April to July, and they lay 2 to 3 eggs. The incubation period is 26 to 34 days, and the young leave the nest three days after hatching, but continue to be fed by their parents, and are able to fly about 40 days after hatching.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Trespassing on its breeding grounds, vehicle noise, and light aircraft traffic are contributing factors to breeding failure, and habitat loss due to development and reclamation of tidal flats is causing the population to decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed along the coast of the country, but wintering mainly on the west and south coasts. In spring and summer, it breeds along parts of the west coast. - International: It also breeds along the northeastern coast of China, with internationally important breeding sites. It overwinters in Hong Kong, southern Japan, Taiwan, and northern Vietnam.

name: Eurasian oystercatcher
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This large bird is 40.0 to 47.5 centimeters long and weighs 425 to 820 grams. Both males and females are black on the head, neck, and upper part of the body, and white on the lower part of the body. The beak is red, long and straight, with a thin knife-like shape when viewed from the side. The eyes, rims, and legs are also red. The young bird's back and wing feathers are brownish-black, with tan edges. The red color of the bill and legs is duller than in the adult bird, and the bill has a black tip.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Calls with a high, shrill, "cree" or "pii" sound. It has the longest beak of any shorebird, which it twists open by inserting it into the shell of a shellfish. The subspecies native to Korea is Haematopus ostralegus osculans, which is distributed in Far East Asia and is believed to be in decline.- Habitat: Found in small flocks on uninhabited reefs, estuarine deltas, and mudflats.- Food: They use their long, pointed bills to feed on shellfish in the mudflats, and also eat conchs, midges, insects, crustaceans, fish, and sea horses.- They build concave, saucer-shaped nests by collecting dry grasses on the ground or rocks.- Breeding season is April through July, with eggs laid between April and May. The male and female incubate together for about 28 to 33 days, and the young fledge 30 to 37 days after hatching.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are habitat degradation and loss due to mudflat reclamation, marine pollution, and disturbance from increased human presence on uninhabited islands where they breed.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Inhabits the southwestern coastal areas of Sihwa Lake, Namyang Bay, the coast of Janghang, the Geum River estuary, the Mankyung River, Suncheon Bay, and the Nakdong River estuary. It breeds on some islands off the west coast, and Yubudo is the largest wintering area. - Overseas: It can be found in Europe, west and north Africa, northeast Africa, northwest India, Japan, eastern China, and Taiwan.

name: Yellow-breasted bunting
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is 14.0 to 15.5 centimeters long and weighs 14 to 33 grams. Males are black on the forehead, face, and throat, bright yellow on the chest and back, with a brown band on the upper chest. They are reddish-brown with black stripes from the back to the head. The flanks have dark brown vertical stripes, and the wings are dark brown. The edges of the collar are brown, with two sharp white bands. Females have pale yellow eyebrows, chin, and belly, and brown beak, iris, and legs.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A rare migrant bird of the bunting family that passes through our country in spring and fall. Due to its population decline, its conservation status on the IUCN Red List was upgraded from Near Threatened (NT) in 2004 to Vulnerable (VU) in 2008, Endangered (EN) in 2013, and Critically Endangered (CR) in 2017.- Habitat: It uses agricultural fields, streamsides, reedbeds, small forests near human settlements, hillsides, broadleaf and mixed montane forests, and breeds in shrubby grassland or forest grassland.- Food: In summer, it mainly feeds on animal insects, butterflies, grasshoppers, flying insects, bees, and flies, and also eats plant food such as seeds of the Asteraceae family. It lays 4 to 5 eggs at a time from late May to mid-July. The incubation period is 13 to 14 days and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 11 to 14 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining rapidly due to climate change, development, and over-hunting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: migrates throughout the country during spring and fall migrations, mainly on the islands off the southwest coast; - International: breeds in the Kamchatka Peninsula, the Okhotsk Sea coast, the Amur region, Manchuria, Shantar Island, Sakhalin, and Hokkaido, Japan; - winters in the tropical lowlands of eastern and central North America and Southeast Asia.

name: Common crane
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 95 to 120 centimeters, the weight is 5.1 to 6.1 kilograms in males and 4.5 to 5.9 kilograms in females, and the wingspan is 180 to 200 centimeters. The body is bluish-ashen in color throughout. A narrow strip of reddish skin is exposed on the crown. It's black from the forehead, past the eyes, to the front of the neck, where it forms a white V-shaped pattern from behind the eyes to the back of the neck. The bill is ashy green. When flying, the gray of the wing coverts and the black of the wing feathers contrast sharply. It has long black legs. When it stands, its secondary wing feathers are extended and droop over its rump. Young birds are light gray overall, with a light tan head and neck, and black bill and throat.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: A rare wintering bird. It is one of the longest-lived species of birds, and has actually been recorded to live 20 to 60 years. It takes 4 to 6 years for a young bird to reach adulthood. It has a strong connection to Irish culture and history, being mentioned in several Irish folk legends, used in place names, and kept as a pet during the Middle Ages. However, due to predation by foxes and degraded wetland conditions, the species became extinct in the 1700s, but recent restoration efforts have resulted in a population increase.- Habitat: Uses shallow wetlands in forests and grasslands for breeding, prefers open grasslands, and overwinters in bogs, lakes, agricultural fields, and open areas.- Diet: Primarily plant foods such as cereals, grasses, and roots, but also animal prey such as insects, frogs, small birds, rodents, earthworms, and gastropods - Lays about two clutches of eggs in April and May, incubated by alternating sexes. It builds an 80-centimeter-wide nest using plants in shallow wetlands. The eggs are oval in shape, brown with dark brown or reddish brown patterns and spots. They lay two clutches of eggs, with an incubation period of 28 to 31 days and a rearing period of 65 to 70 days for the hatched young.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are the loss of habitat, such as agricultural land, wetlands, and mudflats due to urbanization, and the lack of food. Additional threats include egg collection in breeding areas, lead poisoning in wintering areas, and hunting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A very rare wintering bird, found in small numbers along the Imjin River in Paju-si, Gyeonggi-do, the Cheorwon Plain in Gangwon-do, Cheonsu Bay in Seosan-si, Chungcheongnam-do, and Suncheon Bay in Jeollanam-do, South Korea; - International: Breeds in central Siberia, the far east of Russia, and the northeast of China, and migrates to China, Japan, Taiwan, the Iberian Peninsula, North Africa, Central Asia, and South Asia for wintering.

name: Tundra swan
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 120 to 150 centimeters long and weighs about 3.4 to 7.8 kilograms. Both sexes are white all over, with a black bill and yellow at the base of the upper bill. The yellow part is smaller than the black part and has a rounded tip. Young birds are grayish-brown all over, with a pale pink bill and a black tip. The legs are short and black. The bill is smaller than that of the tern and has a narrower yellow tip.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Inhabits river mouths, beaches, lakes, freshwater marshes, and agricultural fields.-Feeding: In shallow lakes and marshes, with its head underwater and tail in the air, it feeds on the leaves, stems, and roots of water grasses, as well as fish, crustaceans, and aquatic insects.-In marshes, it builds volcano-shaped nests using sedges, willows, and other plants, and lays three to five eggs in April and May.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Reclamation of tidal flats and marshes has fragmented habitat, reducing foraging areas and food sources, and the domestic wintering population has declined significantly over the past two decades.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Breeds in estuaries, lakes, lagoons, and reclaimed land in coastal areas; also in inland lakes and reservoirs such as Chungju Lake and Paldang Lake; - International: Breeds in northern Eurasia, Alaska, and northern Canada; winters in the western United States, western Europe, around the Caspian Sea, eastern China, and Japan.

name: Relict gull
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Larus relictus is about 44 to 45 centimeters long and weighs between 420 and 665 grams. It is characterized by an angularly shaped head and, compared to other gulls, its beak appears short in relation to its head size. The head is brownish-black with a half-moon-shaped white pattern, and in summer plumage, the head is black with white eye rims. The back and wings are pale gray, with black wing tips with distinct white spots, the tail is white, and the bill and legs are dark red. Yearlings have grayish-brown legs and bill, and a dark brown stripe on the back of the neck. The winter plumage is white on the head with black spots on the ears.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It makes a "kick-kick" sound similar to that of terns. In the breeding season, the head is black with a white rim around the eyes; in the non-breeding season, the head is white with black spots on the ears. Habitat: Prefers estuaries, coasts, and mudflats; breeds on islands in coastal or salt marshes.- Prey: Insects, beetles, small fish and invertebrates, and occasionally small birds and mammals.- Breeds in groups, building nests of gravel, small branches, and feathers on the ground.- Breeding season is April through May, laying two to three clutches of eggs at a time. The incubation period is 24 to 26 days, and the mortality rate of the young is very high.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to environmental changes in the breeding grounds, reclamation of tidal flats, and estuary development. In Korea, habitat loss due to development of the Nakdong River estuary, the main wintering ground, is a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number breed irregularly along the coasts of Korea, except Jeju Island, including the Nakdong River, the Geumgang Estuary, and Namyang Bay; - International: The species is native to East Asia, with the main breeding areas being Kazakhstan and Russia, and smaller numbers in parts of Mongolia and Inner Mongolia. In winter, large numbers winter in Bohai Bay in eastern China.

name: Japanese paradise flycatcher
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This small mountain bird is 18.5 to 20.0 centimeters long in males and 17 to 18 centimeters in females, and weighs about 18.7 grams. The beak and eye rims are blue, the head, waist, and chest are black, the back is tan, and the belly is white. It has tubular feathers on the top of its head, and during the breeding season, its central bill grows longer than its body length, and females prefer males with long bills. Females, on the other hand, have a reddish-chestnut-colored back, wings, and bill. The female's winter plumage is black with a blue sheen on the head and a shorter crown than the male.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Three subspecies have been reported, with Terpsiphone atrocaudata atrocaudata atrocaudata breeding in Korea and Japan.- Habitat: Inhabits artificial forests, scrub forests, and deciduous broadleaf forests. It prefers lowland forests with water or broadleaf forests with valleys.- Food: It feeds on insects of the order Lepidoptera, cicadas, grasshoppers, and dragonflies.- It builds cup-shaped nests on branches using moss, bark, roots, and spider webs, and decorates the nest with branches, leaves, and feathers. The breeding season is from May to August, with an egg-laying period of about 14 days and an incubation period of about 8 to 12 days to raise the hatched chicks. The eggs are white or rose-colored with reddish-brown and pale purple spots.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: It is estimated that the global population is declining due to habitat loss and degradation in its wintering grounds. In Korea, habitat loss due to golf courses, road development, etc. is a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout Korea as a summer bird, especially in Jeju Island and the southern part of the country; - Overseas: Outside of Korea, it breeds in Japan, Taiwan, and the northern Philippines; in winter, it migrates to eastern China and Taiwan, and overwinters in southern China, the Malay Peninsula, and Sumatra.

name: Ural owl
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 50 to 62 centimeters, wingspan is 115 to 135 centimeters, and weight is 500 to 950 grams in males and 570 to 1,300 grams in females. They are similar to owls but larger, and unlike owls, which have a mix of vertical and horizontal stripes on their chests, these birds have only vertical stripes, making their chests appear lighter. The forehead, top of the head, back of the head, and nape are a pale tan color, with black-brown vertical blotches on each feather and white blotches on the tips of a few feathers. The feathers that surround the face like a plate, the underparts and chin, are cream-colored, each with a black flagellum. The underparts are pale tan, bordered by a line of black and white speckled feathers. The back, collar, and waist are pale tan, with a broad black-brown blotch on each feather. The edges of each feather on the back, waist, and collar are white, and the tail is long and horizontally banded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The call of a male Long-eared Owl can be heard by humans up to 2 kilometers away - Habitat: Lives in coniferous forests at high altitudes, but also in shrubland and broadleaf forests. It especially prefers old forests with dead trees and open spaces.- Prey: Rodents are the most important prey; other insectivores, small birds, and insects are eaten.- Breeding season is from February to July, with two to four clutches of eggs laid in February and March. The incubation period is 28 to 35 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is about 35 days. Once they leave the nest, they're still fed by their parents until 60 days after hatching. They breed in the old nests of horseshoe crickets or sparrowhawks, sometimes in the ground under trees, in farm sheds, or in holes in cliffs. They also use artificial birdhouses.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss and fragmentation due to clear-cutting for forest development, removal of dead trees, and the establishment of forest roads are the main threats. Other threats include poaching, bio-enrichment with toxic substances, and collisions with structures.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It is a native bird with a small population in Korea, inhabiting the mountainous regions of Gyeonggi-do, Chungcheong-do, and Gyeongsangbuk-do, centered on Gangwon-do. - International: It is widely distributed in the northern part of the Eurasian continent, from the Amur region, Sakhalin, northeastern Mongolia, Manchuria, and Ussuri region to northern and eastern Europe.

name: Black woodpecker
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large woodpecker with a body length of 45 to 57 centimeters, a weight of 250 to 370 grams, and a wingspan of 64 to 84 centimeters, making it the second-largest woodpecker in the world after the common nuthatch. Both males and females are covered in black feathers. Males are colored from the forehead to the top of the head and back, while females have a reddish back. The bill is grayish-white with a black back and tip, and gray legs.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Because of its large size, the sound it makes when it knocks on trees is loud and resonant. The nests they build are used as nesting sites by a wide variety of birds and mammals, including blue jays, nuthatches, bluebirds, blue jays, and nuthatches.- Habitat: They live in old forests with old oaks, pines, and other dead or dying trees. It does not prefer areas with too much dense vegetation.- Food: It feeds on insect larvae by knocking on tree trunks to dig holes. They also eat ants, flies, beetles, and plant fruits.- Breeding season is from March to July, and they build nests in tree cavities for 10 to 15 days. They lay 3 to 6 eggs at a time from mid-March to mid-May, with an incubation period of 14 to 16 days and a rearing period of 24 to 31 days for the hatched young.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Old-growth forests with old-growth trees that can support large woodpeckers are being destroyed by logging, reducing their habitat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A rare bird distributed in forests throughout the country. It is most commonly found in Gangwon-do, Gyeongsang-do, and Chungcheong-do provinces, where old forests are widespread. - International: It is distributed continuously across the Eurasian continent from Scandinavia, France, Spain, the Kamchatka Peninsula, and Japan.

name: Eurasian spoonbill
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 70 to 95 centimeters long and weighs 1.8 to 2.4 kilograms, with males slightly larger than females. It has a white body, black legs and bill, and a long neck, legs and bill. The bill is flat and spatulate with a yellow tip, and unlike the spoonbill, the black color of the bill does not extend to the face. The chin is featherless, exposing yellow skin. During the breeding season, males develop a long, dangling, yellow decorative collar on the back of the head, and a yellow band under the chin and on the breast. Females are slightly smaller than males and lack a mane on the back of the neck. Juveniles have a lighter bill color and black wing tips.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is also known as the 'gari bird' (a bent iron used in pottery making to scrape and shape the body of a vessel). There are records of breeding between the spoonbill and the yellow-billed spoonbill at the Incheon breeding grounds in Korea - Habitat: Uses large open marshes, large rivers, and estuaries with shallow water. It breeds on islands in lakes and rivers, mostly in freshwater marshes, and some breed on islands offshore.- Food: Fish, frogs, tadpoles, shellfish, mollusks, and insects; also eats marsh plants and their fruits.- Nests in dense aquatic vegetation, shrubs, or mangroves, on branches and reeds. In May, she lays 3 to 5 chestnut-colored spotted eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 21 to 25 days and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 45 to 50 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are the loss of habitat due to the loss of wetlands and mudflats, and the reduction of food resources due to pesticides. Other threats include egg collection, wire collisions, and avian influenza infection.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Winters in river estuaries, marshes, and Jeju Island along the southwestern coast; - International: Distributed throughout Asia, Europe, and northern Africa, except southern China and India.

name: Great bustard
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is 90 to 105 centimeters long in males and 75 to 85 centimeters in females, and weighs between 3 and 18 kilograms. Males and females are almost the same color, with a reddish-brown back with black horizontal stripes. The bill is pale gray, and the head and neck are light gray with a bluish tinge. When flying, the upper wings show a distinct difference between black and white wing feathers. During the breeding season, males have long white feathers on their chin that look like a beard, and a reddish-brown band on their chest. When breeding is over, the long feathers on the chin disappear and the entire neck and chest become pale gray. Females are similar to non-breeding males and are smaller in size.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: More than half of the world's population lives in Spain - Habitat: Inhabits open plains, dry hilly grasslands and meadows, but has recently been found in agricultural fields and pastures.- Diet: Omnivorous, feeding mainly on plant food such as seeds and insects.- Breeds on the ground, usually laying two to three clutches of eggs from April to June. The incubation period is 25 days, the rearing period, or incubation period, is 30 to 35 days, and the young reach adult size 80 to 120 days after hatching. Males show off their courtship behavior by erecting their neck and fan-shaped bill and flipping their wings.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Intensive agriculture is the main cause of population decline, with additional threats including habitat degradation, illegal hunting, pesticide use, and wire collisions.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Once a common wintering bird, with some records of more than 100 individuals, but the population has gradually declined and has been rarely seen since the 1970s. Recently, it was observed in January 2017 in Yeoju City and January 2020 in Manyeong River. - Overseas: It is distributed in various European countries such as Spain, Turkey, Portugal, Russia, and Hungary, and Asian countries such as Mongolia and China, including Korea. Habitats are discontinuously distributed, not connected to each other.

name: Cinereous vulture
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is the largest of the birds of prey, with a body length of 100 to 110 centimeters and a wingspan of 250 to 300 centimeters. It is entirely black, with wide and long wings. The back of the head and neck are grayish-brown with exposed skin, the sharp bill is black, and the irises are white. The back and wing feathers are brown, and the wing tips are split and curved upward when flying. It is broad and long, but its bill is short.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: The eagle is a scavenger among the top predators of grassland ecosystems - Habitat: It winters in open areas such as rivers, estuaries, and agricultural fields in our country. During the breeding season, the habitat varies greatly depending on the region, including oak forests, high-altitude coniferous forests, grasslands, and deserts.- Food: It feeds on animal carcasses.
					
					- It lays one to two clutches of eggs between February and March, with an incubation period of 52 to 55 days. The eggs are white with dark brown or reddish-brown blotches.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Declining prey resources and secondary poisoning from poisoned carcasses, hunting, and nesting are the main threats, and unlike the growing European population, the Asian population is declining rapidly.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: In the past, many individuals were centered near the Demilitarized Zone, but in recent years, the distribution area has been expanding to the southern provinces with an increase in population size. Large groups are mainly observed in Cheorwon, Yeoncheon, Paju, Goseong, Gyeongnam, etc. - Overseas: It is found in southern Europe, Central Asia, Tibet, Mongolia, and northeastern China. It is distributed worldwide, and the population that arrives in Korea is confirmed to migrate to the Mongolian region.

name: Crested ibis
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird has a body length of about 55 to 84 centimeters, a wingspan of 130 to 140 centimeters, and a weight of 1.2 to 1.8 kilograms. It is a medium-sized bird of the spoonbill family with a long neck, beak, and legs. During the breeding season, the head, neck, back, and shoulders are gray, and the rest of the body is pale gray; in the non-breeding season, the entire body is pale pinkish white. There is a large expanse of reddish skin between the back of the bill and the area around the eyes. The bill is black with a long, tubular, 10-centimeter tufts of feathers on the back of the head. The legs are brownish-red in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: In 1981, seven remaining wild birds were found and restored in Yang County, Shaanxi Province, China, and the restored individuals in Korea and Japan are the descendants of these individuals. In 2019, wild-released individuals successfully bred for the first time.- Habitat: Forage in wetlands such as rice fields, rivers, reservoirs, and lakes, and breed and rest in forests near wetlands.- Prey: Small freshwater fish, frogs, tadpoles, crayfish, snails, and earthworms, especially minnows.- Builds saucer-shaped nests using branches of pine and chestnut trees and dry vines. The breeding season is from March to August, and they lay two to three eggs at a time. The incubation period takes 28 to 33 days, and the rearing period, which is the period of raising the hatched young, takes 45 to 50 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Because it is a slow-moving bird that operates within the range of humans, it is often victimized by hunting, and its population has plummeted due to the conversion of its main feeding grounds to irrigation canals and the loss of habitat due to the destruction of lowland forests where it breeds. Even now, the lack of food in wetlands due to pesticides is a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: According to records from 1892, it was a common migratory bird in Korea, but it has gradually declined and has not been observed since 1979. There are records of small populations distributed throughout the country, including the Demilitarized Zone, Busan, Daejeon, Seoul, and Palmydo, Incheon. About 100 individuals have been released in the wild in Upo Swamp, Changnyeong-gun, Gyeongsangnam-do, since 2019 through a restoration project.- Internationally: Internationally, there are only natural populations in central China's Shaanxi Province, and reintroduced individuals from Japan live on Sado Island.

name: Watercock
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 42 to 43 centimeters in males and 34.5 to 36 centimeters in females, and the weight is 300 to 650 grams in males and 200 to 434 grams in females. During the breeding season, the male's body turns bluish-black, the wing edges are pale brown, there is a reddish band from the forehead to the top of the head, and the bill is yellow. The winter plumage is similar to the female, but the male has a thicker bill and is yellow, while the female's is tan. The female's body is tan with dark brown spots and a sandy underside. Both sexes have long, light green legs and reddish-brown eyes. During the non-breeding season, males and females look almost identical.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: The male's call is characterized by the nursery rhyme, "tinkle tinkle tinkle" or "tinkle tinkle tinkle."- Habitat: It lives in rice fields and wetlands. In the morning and evening, it is active in the rice fields or rice banks, and during the day, it hides in the grasses along the water, hillsides, or bushes near the rice fields.- Food: It feeds on insects, fish, amphibians, and grass and plant seeds.- Breeding season is from June to August, and it usually lays three to six eggs at a time. Eggs vary in color, with reddish-brown or rat-colored spots interspersed.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to loss of habitat and decreasing food resources due to the loss of rice fields and wetlands due to various developments and urbanization.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Once widely distributed throughout the country, but due to various developments and urbanization, it is now only observed locally in the Cheorwon Plain area of Gangwon-do Province, Paju-si, Gyeonggi-do Province, and Seosan-si, Chungcheongnam-do Province.- International: Distributed in Japan, eastern and central China, Taiwan, the Malay Peninsula of Indochina, India, and Sri Lanka.

name: Yellow bunting
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is about 13 to 14 centimeters, and the average weight is 15.2 grams in males and 14.6 grams in females. The winter plumage of both males and females is green on the top of the head, sides of the head, and back of the neck, with the tips of each feather somewhat darker. The eyes are characterized by a distinct white ring around the eye, and the underparts and chin are yellowish in color. The beak is relatively thin and long, and reddish-brown in color. The upperparts of the body are grayish-green, with axial black spots, especially on the back feathers. The chest and belly are pale yellow to grayish-green, with pale black vertical blotches on the flanks. The lower tail feathers are yellowish-white, and the legs are apricot-colored.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: A very rare migratory bird that passes through Geoje Island and Jeju Island in small flocks during spring and fall. Its population plummeted in the 20th century, but recent evidence of breeding populations in Japan and increased numbers passing through Korea led to a change in the IUCN Red List from Vulnerable (VU) to Least Concern (LC) in 2022.- Habitat: Inhabits open areas, shrublands, and grasslands, preferring well-lit deciduous forests. It breeds in shrublands on the edges of broadleaf or mixed forests and on the gentle slopes of mountains.- Food: Insects, spiders, and seeds of the Lamiaceae family.- Nests in the branches of shrublands in a bowl-shaped cavity. The breeding season is from mid-May to early July, with three to five eggs laid at a time.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are habitat loss and degradation due to industrialization of agriculture, and captivity for sale as pets.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A rare migrant bird that passes through stream banks, forest margins, and grasslands along the southern coast during spring and fall, but there are no records of specific populations.

name: Osprey
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 50 to 66 centimeters and the wingspan is 127 to 174 centimeters. Its head is white with yellow irises, brown eye lines, and a short crown on the back of the head. The bill is black with a blue tint at the base. The back and upper wings are blackish-brown, while the top of the head and lower body are white. It has a black-brown band on its chest. It has a brown horizontal stripe on its tail. The wings are slender and long, and the male and female are similar in color when flying. Its legs are a pale greenish-blue color, and its claws are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: unlike most birds of prey, which have feet with three toes pointing forward and one backward, this bird has a single toe that can be extended backward, making it well suited for grasping fish.- Habitat: nests on rocks or in the branches of large trees on shorelines, on the rocks of islands, and in lakes and streams. During the non-breeding season, they can be found in rivers, reservoirs, lakes, and coastal wetlands.- Food: They feed primarily on fish.- Nests are saucer-shaped, made of stacked twigs, seaweed, dry grasses, and mosses. The breeding season varies widely depending on the region, but in Korea, it is known to be from February to June. They lay two to four eggs at a time, with an incubation period of 34 to 42 days and a rearing period of 56 to 70 days for the hatched chicks. The male catches the prey and gives it to the female, who tears it into small pieces and feeds it to the young.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations plummeted from the 1950s to the 1970s due to DDT. Since the ban of DDT, the global population is thought to be increasing, but threats include hunting, wind turbine collisions, and reduced food sources due to overfishing.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A rare wintering and migratory bird that passes through our country, it is distributed throughout the country but is mainly found along the coast, and inland it is found near rivers and dams.- International: Widely distributed throughout the world.

name: Oriental honey buzzard
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 52 to 68 centimeters long, weighs 0.8 to 1.3 kilograms in males and 1.0 to 1.5 kilograms in females, and has a wingspan of 115 to 155 centimeters. It has a long neck and a small head, which makes it appear longer than other birds of prey when in flight. The upper surface of the body is brown or blackish-brown, but the lower surface has a wide range of color variations between individuals. Depending on the type of feather color, there are light-colored individuals (pale), dark-colored individuals (dark), and brown individuals (medium). The wings are longer and wider than the body, and the tail is slightly longer and rounded. Males have wider wing stripes and black bands on the bill than females, and the irises of the eyes are darker in males and yellowish in females. Juveniles have a yellow bill, black wing tips, and a narrow, striped bill.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Often uses the old nests of horseshoe crickets or sparrowhawks to build nests on top of them. During the breeding season, they line their nests with the green leaves of broadleaf trees. Habitat: They use a variety of habitats, including moist forested areas and dry grasslands in the tropics and subtropics, but prefer broadleaf forests. They are usually solitary, but may form large swarms during migration.- Food: They feed on larvae, pupae, and adult bees by digging into tree cavities, hives hanging from trees, and bumblebee houses; they also eat some honeycomb and nectar. They also eat frogs, snakes, moles, mice, rats, and other insects. - They build their nests in branches in high trees in broadleaf forests. The breeding season is from May to June, and she lays one to three eggs at a time, usually two. The incubation period lasts between 28 and 35 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 35 to 45 days. Males and females lay together, with the male carrying the food.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: They are highly vulnerable to collisions with wind farms during migration, and deforestation is also a major threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Observed along the west coast and south coast during migration. Recently, it has been found that large numbers regularly pass through the Korean peninsula, especially in spring and fall. A small number of breeding records have been found in limited areas of Gangwon Province. - Overseas: Distributed in the Amur region, Sakhalin, Mongolia, northeastern China, Japan, Southeast Asia, and South Asia.

name: Chinese sparrowhawk
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 25 to 35 centimeters, the weight is 106 to 140 grams in males and 125 to 204 grams in females, and the wingspan is 52 to 62 centimeters. Males are bluish-gray on top, with a pale tan breast and creamy underbelly. Females are similarly colored to males, but have a darker back and chest than males. Both sexes have black beaks, with yellow lead membranes on the upper bill, and yellowish-orange toes. Males have red irises, while females have yellow. The kestrel, a related species, has yellow eye rims and is distinguished by a thin stripe on the lower wing feathers when flying. Males of the related species, the ashy frogfalcon, have a white back.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Despite the "hawk" in its name, this small to medium-sized bird of prey is not a member of the hawk family, but rather of the osprey family.- Habitat: It breeds in deciduous and coniferous forests around wetlands, including rice paddies, where it can forage.- Food: Frogs, small birds, and insects are eaten, and the young's diet is primarily animal matter, mainly frogs and cicadas. Frogs make up 70% of the young's diet, but they also occasionally catch small birds such as chickadees and red-headed woodpeckers.- Nests in branches in trees. The breeding season is from May to August, with eggs laid around May, usually three to four eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 24 to 31 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, is 18 to 25 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Loss of frogs and key food resources in rice paddy wetlands due to deforestation and agricultural land loss and pesticides are the main causes of population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A summer migratory bird that used to be common throughout Korea, but breeding populations have declined significantly in recent years; - International: Breeds in Far Eastern Russia, eastern and central China, and overwinters in southeastern China, Taiwan, Sumatra, Indonesia, and the Philippines.

name: Great knot
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 26 to 28 centimeters long and weighs 115 to 248 grams. Its bill is longer than the length of its head, and when it flies, it has a distinct white back. When sitting, the wing tips protrude clearly behind the tail tip. The irises are dark brown. The throat, under chin, and muzzle are white with small black patterns. The top of the male's summer collar is blackish-brown, with reddish-brown blotches on the back and shoulder collar. The chest is black with a cluster of black dots. The female's summer collar is similar to the male's, with less reddish-brown on top. Winter plumage, on the other hand, is mouse-colored on top and white on the underside, with thin black stripes on the neck, chest, and flanks. Juveniles have a blackish-brown upperparts, with yellowish-white or pale reddish-brown edges to the back and shoulder feathers. The underside is similar to the winter plumage of adult birds, but the upper breast is characterized by a denser, more spotted pattern.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Found in flocks on mudflats, estuaries, and salt flats throughout the country during the migration season.- Food: During the non-breeding season, the bird feeds on midges, shellfish, and crustaceans.- During the breeding season, the bird feeds mainly on plant food such as berries, conifer seeds, and insects.- Breeds in May and June, laying about four eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 21 days and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, is 20 to 25 days. Breeds on ground cover or herbaceous ground on plateaus and gentle slopes in the tundra and mountainous regions.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are plummeting due to habitat loss caused by the reclamation of tidal flats on the west coast, including Saemangeum, a major stopover site. Additional threats include habitat degradation due to fish and shellfish overfishing, aquaculture, invasive species, and development in its wintering areas of the Philippines, India, and Australia.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Large flocks occur along the coasts of Namyang Bay, Cheonsu Bay, Yubu Island, and Janghang during the spring-fall migration. Because it passes through Korea in the spring, it is more frequently observed in the spring than in the fall. - Overseas: Breeds in northeastern Siberia and overwinters in India, Southeast Asia, and Australia.

name: Japanese night heron
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is about 49 centimeters long. Males and females are the same color, with yellow in the front of the eyes and irises, and a dark brown band down the center of the front of the neck. The beak is short and thick. Its entire body is reddish brown, with a darker brown color between the head and shoulders and a creamy brown underside. When it flies, it has a thick black band that runs down the center of its wings. The legs are yellowish green. Juveniles are generally darker in color than adults, with scattered black and white patterns on the head and wings.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Flutters loudly when taking off, but usually flies quietly and gently; neck is arched in an S-shape. Nocturnal and difficult to observe. It lives singly or in very small flocks.- Habitat: It lives in low forests in breeding areas with swamps or waterholes.- Food: It feeds mainly on crustaceans, including crabs, but also on ground worms, insects, snails, and fish. It forages at night, often in dark ravines in coniferous trees and near water, such as ponds and ponds.- Nests in dense forests, 7 to 20 meters high. The breeding season is from May through August, and they begin breeding in late May or June, laying three to four eggs at a time. The incubation period is 17 to 27 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 35 to 37 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to deforestation and habitat loss, with an estimated 7,500 to 15,000 individuals remaining globally as of 2020.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Occasional spring and summer arrivals on some south coastal islands, including Jeju Island, Busan, Haetae Island, and Geumo Island. It has been recorded breeding on Jeju Island - Overseas: It breeds mainly in Japan, with breeding records in Taiwan. It overwinters in the Ryukyu Islands and the Philippine Islands.

name: Japanese murrelet
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 24 to 26 centimeters long and weighs between 189 and 213 grams, making it one of the smaller marine birds that live in the ocean. It has a short head with a black horn collar and a long, bluish-gray beak. The head is black with a bold white stripe running from the top of the head to the back of the neck. The back, shoulder collar, loin, and upper tail feathers are dark gray. The lower neck, chest, belly, and underparts of the tail are white, and the sides are black with spots of gray. The feet are gray and have developed webbed feet for life in the sea. It's hard to tell the sexes apart by appearance. The winter coat has shorter horns than the summer coat.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Monogamous, returning to their breeding grounds. It is a seabird that spends its entire life at sea, except during the breeding season.- Habitat: It lives in the open ocean (sea far from land) and coastal waters, and breeds on rocky islands off the coast. They feed in areas where upwelling (the rising of mid-level cold waters to the surface at depths of 200 to 300 meters) occurs and food is abundant, such as the edges of continental shelves. They swim in groups of 5 to 10 individuals and forage in the open ocean. - Prey: Small fish and crustaceans such as krill. - Breed by building nests in rock crevices and burrows or by digging shallow burrows under plant roots. Breeding season is mid-March to early July, with most migrating in late April and May. Eggs are laid two at a time, seven to eight days apart. The incubation period is about 31 days. The young birds leave the nest at night with their parents one to two days after hatching and migrate to the open ocean, where they raise their young at sea.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Overharvesting of eggs and adults in the 20th century led to a significant population decline. Currently, predation by rats and cats introduced to island areas and bycatch in nets set to catch fish are the main threats. Other threats include damage from marine debris.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Breeding has been confirmed on some islands, including Jeju Island, Baekdo Island off the Dado Sea, Gugul Island in Shinan County, Dokdo, and Marado, and observations have been made off the coast of the Nankai and Oryukdo Islands.- Overseas: Mainly breeds in eastern and southern Japan, and during the non-breeding season is distributed in the waters of Northeast Asia, including Sakhalin, Taiwan, and China.

name: Crested lark
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It is 17 to 19 centimeters long, weighs 35 to 50 grams, and is light brown overall, with a pale tan belly. The feathers on top of the head form a cap. The body is similar in both sexes, with a brown back and dark spots. The muzzle and chest have a dark brown vertical pattern. The middle tail feathers are a dark sandy color, the other tail feathers are black-brown, and the outer tail feathers are tan. They have broad, rounded wings, and when they fly, they differ from skylarks in that they don't have a white band on the back of their wings, and they don't have white on their tail feathers.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Inhabits dry open areas with low vegetation density, cultivated fields, and around villages - Food: Insects in spring and summer, but plant seeds and rice grains in fall and winter - Breeding season is from April to June, laying three to six eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 12 to 13 days, and both sexes take turns incubating the eggs. The incubation period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 9 to 11 days. The eggs are white, glossy, and dotted with thin patterns of purplish gray, tan, and yellowish brown.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to habitat loss and degradation caused by reclamation, development of agricultural land, and excessive use of pesticides.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Once a common bird throughout Korea, it has become very rare since the early 1980s. The last breeding record was in 2008 in Seosan reclaimed land in Chungcheongnam-do, South Chungcheong Province, and since 2010 there have been observations in Gyodong-do, Incheon, and Bucheon, Gyeonggi-do, Korea.- Overseas: Widely distributed in Eurasia and northern Africa.

name: Eurasian sparrowhawk
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Accipiter nisus is a small to medium-sized bird of prey with a body length of 28 to 40 centimeters, a weight of 105 to 196 grams in males and 185 to 350 grams in females, and a wingspan of 56 to 65 centimeters in males and 65 to 78 centimeters in females. Males have an overall dark gray head and upper body with a white, faint brow line above the eyes, although some individuals do not have a brow line. The underside of the body is white with thin horizontal reddish-brown stripes. Females are brownish overall with black around the eyes and a darker, more pronounced eyebrow line than males. The mantle has a dark brown vertical stripe on a white background. The rest of the underside is white with tan and dark brown horizontal bands. In juveniles, the upperparts of the body are darker brown than in adults, with darker stripes on the muzzle, breast, and belly.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This bird of prey has long been used for falconry around the world. Despite its name, this bird of prey is a member of the family Accipitridae. Habitat: Solitary during the non-breeding season, it is usually found in open areas, agricultural fields, rivers, and islands. During the breeding season, it inhabits slightly elevated mountainous or flat forests.- Prey: It feeds mainly on small to medium-sized birds.- Nests are built in a saucer-shaped pile of slender branches in trees at least 4 to 8 meters high. The breeding season is May through July, with clutches of 3 to 6 eggs. The incubation period lasts 32 to 35 days and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, lasts 24 to 30 days. After the young leave the nest, the parents will continue to feed them for three to four weeks. The eggs are pale blue in color with large reddish-brown blotches and pale purple patterns interspersed throughout.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations plummeted in the early 20th century due to reduced reproductive success and survival rates caused by pesticides such as DDT. The global population is now thought to be stable, but there are still threats, including habitat loss due to development, trapping for falconry, lead poisoning, and collisions with wind turbines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout the country, mostly in winter, and can be observed in the West Sea Islands and Busan, Korea, where it is a stopover during migration. It has been observed occasionally during the breeding season since 2000, and a breeding nest was confirmed for the first time in 2015. - International: Widely distributed in Eurasia, with a wintering population in northwestern Africa.

name: Eurasian hobby
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 28 to 36 centimeters long, weighs 131 to 232 grams in males and 141 to 340 grams in females, and has a wingspan of 68 to 84 centimeters. It has a dark blue-gray upperparts, white neck and throat, white or pale yellow belly and chest with black vertical stripes, and reddish-brown underparts and lower tail feathers. It has a white eyebrow line, dark brown iris, and yellowish eye rims. The beak is dark gray with a darker tip. The wings are narrow and long, like those of a swallow. Both sexes are the same color, but the male's chest is slightly lighter. In young birds, the stripes on the lower part of the body are thicker and the entire underparts are yellowish brown.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The name birdcatcher comes from the fact that it captures and eats small birds. It hunts its prey mainly from the air and is very agile, so it can also hunt fast-flying birds such as swallows and swifts.- Habitat: It lives in open areas with trees, pastures, croplands, and forest edges, and also breeds in urban forests and buildings. During the breeding season, they prefer wetland areas for feeding. They live in forested areas, urban forests, open areas, and agricultural fields.-Feed: They hunt and eat insects and small birds, and vomit out undigested material in pellets.-They do not build their own nests, but use the nests of other birds such as magpies, crows, and other birds of prey. The breeding season is from May to August, with two to three clutches of eggs laid at a time from late May to late June. The incubation period is 28 to 32 days, and the rearing period, the time spent raising the hatched young, is 28 to 31 days. The eggs are pale yellowish-brown in color with small red blotches.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The global population is estimated to be declining, with the main threats being the loss of breeding season habitat due to land use change and the reduction of food sources such as insects and birds due to the industrialization of agriculture. Other threats include collisions with wind turbines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: summer bird, uncommon but distributed throughout the country - International: breeds in temperate regions of the Eurasian continent, wintering in Southeast Asia or sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Pleske's grasshopper warbler
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 16 to 17 centimeters long and weighs 16 to 24 grams. Its back, chest, sides, and flanks are grayish-brown or olive-brown, its throat is white, and its belly is gray with a yellowish tinge. It has a long bill, indistinct pale brown eyebrow line, and pale eye rims. The four outer pairs of tail feathers are tipped with white, and the legs are apricot-colored.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is difficult to distinguish this species because it is very similar in appearance to the black-tailed mouse, and little ecological information is known about it, so much research is needed. During the breeding season, it makes a loud "beep, beep, beep, beep, beep" call or a rapid "chororo-chororo" call.- Habitat: Found in bamboo forests, shrub forests, and tall evergreen forests. It descends to feed in fields and around human settlements. During the winter, it can be found in coastal mangroves, reed beds, and shrublands.- Food: Insects are the mainstay of its diet, but it also feeds on mollusks such as gastropods.- Nests in shrubs, using leaves of sedge family plants or mallow leaves to build a bowl-shaped nest. It lays 3 to 5 eggs at a time from mid-May to mid-June and sometimes until early August. The incubation period is 14 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 12 to 20 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss on breeding islands and loss of wetlands in wintering areas are thought to be the main causes of the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Summer bird, breeding on uninhabited islands with shrubland and grassland, especially along the west and south coasts; - International: Very limited distribution, breeding on islands in Far Eastern Russia, Honshu and Kyushu in Japan, and islands south of Kyushu; overwinters in southeastern China and parts of northern Vietnam.

name: Black kite
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Body length 44 to 66 centimeters, weight 630 to 928 grams in males and 750 to 1,080 grams in females, wingspan 120 to 153 centimeters. They are dark brown overall. The bill and throat are lighter in color, and the ear feathers are very dark brown, silvery white, with a light brown vertical stripe. There is a distinct black line behind the eye and the iris is brown. When in flight, a white spot is visible at the base of the first wing feather on the underside of the wing. It has a long tail, which is straight at the tip but concave when folded, characterized by a swallow's bill. The legs are pale yellow or ashy yellow. Juveniles are pale reddish-brown overall, with broad white spots scattered across the back and wing feathers.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It used to be a relatively common bird in Korea, but is now a rare wintering bird.- Habitat: It lives in wetlands and surrounding pastures and forests, including coastal, island, and lake shores, but in some areas, such as Pakistan, it has adapted to live in large cities. It roosts on cliffs and in the shrubs of the forests surrounding wetlands.- Food: It feeds on a wide variety of animal carcasses, but also hunts and catches mice, small birds, amphibians, reptiles, and insects.- It builds saucer-shaped nests using the branches of shrubs and collects animal hair, threads, and rags during the breeding season. The breeding season is from March to August, when they lay two to three eggs at a time from mid-March to mid-May. The incubation period lasts between 26 and 38 days, and the rearing period, which is when the young hatch, lasts between 58 and 63 days. The young birds are still fed by their parents after they leave the nest and become independent after about 47 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Past declines in domestic populations are believed to be due to secondary poisoning from eating poisoned carcasses. Because of its sensitivity to habitat fragmentation, land use change is thought to affect breeding and wintering populations. They are also vulnerable to wind turbine and power line collisions.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: It is concentrated in winter on the west and south coastal islands. Smaller populations are also found in Dokdo, Cheonsu Bay, and the Cheorwon Plain. Once a nationwide breeding population, it declined sharply during the 20th century, and now breeds only on the southern coastal islands, where it is very rare.- International: Distributed in Europe Asia, Africa, and Australia, excluding North and South America.

name: Ochre-rumped bunting
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species is 14 to 15 centimeters long and weighs 13 to 14 grams. The male's summer plumage is black on the head and a mix of reddish-brown and grayish-brown on the back, with black vertical stripes. The loin and lower tail feathers are tan, and the outer pair of tail feathers are white. The underside of the body is yellowish white, with a darker chest. In wintering birds, the browline, jawline, and muzzle of the head are tan. Females are similar to males, but have a darker brown head and lighter brow, chin, and crown. The male's bill is black in summer and pale brown in winter, while the female has a dark upper bill and pale brown lower bill in both summer and winter. The legs are pale yellowish-brown.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
