extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Inhabits grasslands, marsh edges, and reedbeds with tall trees, and overwinters in dense weedy fields, grassy forests on the edges of agricultural fields, riverine reedbeds, and estuaries.- Food: Animal prey, mainly beetles and arachnids, but also plants, such as seeds.- Breeding season is June through August, with clutches of 3 to 5 eggs laid in early June to mid-July.- Usually breeds twice a year. The incubation period is 12 to 14 days, and it takes 10 to 13 days for the young to hatch and leave the nest.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Its habitat is gradually diminishing due to the development of its wintering grounds, including in Korea, as well as the modification of rivers and the development of coastal wetlands. Drought in Mongolia, where it breeds, and dam construction and fires in Russia are also reducing habitat, and the global population is thought to be declining.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Wintering in small numbers in reed beds around open fields and reclaimed areas throughout the country. Breeding was first confirmed in 2015 around Lake Shihua. - International: Breeds in eastern Mongolia, Ussuri region, and northern China, and winters in Japan and China.

name: Eurasian eagle-owl
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The bubo is a large nocturnal bird of prey with a body length of 58 to 71 centimeters, weight of 1.6 to 2.8 kilograms in males and 2.3 to 4.2 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 160 to 188 centimeters, making it the largest member of the owl family in Korea. The head has a right horn and the eyes are orange in color. The ears are located on either side of the back of the eyes and are hidden by the fur, making them hard to see. From the top of its head to the back of its neck and on its back and wing feathers, it has a tan color with black and dark brown vertical stripes. The tail is short and brown with black horizontal bands. The legs and toes are covered with light brown feathers. It's hard to tell the sexes apart in appearance.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It can change the shape of its outer ears slightly to hear sounds and track its prey in three dimensions. It can also see things in the dark as brightly as in daylight - Habitat: Prefers rocky mountains and rocky areas with open areas and water, rather than forested areas alone. In Korea, studies have shown that they feed on monkeys and pheasants in forested areas, and pheasants and rodents in open areas.- They do not build nests, but use ledges or flat spots on rocks to lay eggs. They begin courting in November, and the breeding season is from January to April, laying one to four eggs at a time from January to March. The incubation period is 34 to 36 days, and the female is in charge of incubation, while the male provides food. The incubation period is 22 to 25 days, but the hatchlings remain under the care of their mother for five to six months.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In Korea, it is believed that the population has declined in large numbers due to overfishing and secondary poisoning from eating rats poisoned with rodenticides. Currently, the population is believed to be declining in Asia, and the main threats are changes in the habitat environment due to forest loss and fragmentation, development, and road construction. Other threats include roadkill, accidents, and wire collisions.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rare, nationally distributed; - International: Widespread in Europe, Asia north of the Himalayas, and parts of northern Africa.

name: Pied harrier
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a medium-sized bird of prey with a body length of 43 to 50 centimeters, a weight of 254 to 325 grams in males and 390 to 455 grams in females, and a wingspan of 110 to 125 centimeters. Males are black on the face, chest, back, and wingtips, with white on the belly, undersides of the wings, and small wing feathers. Some of the wings and the rump are grayish-white. The back, shoulders, and some of the wing feathers are black, forming a bow shape. The upperparts of the female are brown, but the head and nape feathers have a tan edge on either side of the head and nape, with a vertical speckled pattern. The wing coverts are blue-gray with a blackish-brown stripe and a stripe on the underside of the wing. The tail feathers are ashy-brown with four to five irregular horizontal bands, and the underside is cream-colored with a brownish-brown stripe. The bill is slate-colored, the iris is yellow, the legs are yellow, and the claws are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A rare resident bird of central and eastern North America, and a very rare migrant bird.- Habitat: Found in grassy wetlands, open fields, lower reaches of rivers, reedbeds, and small settlements.- Prey: Primarily rodents, but also small birds, amphibians, reptiles, and insects.- Breeding season is April through May, with four to five eggs laid at a time. The egg-laying period is about 29 to 32 days, and the incubation period, the period of rearing the hatched young, is 32 to 45 days. The eggs are bluish-white in color with light brown spots.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species breeds in wetlands, small settlements, and other habitats, and uses riverine areas, reclaimed land, agricultural fields, grasslands, and small settlements as its primary behavioral areas, so degradation of its habitat by development activities seems to be its greatest threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rarely observed as a migratory bird; males have been recorded during the breeding season in Cheorwon-gun and Paju-si; - International: Breeds in northeastern China, Ussuri, northern Myanmar, and northeastern India; overwinters in southern China, Southeast Asia, and India.

name: Far Eastern curlew
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 53 to 66 centimeters, the weight is 0.4 to 1.4 kilograms, and the wingspan is 97 to 110 centimeters. The bill is long and curved downward, shorter in males than in females. The entire body is brown with tan edges to the feathers. The lower part of the body has a thin vertical stripe of dark brown. The eyebrow line and under the chin are white, and the shoulder collar is black-brown with a serrated edge. The undersides of the wings are densely striped with brown. Although similar in appearance to the madoyo, the madoyo has a white back, lower tail feathers, and undersides of the wings.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: The female has the longest bill of any shorebird, about 185 mm long - Habitat: Nests in grassy areas with small shrubs in alpine meadows, plateaus, and tundra. During the non-breeding season, they inhabit coastal areas, using estuaries, mangrove swamps, and mudflats.- Food: During the breeding season, they eat beetles, caterpillars, and insects; during the non-breeding season, they eat marine invertebrates such as crabs and crustaceans.- Breeding season is May through June, and they lay two to four eggs at a time. The incubation period lasts between 28 and 30 days, and the birds migrate to their wintering grounds. The eggs are greenish-brown in color with spots.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In its main wintering grounds, Australia, 82% of the population has disappeared in the 30 years since the 1990s, most likely due to the reclamation of west coast tidal flats, an important stopover site. The population is expected to continue to decline due to the reclamation and development of west coast tidal flats, and additional threats include disturbance of breeding sites and habitat, and declining prey resources at domestic stopover sites due to pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A migratory bird, mostly observed along the southwest coast in spring and fall when migratory birds are moving between breeding and wintering grounds; - International: Breeds in northeastern Siberia and northeastern China, mostly migrating to Australia, but also wintering in Japan, eastern China, Taiwan, Indonesia, and New Guinea.

name: Hill pigeon
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 31 to 35 cm long and appears grayish overall, with a dark gray head, face, cheeks, and under chin, red irises, and a dark bill with a light leaden membrane. The neck has a metallic sheen, the back is white, and the wings have two black bands. The tail has a wide white band with a black tip. The legs are reddish-coral in color. Young birds have no metallic sheen on their throats and the edges of their feathers are grayish white. House pigeons have less pronounced white on the back and rump, and more variation in plumage color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: much faster in motion and flight than house pigeons - Habitat: mainly in agricultural areas of islands and coastal areas, relying on cliffs, inland temples, and reservoir bridges - Food: mainly plant seeds, but also fallen grains, shoots, and snails - Breeds in groups, building nests in temple plaques, under eaves, bridge piers, and recesses in coastal rocky cliffs. Breeding is thought to be possible year-round, with two eggs laid at a time, 17 to 18 days of incubation, and 30 days or more of rearing the hatchlings.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is thought to be declining due to competition from house pigeons and hybridization.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Formerly distributed throughout the country, but recently observed only in limited areas such as Gurye-gun and Goheung-gun, Jeollanam-do, and Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do; - International: Distributed in Central Asia, central and southeastern Siberia, eastern Tibet, northern China and eastern Sichuan Province, Mongolia, and elsewhere, mostly in migratory groups.

name: Fairy pitta
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Pitta nymphs are 16 to 20 centimeters long and weigh 67.5 to 155 grams, with plumage in a variety of colors, including black, green, blue, red, and yellow. Males and females are identical, with a brown top of the head and a creamy tan eyebrow line that extends to the back of the neck. The area from the front of the eye to the back of the neck, including the cheeks and earlobes, is black, and the underparts and under the chin are cream-colored. The upperparts of the back, shoulders, and loin are bluish-green with a bluish sheen, and the underparts are vivid blue. The upper tail feathers are black with blue tips to each feather. The chest and flanks are tan, the sides of the neck and chest are greenish-yellow, and the underparts are red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is very wary and rarely seen, and has a habit of flicking its short tail up and down. It is a very beautiful and rare summer bird.- Habitat: Prefers dense forests with lowland understory vegetation with nearby streams or valleys, often found singly in scrub and broadleaf forests on coasts and islands or on inland slopes.- Food: It walks on the ground and feeds on prey such as beetles, earthworms, and crustaceans. It feeds its young almost exclusively earthworms. - Nests in rock crevices or in oval-shaped nests between tree trunks. The breeding season is from May to August, with 4 to 6 eggs laid at a time in May and June. The incubation period is 16 to 18 days. The eggs are cream-colored with pale purplish-brown speckles.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to extensive deforestation in its breeding areas. Other threats include trapping and nest disturbance by humans.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed mainly in the southern coastal islands such as Jeju Island, Geoje Island, and Jindo in Jeollanam-do, South Jeolla Province, but its range has recently expanded and it can be observed inland.- International: Breeds in Southeast Asia, including Japan, eastern China, Taiwan, and Borneo. It migrates from southern China and Taiwan to Borneo around October to overwinter.

name: White-naped crane
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This large crane is about 127 centimeters long and weighs between 4.8 and 6.5 kilograms. The head and neck are white, and the lower two-thirds of the forehead is blue-gray. The blue-gray part of the body tapers up the side of the neck to a thin line just below the eyes. The forehead, eye rims, and cheeks are reddish with exposed skin. The first and second wing feathers are black, but the third wing feather and part of the back are white. Young birds are brown from the top of the head to the back of the neck. The bill is yellowish-green and the legs are red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Highly alert, when approached by humans, the entire flock will raise their necks and heads in the air, ready to fly, as signaled by an individual who has been monitoring the area. There are an estimated 6,250 to 6,750 individuals worldwide. They can live 25 to 30 years in the wild and 45 years or more in captivity.- Habitat: During the non-breeding season, they live in river mouths, mudflats, rice paddies, open fields, and grasslands. During the breeding season, it utilizes shallow marshes or grasslands at the edge of large valleys or lakes.- Food: It feeds on shellfish, insects, corn, rice kernels, grass seeds, and grass roots.- Breeds in dry sedge family plants or grass piles. The breeding season is around April and they lay about 2 eggs at a time. The egg-laying period lasts 28 to 32 days and the incubation period, the period of raising the hatched young, lasts 70 to 75 days. The eggs are greenish-brown in color with dark brown spots and patterns scattered throughout.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Industrialization of agriculture, loss of wetlands due to increased demand for water, habitat fragmentation, and lack of food are thought to be the main factors contributing to the population decline. Other threats include hunting, direct disturbance, pesticide poisoning, and infectious disease outbreaks in their wintering grounds in Izumi, Japan.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Wintering bird, with the largest number of individuals wintering in Cheorwon, distributed in the Han River estuary, Imjin River basin, Suncheon Bay, Gumi Haepyeong Wetlands, Junam Reservoir, and Nakdong River estuary; - International: Breeds in the Amur River basin in eastern Siberia, Izumi, Japan, and the middle and lower reaches of the Yangtze River in eastern China.

name: Hen harrier
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A medium-sized bird of prey with a body length of 43 to 50 centimeters, a weight of 300 to 400 grams in males and 370 to 708 grams in females, and a wingspan of 100 to 121 centimeters. Males are ash-colored on the head, back, tail, and upper wings, while the abdomen and undersides of the wings are white. They have a white back and black wing tips. Females are brownish overall, with a tan underside and brown vertical stripes. When flying, a grayish-black horizontal stripe is visible on the underside of the wings. It has a brown horizontal stripe on its bill and a thicker stripe on the tip of its tail. The legs are tan, the bill is slate-colored, the lead membrane (the soft, convex skin covering the bird's upper bill) is yellow, and the iris is yellow.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It rarely cries except during breeding season, and when it does, it makes a vigorous "ket, ket, ket" sound. They walk or run lightly on the ground, and when they run, they wag their tails vigorously up and down.- Habitat: Mostly solitary, living in wetlands, agricultural areas, and flatlands.- Prey: Mammals, birds, and especially rodents.- Breeding season: Mid-April to early July.- They lay three to six blue-white eggs at a time. The incubation period is 29 to 31 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 32 to 42 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In the past, hunting and secondary poisoning by poisons were the main threats. Currently, habitat loss and degradation are the main threats, and the population is thought to be declining.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A wintering bird, commonly observed throughout the country - International: Breeds in Eurasia and is known to winter from Europe to Central Asia, southeastern China, Japan, and northwestern Africa.

name: Japanese sparrowhawk
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The accipiter gularis is 25 to 27 centimeters long in males and 30 to 31 centimeters long in females. As a small bird of prey, males are dark gray with a bluish tinge on the top of the body, pale orange on the chest and flanks, and whitish as they descend. The irises are dark red, and the bill is ash-colored with a black tip. The rump is a dark grayish-brown color with three thick black bands. The upperparts of the female's body are grayish-brown, the underparts are white with blackish-brown horizontal stripes, and the irises are yellow. Both males and females have a bright yellow rim around the eyes. In young individuals, the edges of the feathers on the upper body are tan and scaly. They have a heart-shaped vertical stripe on their chest and a horizontal stripe on their flanks. In flight, they have several thin horizontal stripes on the underside of their wing feathers, and their legs are tan in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Nests mainly in dense forests. It forages by flying over hillsides or agricultural fields at or near the forest edge.- Prey: Small mountain birds, but also medium-sized birds such as house pigeons, mammals, and small insects such as butterfly caterpillars, grasshoppers, and dragonflies.- Builds nests in branches and usually breeds at heights of 10 meters. The breeding season is from May to August, with 2 to 5 eggs laid in May and June, and the incubation period is about 30 days. The eggs are thin, bluish-white in color with small brown specks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss due to deforestation is the main threat. In some areas of Japan, decreases in breeding success and breeding populations have been reported due to the increase of and attacks by toucans.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: This is an uncommon resident bird, intermittently distributed throughout Korea. Occasional observations are made along the west coast during spring and fall migration, and small numbers are found mainly along the southwest coast during the wintering season - Overseas: Distributed in East Asia, including China, Korea, and Japan, and the northern breeding population descends to Southeast Asia to winter in China, Myanmar, Indochina, and the Philippines.

name: Northern goshawk
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a medium-sized bird of prey with a body length of 50 to 56 centimeters and a wingspan of 106 to 131 centimeters. The male and female forms are similar, and the head, back, wing tops, and tail are bluish gray with a distinct white browline, thick black eye lines, and yellow irises. The chest and belly are white with dense black-brown horizontal stripes. The wings are short and wide, with a long tail that is visible when flying.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It has been used as a hunting falcon in Korea since ancient times - Habitat: In winter, it can be found in forests, agricultural fields near mountains and along streams. It breeds in dense forests with many large trees and a nearly closed tree canopy.- Prey: It tracks and catches flying birds such as pheasants, pigeons, and ducks, and also preys on small mammals such as rabbits, shrews, and squirrels.- Breeding season: The breeding season is from March to August, and two to four eggs are laid at a time from March to May. The incubation period is 36 to 38 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 41 to 43 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include habitat loss and decreased food resources due to the loss of forests and agricultural land due to various developments, and changes in coastal ecosystems due to the development of the western islands. In addition, adverse effects from the installation of wind turbines are predicted.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: In winter, it can be found in the mountains, plains, and riversides throughout the country, and during the breeding season, it inhabits forested areas. During the migration season, a relatively large number of individuals are observed in the western islands of Socheng Island, Eocheng Island, Hong Island, and Black Mountain Island. - Overseas: Distributed throughout the boreal and temperate forests of the New and Old North China, including Japan, Europe, North America, Siberia, and Northeast China.

name: Whooper swan
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is about 140 to 165 centimeters, the weight is 7.2 to 15.0 kilograms in males and 5.6 to 13.1 kilograms in females, and the wingspan is about 205 to 243 centimeters. They have exposed yellow skin in front of the eyes, which is connected to the base of the beak and points forward. The tip of the beak is black. Their entire body is white, and the plumage of both sexes is similar in color, making it difficult to tell them apart in the wild. Young birds are grayish-brown with black grime on a white background. The legs are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It comes to Korea as a wintering bird.- Habitat: It lives in shallow water such as reservoirs, stagnant rice paddies, estuaries, and coasts.- Food: It feeds mainly on plant food, most of which is aquatic vegetation, but it also eats algae, fallen grains, and potatoes. Other foods include plankton, aquatic insects, etc.- Breeding season is from late May to early June, with three to seven eggs laid at a time. The incubation period is 31 to 42 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is about 87 days. They stay with their parents until the first winter.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main causes of the population decline are thought to be the loss of shallow water marshes due to damming and diking of estuaries, dredging, channelization, road building, and reclamation of mudflats and marshes, and the fragmentation of habitat, which reduces prey resources. Other threats, depending on the region, include hunting, lead poisoning, collisions, and avian influenza infection.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Winters on lakes and coasts throughout Korea, including Gangneung City, Gangwon-do, Hapcheon County, Gyeongsangnam-do, Changnyeong County, Seosan City, Chungcheongnam-do, Haenam County, Jeollanam-do, and Sihwa Lake, Gyeonggi-do - International: Breeds in the tundra from Iceland to Siberia in the Old North, and winters in western and central Europe, eastern China, Korea, and Japan.

name: Taiga bean goose
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 76 to 89 centimeters long and is darker brown in color than the common geese. Both sexes have similar plumage colors. The entire body is brown, with a darker upper back and belly, and a light grayish-brown belly. The bill is black with a yellowish band at the tip. The wingtips and tail are black with a white band around the edge of the tail feathers. The upper and underparts are white, and the legs are orange in color. Juveniles have a pale brown head and neck, not much darker than the adults. The orange color of the legs and bill is also lighter than the adult.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: In winter, inhabits plains with large agricultural areas, lakes, rivers, estuaries, reclaimed land, and large reservoirs. During the breeding season, it lives in lakes and rivers. - Diet: It feeds mainly on plant food. It feeds on the fruits and stems of various plants, and in winter, it mainly feeds on rice ears, water grasses, and grass roots that fall in rice fields.- Spawns from the end of May, laying 4 to 6 eggs at a time, with an incubation period of 25 to 29 days. The growth period of the young is 7 to 13 weeks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat degradation due to oil spill pollution, peat extraction, and forest exploitation in its breeding grounds are the main threats to this species. Other factors include poaching, hunting, and pesticide poisoning.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A wintering bird, distributed throughout the country in large agricultural areas, including major migratory stopover sites such as the Qingyuan Plain, Xihua Lake, Tianshu Bay, and Chunan Reservoir; - International: Breeds in the tundra and taiga regions of Eurasia, and overwinters in South Asia, East Asia, and southern and central Europe.

name: Von Schrenck's bittern
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species is about 33 to 42 centimeters long and weighs 89 to 123 grams. The spiracles in front of the eyes are yellowish-green and the irises are yellow. Males have a dark chestnut color on the top of their bodies. The sides of the underjaw and underparts are creamy white; the underparts are tan from the center of the underjaw to the front neck, chest, and belly; the sides and flanks of the chest are brownish; and there is a single dark brown vertical stripe running from the underjaw to the chest. Females have scattered white dots on their backs and shoulders and a vertical stripe down their lower body. The back and upper tail feathers are pale chestnut brown, while the ears, sides of the neck, and back are dark reddish chestnut. The legs are olive green. Juveniles are similar to females but are lighter in color and have more stripes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: very rare summer bird - Habitat: It lives in reed beds, small waterholes, and grassy marshes.- Food: It eats fish, frogs, shrimp, and insects such as grasshoppers.- Nests are made of grass blades and stems on reed stalks at the water's edge or on grassy ground. The breeding season is from May to August, with 3 to 6 eggs laid from May to July. The incubation period is 16 to 18 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is thought to be declining due to habitat loss and degradation from development and human access to wetlands.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: An uncommon summer migrant, it inhabits large reclaimed areas and wetlands such as Sihwa Lake in Gyeonggi-do, Cheonsuman Bay in Chungcheongnam-do, Haenam-gun and Mugan-gun in Jeollanam-do. International: Breeds in southeastern Siberia, eastern China, and Japan, and winters in the Malay Peninsula, Sunda Islands, Philippines, and Indonesia.

name: Upland buzzard
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a medium-sized bird of prey with a body length of 66 to 71 centimeters, a weight of 1.0 to 1.4 kilograms in males and 1.0 to 2.1 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 143 to 161 centimeters. The upperparts of the body are dark brown, and when in flight, the wings and the base of the first wing feathers appear broadly white. The bill is white with brownish-brown markings and has five to eight thin horizontal black-brown stripes. The iris of the adult bird is dark brown, and the juvenile bird is pale yellow. There is a very fine brown vertical stripe under the chin and on the throat. The edges of the wing feathers are lighter in color, and the underside of the body is white with a scattering of brown bold patterns on the chest and underbelly. Below the breast, the color and blotches vary; the flanks and underparts are dark brown. The legs are covered with short dark brown feathers. Its wings and tail are longer than those of the horse shrew, and when it sits down, its wings reach almost to the tip of its tail.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Similar to the horse shrew, but more active in behavior and bolder in temperament. There are no data on its global distribution, but it is believed that the number of individuals is related to the number of rodents it consumes.- Habitat: Inhabits agricultural fields, plains, reclaimed land, open areas, and forest margins.- Prey: Primarily rodents, but also insects and birds.- Nests in the branches of trees overhanging rock walls and mountain slopes, stacking branches to form a saucer-shaped nest. They lay two to four eggs at a time in April and May, with an incubation period of 35 to 38 days and a rearing period of about 45 days for the hatched chicks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss is a major threat to this species due to the loss of grassland and agricultural land due to various developments.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It is found throughout Korea during the winter months, mainly in reclaimed and open areas such as Sihwa Lake in Gyeonggi-do and Cheonsuman Bay in Chungcheongnam-do.

name: Tawny owl
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This nocturnal, medium-sized bird of prey, 35 to 40 centimeters long and weighing 375 to 392 grams, has a rounded head and no right wing with ear-like feathers. Its body is gray, with a vertical stripe pattern on the belly and back mixed with horizontal bands. Its eyes are black, and its beak is bluish-gray.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Uses tree cavities as nests, breeding season is March through June, laying four eggs every three to five days. The incubation period is 28 to 29 days, and the incubation period, or rearing period, is 29 to 35 days, but the young are cared for by the mother until about 7 weeks of age. Habitat: Solitary in coniferous, broadleaf, and mixed coniferous forests in plains and mountains. Sits on branches during the day and is active at night. It breeds in old-growth forests with large dead or dying trees where owls can roost.- Food: It feeds on voles, small birds, and insects, vomiting up undigested material in pellets.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are habitat loss due to deforestation and a decrease in food resources.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A rare bird distributed throughout the country, most commonly found in Gangwon-do, and observed in forests in various parts of Korea, including Gyeongsangbuk-do and Chungcheongbuk-do - International: Distributed from northwestern India to Nepal, southeastern China, northern Myanmar, and northern Indonesia.

name: Greater spotted eagle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird of prey with a body length of 59 to 71 centimeters, a weight of 1.5 to 1.9 kilograms in males and 1.8 to 2.5 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 158 to 182 centimeters. It has a blackish-brown body, long and wide wingspan, and a short tail. The underparts of the first wing feathers are pale, appearing as pale spots on the underside of the wings. The nostrils are rounded, and the irises are brown. The feet are yellow, with feathers covering them to the ankles. Young birds have white spots on the tips of their wing feathers, which look like two white stripes. Its outer first wing feathers droop down when it glides instead of flapping. The size is slightly larger than that of the great horseshoe warbler.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A very rare wintering bird in central and southern Europe. It is characterized by a decrease in the number of spots during molting. - Habitat: In winter, it lives mainly in wetlands, such as river mouths, rice paddies, reservoirs, and mudflats. During the breeding season, they live mainly in the lowlands of forests, preferring forests with adjacent wetlands.- Prey: Mice and other small rodents, frogs, snakes and other amphibians, reptiles, and young of waterfowl, but during the winter months they also eat animal carcasses and dead fish.- Nests are built in the tops of tall trees. From mid-April to early June, the female lays one to three eggs, which she incubates for 41 to 44 days. The incubation period is 60 to 67 days, and the young are fed by their parents for up to a month.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The loss of forests and wetlands due to various developments, as well as the reduction of habitat and lack of food resources due to the industrialization of agriculture and the reduction of rice fields, are thought to be the causes of the population decline. Poaching, secondary poisoning, and collisions with power lines or wind turbines are also major threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Localized distribution in winter in Socheongdo, Cheonsu Bay, Haenam County, Jeju Island, etc. Only a few individuals are observed, and the number of arrivals fluctuates greatly from year to year. - International: Breeds in eastern Europe, Siberia, eastern China, Ussuri Province, northern Iran, and parts of the Tenshan Mountains, and winters in southern Africa, Turkey to India, the Indochinese Peninsula, and southern China.

name: Brent goose
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This small geese is about 61 centimeters long and weighs about 0.9 to 1.8 kilograms in both sexes. Both sexes have a black head and neck with a white neckband. The back, shoulders, waist, and upper tail feathers are dark brown with black markings, and both sides of the waist and both tips of the upper tail feathers are white. The chest is black with a dark brown belly that gets paler towards the bottom, and the lower tail feathers are white. The beak and legs are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: similar in appearance to Canada geese, but with black cheeks; - Habitat: mainly in shallow waters of oceans, bays, and coasts, sometimes settling in rivers, lagoons, and reclaimed areas. During wintering, it can be found in shallow coastal waters and bays. It breeds in moss-covered tundra lakes, tidal river shores, and river mouths.- Food: In winter, algae is the main food, and occasionally shellfish.- Eggs are laid in June, usually in clutches of 3 to 5, and are grayish-white in color. The incubation period is about 23 to 24 days, and the young birds leave the nest within 24 hours of hatching and travel with their parents. They can fly 40 to 45 days after hatching.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are habitat loss due to development and pollution of the coastal areas where it breeds and overwinters, reduced food resources, and hunting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: This rare wintering bird is found on both the south and east coasts, with large annual population fluctuations. During the migration season, it can be observed on both the east and west coasts. A group of less than 100 wintering individuals regularly arrives at Soan Island, Bogil Island, Nohwa Island, and Hyanggido Island in Wando-gun, Jeollanam-do, Korea.- Overseas: Breeds in the Arctic Circle of Eurasia, North America, and Greenland. Winters on the west coast of North America, the coasts of Denmark, the Netherlands, England, and France in Europe, northeastern China, and Japan.

name: Hooded crane
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a relatively small species of crane, with a body length of 91 to 100 centimeters and a weight of 3.3 to 4.9 kilograms in males and 3.4 to 3.7 kilograms in females. It is entirely black except for the white head and the back of the neck. The forehead, top of the head, and in front of the eyes have reddish skin. The beak is tan with a dark apricot color at the base, and the irises are brownish yellow or orange. When flying, the entire wing appears black. It's distinguished from other species by its distinctive white throat and black body color. The legs are black. Young birds are lighter gray than their parents, with a light brownish-white forehead, head, and neck.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: When one bird emits a warning call, the entire flock raises its head, erects its neck, and prepares to fly. When flying, the flock forms a V-shape and performs a high-flying circling maneuver - Habitat: Prefers open grasslands, cleared agricultural fields, or mudflats or riverbanks. During the breeding season, they breed in wetlands or peatlands with surrounding forests.- Food: In breeding areas, they eat a combination of animal prey such as fish and insects and plant prey such as aquatic plants and berries.- In wintering areas, they eat rice and other grains and the stems and roots of plants.- In April and May, they gather reeds or straw to build nests and lay two eggs at a time. The egg-laying period is 27 to 30 days, and the incubation period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, is about 75 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The ongoing reclamation of tidal flats, construction of dams, and development in the wintering areas of China and Korea is reducing habitat as rice fields are converted to cropland for other crops. Threats to the species include outbreaks of infectious diseases such as avian influenza, invasive species, pesticide poisoning, direct disturbance, and poaching in wintering areas where large numbers of individuals are concentrated.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in areas with large agricultural areas, such as the Han River estuary, reclaimed land in Seosan City, Suncheon Bay, and the Nakdong River estuary in winter; - International: Breeds in southeastern Russia and northeastern China, and is distributed in Japan, central and eastern China, and elsewhere.

name: Japanese wood pigeon
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is the largest of our pigeons, with a body length of about 37 to 43.5 centimeters and a weight of 397 grams. The head is slate black with a rosy-purple metallic sheen. The muzzle has a particularly strong green metallic sheen. The beak is blackish-gray, and the irises are dark brown. The body is black, with green and purple luster on the feathers. The legs are red. There are no external differences between males and females, and young individuals lack the green sheen on the back of the neck.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The behavioral range is a 150-meter radius from the tree in which it nests, and it flies low and silent when approaching the nest. In 2020, a single breeding black pigeon was tracked in Ulleungdo and found to leave Ulleungdo in September and winter on Okinoshima Island, Shimane Prefecture, Japan, about 278 kilometers away.- Habitat: Found in dense subtropical and temperate evergreen broadleaf forests in island areas, and is known to prefer old-growth forests as a habitat.-Feeding: It feeds mainly on the fruits of evergreen broadleaf trees, but also commonly eats rowan, sweetgum, umuksasreppi, barleygrass, and fufu.-Nests in saucer-shaped nests about 3.4 meters high in trees that are relatively large and not easy to observe from the outside. The breeding season is from February to August, with eggs being laid until June. Eggs are usually laid in clutches of one, with an incubation period of 18 days and a rearing period of 30 days for the hatched young. The eggs are white and oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to habitat loss caused by various developments. In the case of Ulleungdo, threats include the construction of coastal roads, damage to coastal cliffs due to tourism development, loss of habitat due to forest clearance, and decreased prey resources.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Inhabits coastal and island areas; observed year-round and breeds locally on islands off the southern coast, including Sasado, Chujado, Hodo, and Oedo on Jeju Island, while arriving as a summer migrant on Ulleung Island; - International: Distributed in Japan, eastern Russia, Shandong Province, and Taiwan.

name: Long-billed plover
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 19 to 21 centimeters. Both males and females have a white forehead with a thick black horizontal band bordering the top of the head. The top of the head and back of the neck are grayish brown, with a white brow line above the eyes. It has a wide, dark brown eye line from the front of its eyes to the top of its earlobes, with pale yellow eye rims. The beak is black. The chin, under the chin, is white with a wide white collar that runs across the back of the neck. Under the collar is a wide, dark brown band that runs from the front of the neck to the back of the neck. The back, shoulder collar, loin, and upper tail feathers are grayish brown.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This bird is very similar in appearance, habitat, and behavior to the common summer plover. The plover has a bright yellow eye rim, whereas the white-throated plover is lighter in color.- Habitat: Inhabits gravelly shores of rivers and streams, rice paddies, mountain streams, estuarine deltas, and coastal sandy beaches. It breeds in gravel or sandy areas above the middle reaches of streams.- Food: It feeds on insects and invertebrates in and around streams.- Nests in depressions in gravel or sandy areas, lining them with small stones, shells, and dry grass. The breeding season is March through August, with three to four clutches laid at a time from mid-March through early July. The eggs are reddish-rusty cream-colored with dark brown and small gray specks. The oviposition period is 27 to 29 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to loss of habitat from river and stream construction and loss of sandbars.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Breeding was first recorded in Gapyeong-gun, Gyeonggi-do, in 1994, and has recently been confirmed as a breeding bird in riverine areas throughout the country.- International: Breeds in Far Eastern Russia, northeastern and eastern China, and Japan, and winters in Nepal, India, Bhutan, northern Indochina, southern China, Taiwan, and Japan. There are an estimated 10,000 (670-17,000) birds worldwide.

name: Lesser white-fronted goose
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Anser erythropus is a small geese with a body length of 53 to 66 centimeters and a weight of 2.0 to 2.3 kilograms in males and 2.1 to 2.2 kilograms in females. They are white from the forehead to the top of the head, and dark brown on the forehead, crown, and back of the head. The bill is bright pink, with yellow eye rims that are visible at close range. The irises are a dark chestnut color. The grayish-brown belly has irregular black horizontal stripes. The legs are an orange-yellow color, and sometimes the legs appear crimson, as in the case of the bullfinch. Young birds lack the white on the forehead and the black pattern on the belly. Unlike other geese, the wingtips are longer than the tip of the bill when sitting.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Anser erythropus is similar to a cowbird but is smaller than a cowbird, has a shorter bill, and distinctive eye rims. There are an estimated 24,000 to 40,000 individuals worldwide - Habitat: Prefers large agricultural fields, lakes, and coasts for wintering. In breeding areas, it prefers tundra areas with scattered trees and shrubs.- Food: It feeds exclusively on plant food, eating leaves of herbaceous plants and grains of cereals that fall to the ground in agricultural fields.- It lays two to eight eggs in May and June, and the incubation period lasts about 25 to 28 days, during which the female is in charge. The incubation period, the period of raising the hatched chicks, lasts 35 to 40 weeks. The young spend their first winter with their parents.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Its wintering grounds are severely threatened by poaching, loss of agricultural land, and coastal and lake construction. In the breeding grounds, the main threats are the loss of tundra areas due to climate change, land development, disturbance and poaching.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A wintering bird, regularly seen in small numbers. It is a wintering bird that is regularly seen in small numbers in the Han River area, Junam Reservoir, Cheonsu Bay, and the Geumgang River.- Overseas: It breeds scattered in the Arctic region of Eurasia from Norway to eastern Siberia. It is distributed in southeastern Europe, Iran, eastern China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Eastern imperial eagle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a large bird of prey with a body length of 72 to 84 centimeters, a weight of 2.5 to 2.7 kilograms in males and 3.2 to 4.5 kilograms in females, and a wingspan of 180 to 215 centimeters. It is blackish-brown overall, with a yellowish-brown back, blackish-brown cheeks and lower body, and white shoulders. The bill is large, curved, hard, and horny black with a thinner base and dark yellowish-brown iris. The upper back and upperparts are thinner in color, with white blotches at the base of the feathers and pale green tips. There is a thick dark brown band on the tip of the tail. The toes are indistinct yellow. Young birds are lighter than adults, with tan spots scattered throughout their bodies. The feathers on the inside of the first wing feathers are lighter in color, contrasting with the black wing feathers on the outside.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The same nest is renovated and used every year, so the nest tends to get bigger and bigger. It is not very active and often rests motionless for long periods of time on trees or rocks - Habitat: Inhabits open and flat areas such as estuaries, reclaimed agricultural land, large reservoirs, and rivers. Rests for long periods of time in trees in the center of agricultural fields or at the edge of forests. During the breeding season, it breeds mainly in plains with sparse trees, but also in forests due to habitat loss.- Prey: Small and medium-sized mammals, birds, amphibians, and reptiles, and sometimes feeds on animal carcasses during the winter months.- Lays two to three eggs at a time from late March to early May. The incubation period is 43 to 45 days, and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 65 to 77 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are shrinking habitat, including loss of forests and agricultural land due to development, lack of food, poaching, and poisoning.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It is a wintering bird, locally distributed in Paju-si, Gyeonggi-do, Cheorwon-gun, Gangwon-do, Chungcheongnam-do, Cheonsu Bay, Chungcheongnam-do, Sinan-gun, Jeollanam-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Hyungsan-gang, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Nakdong-gang estuary, Busan, South Korea, and Haenam-gun, Jeollanam-do, South Korea.

conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Sibynophis chinensis is 30 to 60 centimeters long and has a blackish-brown irregular pattern on its head. The black pattern on the head extends down to the nape of the neck, where it gradually tapers and fades along the spine of the dorsal surface. The dorsal surface is yellowish-brown or reddish-brown, and the ventral surface is pale yellow or yellowish-white. Both edges of the ventral scales are reddish-brown in color, and the middle row of scales on the body is mostly 17 rows, with no keel.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Mainly active from April to October, then hibernates - Habitat: Found in mixed grassland and shrubland below 600 meters on Jeju Island.- Prey: Small reptiles such as banded gartersnakes and lizards, and small snakes such as continental bloodsucker hatchlings.- Mates in September, and the female lays five to six eggs in June of the following year, which hatch in 30 to 45 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Because its habitat is extremely limited, its population has plummeted due to the destruction of habitat with conditions that allow it to live. Their preference for certain prey (lizards, long-legged snakes) also seems to be a factor in their decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Currently found only on Jeju Island, where the population is very small - International: Found in China, India, Myanmar, Thailand, Laos, Vietnam, and Malaysia.

name: Amur rat snake
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 1.1 and 2 meters, and the coloration varies greatly among individuals. The upper and lower lip plates have fine black or tan vertical stripes on the edges. The dorsal surface varies from black, dark brown, and tan, while the ventral surface is yellowish white or grayish white, sometimes interspersed with blackish brown spots. The middle row of scales on the body is mostly 23 rows, with the exception of the outer three to five rows, which have keels.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The largest of the large species of Korean reptiles. It is active from April and hibernates from November in the ground, rock crevices, and stone walls on mountain slopes.- Habitat: It lives in forest areas, lakes, streams, cultivated land, and around civilian houses, as well as on the coast and islands of the West and South Seas.- Prey: It preys on rodents such as squirrels, shrews, and shrews, as well as birds and amphibians. Birds prefer eggs and fledglings - Mates from May to June, and females lay clutches of 8 to 22 eggs from July to August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat destruction, roadkill and poaching are the main threats to this species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found throughout the country except for Jeju Island; - International: Distributed in central and northern China and Russia.

name: Reeves's turtle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The top of the head is dark green, greenish gray, or black with no particular pattern. The sides of the head have several yellowish stripes that run from behind the eyes to the nape of the neck. The head and legs can be completely retracted into the carapace, which is 25 to 45 centimeters long. The carapace is dark brown, tan, and divided into several plates, with three distinct keels in the center and on each dorsal side. The edges of the carapace are rounded, and the abdominal carapace is divided into several dark brown and tan plates. The four legs are stacked with broad scales.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: active from April and hibernates until November - Habitat: lives in and around water bodies such as rivers, lakes, reservoirs, and ponds, as well as surrounding waterways, rice fields, and grasslands.- Food: Omnivorous, feeding on aquatic vegetation such as hackam, insects, gastropods such as darters and burrowers, crustaceans, and fish carcasses.- Mating: Spawns in shallow water or underwater from October through November.- Females lay 4 to 15 eggs from June through July in shallow nests in grassland along streams, in cultivated fields, and along banks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss is a major factor in the decline of the population, and other threats include competition from non-native species, such as the Chinese snapping turtle and the red-eared turtle, which have been introduced into the country.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found throughout the country except Jeju Island; - International: Distributed in Hong Kong, China, Japan, Taiwan, and Taiwan; introduced and partially distributed in Canada and the United States.

conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 6 and 10 centimeters. It has a generally large head compared to other pythons. Its dorsal surface is yellowish brown with dark brown or blackish brown edges. The body is scattered with small leopard-print spots that are white on the inside, and the ventral surface is white or grayish-white with no special pattern. The scales on both the dorsal and lateral sides are small and grainy, with 46 to 62 rows of scales, and 11 pairs of inguinal pores*.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Mostly active in the morning and afternoon, hiding under the ground or in the grass during the heat of the day.- Habitat: Inhabits the grasslands of sand dunes along the coasts and islands of the western and southern oceans; inland, along the banks of large rivers and surrounding grasslands; in forested areas, near graves or mountain tops.- Food: Eats spiders and insects.- Mating occurs in May, and the female lays eggs in the ground until June or July. She lays three to six eggs in two to three clutches, which hatch in 40 to 50 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Large-scale river construction is destroying large areas of habitat, and the population is declining due to continued habitat development.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly distributed on the west coast of Korea, including parts of Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do, Gyeongsang-do, and Chungcheong-do - International: China, Russia, and Mongolia.

name: Suweon tree frog
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 2.5 and 4 centimeters. The head is more pointed than that of the common tree frog, with brown and light brown stripes running from the nostrils, through the eyes and nape of the neck, and down the body. The male's bill is usually yellow, but sometimes it's partially black under the chin. The dorsal surface is greenish-blue and the ventral surface is white. Compared to the common tree frog, this species is smaller and has shorter hind legs and less developed webbing between the toes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: begins calling in the afternoon, earlier than common bullfrogs, and its call is relatively low-pitched compared to bullfrogs.- Habitat: Lives in the floodplains of large rivers (large rice fields, agricultural ditches, etc.)- Prey: Insects such as flies, bees, butterflies, and beetles- Breeds from May to July, laying eggs in rice fields and agricultural ditches.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat destruction due to pesticide use is playing a decisive role in the decline of this species, and its localized distribution and low population densities are thought to be responsible.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to Wonju, Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do, Seoul, Chungcheongnam-do, and parts of Jeollabuk-do and Chungcheongbuk-do.

name: Yang's salamander
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Hynobius yangi is 7 to 14 centimeters long, with a yellowish, tan, or yellowish-brown dorsal surface that varies in color depending on its habitat. The ventral surface is yellow, pale yellow, or grayish white with small blackish-brown spots. During the breeding season, males have a wider tail than females due to hormonal changes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: active from February to October, hibernating from November onwards - Habitat: Lives under rocks, stones, dead trees, and fallen leaves in forested valleys and around cultivated fields.- Food: It feeds mainly on insects such as ants, beetles, and bees, as well as on earthworms, spiders, and aquatic insects.- It mates from February to April and lays its eggs in valleys, marshes, waterholes, rice fields, ditches, and agricultural channels around mountainous areas.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to habitat loss and degradation, loss of rice paddy wetlands, construction of houses and roads, and water pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to parts of Gyeongsangnam-do, including Busan, Ulsan, Yangsan, Gyeongsangnam-do, and Gyeongju, Gyeongsangbuk-do.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species is about 3.5 to 6 centimeters long. It is distinguished from the three-banded tree frog by two distinct brown and golden bands on each side of its back, starting behind the eyes, with small bumps scattered irregularly between the two bands. The dorsal surface is green, brown, or other colors depending on the environment, while the ventral surface is mostly yellow or gold. Males have two crying pouches under their chin, but they're very small compared to other frogs. Females are about two to three times larger than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: emerges from hibernation in April and hibernates until October, when it burrows into the ground in the banks of rice paddies, surrounding embankments, and near agricultural fields.- Habitat: found in lowland rice paddies, agricultural ditches, drainage ditches, waterholes, marshes, and reservoirs with abundant vegetation.- Prey: prefers flies, bees, groundhogs, and spiders; occasionally eats trout and frogs.- Breeding season: May through July.- Eggs are laid on vegetation or plant debris, some falling to the ground.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The decline has been attributed to the construction of houses and roads, loss of agricultural land, water pollution, habitat destruction due to pesticide use, and the threat of the introduced bullfrog. Low genetic diversity is also thought to be another factor.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and was previously thought to be distributed throughout southern Korea, including Jeju Island, but recent surveys have confirmed that it is only found in parts of Seoul, Incheon, Gyeonggi-do, Chungcheong-do, Gangwon-do, and Jeolla-do.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 3.5 and 5.5 centimeters. The head is short and blunt compared to the body. Males have a single cry pouch under their chin, which is black during the breeding season, making it easy to distinguish them from females that don't have a cry pouch. The dorsal surface is dark brown with small spots scattered throughout and small, rounded bumps on the nape and back. The ventral surface is translucent gray, and females are slightly larger than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Active from April to October, then hibernates. Its distinctive call of "meng-meng-meng" and "meng-meng-meng" gave it the name meng-kong. - Habitat: It is found in shrubland and grassland around flatlands and wetlands. On Jeju Island, it is widely distributed from the coastal lowlands to the hills and surrounding pastures in the mountainous areas.- Prey: It feeds on insects such as ants, flies, dust bunnies, and fruit flies, as well as arachnids.- Breeds during the rainy season, from June to August, and is known to lay more than 2,000 eggs per clutch. The eggs hatch in about a day after laying.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss and destruction, loss of wetlands, construction of houses and roads, and low genetic diversity are some of the factors contributing to the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found throughout the country, including Jeju Island - International: Limited to central and northeastern China.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 8 to 10 centimeters long, with a very slender, elongated body and a pointed snout. The mouth is small and lower, with a single pair of short whiskers. The body color is dark brown with a broad stripe of blackish-brown running down the center of the sides of the body from the tip of the snout to the base of the tail fin. The fins, except for the pectoral fins, have two black bands.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The pseudopungtungia spawns its eggs on rocks and boulders, and the pseudopungtungia spawning grounds are turbid.- Habitat: The pseudopungtungia nigra inhabits the rocky or boulder-laden bottoms of clear pools in the middle and upper reaches of streams. The habitat varies depending on the size of the individual, and the first and second years live in rocky water at the edge of the stream at a depth of 30 to 100 centimeters, and the third year and older live in rocks or rocks at a depth of 100 to 200 centimeters in the center of the stream.- Food: It mainly eats aquatic insects, and also eats attached algae on stones.- Spawning season is from May to July, and the egg size is 1.8 to 2.1 mm (average 2.0 mm). They hatch 10 days after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C, and 37 days after hatching, the fry are mature and nearly the same size as adults.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Water pollution due to the influx of factory wastewater and domestic sewage, and habitat destruction due to river construction, aggregate extraction, and dam construction are causing a decline in distribution and population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea, inhabiting the Geumgang and Mankyung rivers, and was thought to have been extirpated from Ungcheoncheon Stream in Boryeong-si, Chungcheongnam-do, but was recently reintroduced to Ungcheoncheon Stream by a species restoration project.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Less than 10 centimeters long, with a short, flattened body. The head is flattened at the top and bottom, and the snout is short and rounded. There are four pairs of whiskers around the mouth, the longest of which reaches to the beginning of the pectoral fins. The eyes are relatively large and set back on the sides of the head. The dorsal and pectoral fins have strong spines, with the pectoral fin's spines having an irregular set on the front, and 8 to 10 serrated spines on the inside. The tail fin has a half-moon-shaped pattern at the beginning.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: A nocturnal fish and the smallest member of the family Pseudobagrus. It is very sensitive to environmental changes and has a weak tolerance to water pollution, so it has difficulty living when organic matter accumulates on the bottom or when green or blue-green algae occurs. The Cultural Heritage Administration designated it as a natural monument in 2005 and protects it.
					- Habitat: It lives mainly in the middle and upper reaches of rivers with clear, gravelly water and slow flow rates. Food: It feeds mainly on aquatic insects, crustaceans, and fish eggs at night. Spawning season is from May to July, and the eggs hatch about 50 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 24℃.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution caused by pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction caused by indiscriminate subgrade construction and aggregate extraction for flood rehabilitation, road construction, and bridge construction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is restricted to rivers such as Namgang, Hoecheon, Kumho River, and Gamcheon in the Nakdong River system. Recently, it is also known to have been transplanted to the upper reaches of the Gokcheon River, which flows into the East Sea.

name: Dark sleeper
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 10 to 15 centimeters long, cylindrical in the front and flattened laterally in the back. It has small eyes on the top of its head, a long snout and a large mouth. It has teeth on both jaws, but no teeth on the roof of the mouth and the pubic bone. Its body color is dark brown with a yellow belly and three blackish-brown cloud-like spots on the sides of the body. The two dorsal fins are separate. The back edges of the pectoral and caudal fins are rounded. All fins are striped, and the pattern below the first dorsal fin looks like a bowtie when viewed from the dorsal side.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It was first reported in Korea in 1999 and has a very limited habitat. It is considered to be evidence of the connection between Korean and Japanese rivers during the Ice Age, and is a biogeographically valuable fish species that requires efforts to protect its habitat.- Habitat: It prefers stagnant or very slow flowing water in the middle and lower reaches of rivers, and lives in places where riparian vegetation develops at the edge of the stream and the bottom is gravel or mud.- Food: A nocturnal fish that feeds on aquatic insects, crustaceans, and fish - Spawning season is April through July, when males build spawning nests under large boulders and attract females, who lay their eggs in a single layer on the underside of the boulder and protect them until they hatch.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to habitat destruction caused by water pollution and river development.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Very restricted to Sanyang Stream on Geoje Island, Korea - International: Distributed in southwestern Japan and southern China.
