extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 10 to 12 centimeters long, slender, elongated, and slightly flattened on the sides. The mouth is lower and horseshoe-shaped, with cortical protuberances on the upper and lower lips. The edges of the mouth have a pair of whiskers. It has between 38 and 41 lateral rows of scales, with scales on the ventral side of its chest. The lateral rows are almost straight, but curve slightly downward in front. On the sides of the body, there are about 5 to 13 indistinct brown spots arranged in a row, with an overall greenish-blue vertical stripe. The tail and dorsal fins have small spots arranged in two to three rows of stripes. The dorsal fin has no spots. It's very similar to the pear lionfish, stone lionfish, and goby lionfish, but can be distinguished by its papillary and cortical projections.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: In the past, this species inhabited many streams in the Nakdong and Seomjin rivers, but due to recent population declines, it has been found only in Sancheong-gun, Mungyeong-si, and Yeongyang-gun in the Nakdong River system, and in Imsil-gun in the Seomjin River system.
					- Habitat: Inhabits the middle and upper reaches of rivers with high flow velocities and gravel and sandy pool bottoms - Prey: It mainly eats attached algae, but also small crustaceans and aquatic insects - Spawning season is April to May, and it spawns on gravel surfaces or crevices with high flow velocities. Females carry between 1,100 and 5,920 eggs, the size of the eggs is 0.1 to 1.0 mm, and they hatch 29 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution from pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction due to indiscriminate grading and aggregate extraction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is restricted to the Nakdong and Seomjin river systems.

name: Choi's spined loach

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 8 to 10 centimeters long, thick in the middle but thin in the front and back. The head is flattened sideways, with a pointed snout and three pairs of whiskers around the edges of the mouth. The lateral bands are not distinct, and there are 12 to 17 semicircular or triangular spots arranged on the sides of the body. The upper and dorsal sides of the body have irregular dark brown blotches. The dorsal and caudal fins have three rows of brown bands, and the caudal fin has a small black spot above the base. The bony plates on the pectoral fins of males are serrated, which distinguishes them from other members of the loach family.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This small fish lives in shallow water, but moves to deeper water as it grows. First-year males are distinguished from females by a secondary sexual characteristic, an osteophyte band on the pectoral fin. It was designated as a natural monument by the Cultural Heritage Administration in 2005 and is protected. - Habitat: It lives in clear, flat waters with fine sand at a depth of 30 to 50 centimeters and slow current. It lives by completely burying itself in the sand.- Food: It mainly feeds on small invertebrates in the sand, such as the larvae of crickets, and also feeds on attached algae and zooplankton.- Spawning season is from June to August, the number of eggs laid by the female is 2,000 to 3,000, the size of the eggs is 1.1 to 1.3 mm, and they hatch 24 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 25°C.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Water pollution from pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction due to indiscriminate grading and aggregate extraction, are contributing to the decline of this species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and was abundant in Miho Creek in the Geumgang water system until recently, but now the population is very rare and the distribution area is very limited and fragmented. It is distributed in Yugucheon in Gongju-si, Baegokcheon in Jincheon-gun, Gakcheon in Daejeon Metropolitan City, and Jicheon in Buyeo-gun and Cheongyang-gun.

name: Nakdong korean loach
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 10 to 16 centimeters long and cylindrical in shape, but slightly flattened. The head is large, the lips are made of thick flesh, and there are three pairs of whiskers on the edges of the mouth. The lateral stripes are not pronounced and do not extend beyond the pectoral fins. From the top of the snout to the top of the head, there's a single white band, or it's slightly faded. Males have a bony plate (osteophyte) on their pectoral fins. Overall, their body color is pale yellow with irregular blotches and several black bands on the dorsal and caudal fins.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Distributed throughout the Nakdong River system, but population density is low. Males wrap their arms around the female's torso to induce her to lay eggs. - Habitat: Mostly under gravel or stones in the middle and upper reaches of rivers with fast currents, but juveniles also inhabit gravel and stone substrates with slower currents.- Prey: It feeds mainly on aquatic insects such as mayfly larvae and stonefly larvae at night - Spawning season is April and May, with females carrying between 8,000 and 23,000 eggs, which average 0.9 mm in size and hatch 38 hours after fertilization at 20°C. Fry hatch 50 days after fertilization and resemble adult fish.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to habitat loss from environmental pollution and river construction, habitat fragmentation from dam construction, and overfishing for food.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed throughout the Nakdong River system, but mainly in the middle and upper reaches.

name: Rapid stumpy bullhead
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is about 10 centimeters long, slender, elongated and flattened laterally. The mouth is lower and horseshoe-shaped, with a cortical protuberance on the upper lip. It has 1 pair of short whiskers on the edges of its mouth. It has 38 to 40 lateral rows of scales, and the lateral rows are complete and almost straight. The sides of the body have 10 to 12 spots the size of glasses arranged in a row in the center, with a broad yellow-green band with dark brown stripes. The dorsal and anal fins are nearly straight.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: During the spawning season, the head and cheeks have a blue sheen, and the pectoral and anal fins are slightly reddish. Although similar in habitat and morphology to the stonefly, the coloration of the spawning season is very different.- Habitat: Inhabits shallow, fast-moving, gravelly bottoms in the middle reaches of streams.- Food: Primarily attached algae, but also small crustaceans and aquatic insects.- Spawning season is April and May, and is often found in gravelly pools during the spawning season. Females carry between 2,800 and 5,900 eggs, which are 0.61 to 0.65 millimeters in size and hatch 72 hours after fertilization. They hatch 30 days after fertilization.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat is declining due to indiscriminate grading, aggregate extraction, and water pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, this species is restricted to the Nakdong River system and is currently only found in the Namgang area due to the rapid decline of its habitat.

name: Somjin bitterling
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 5 to 6 centimeters long, flattened laterally and oval in shape. It has 1 pair of whiskers on the edge of the mouth and a complete lateral line. During the spawning season, males have bumps on the top of the snout and around the eyes. The body color is dark on the dorsal side, brownish in the middle, and yellowish or colorless on the abdomen. The base of the dorsal and anal fins has a wide pale band and a wide black band in the center, with a black band at the very edge.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: Males turn bright red near the spawning season. Females use spawning tubes to lay their eggs, which are mainly on fan clams and razor clams. During the spawning season, males compete for freshwater clams. It was first identified in the Imsil area of the Seomjin River system and named as Imsil saddlefish. It is morphologically similar to the knife funnel, but the female's spawning tube is much longer, extending to the dorsal fin, and the eggs are rhombic in shape, distinguishing them from each other.- Habitat: Inhabits shallow, muddy waters with a depth of 1 meter or less and a lot of aquatic vegetation.- Food: Omnivorous, mainly feeding on aquatic insects and attached algae.- Spawning season is from April to June, and the number of eggs held by a female is 10 to 30. The eggs are non-adhesive and do not stick together. The female lays the eggs in the gill cavity of the clam, and the male deposits them in the water-absorbing tube of the clam, the mouth cavity. The eggs hatch 75 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 25 degrees Celsius. Thirty days after hatching, the clams begin to open and close their mouths, allowing them to live independently.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to water pollution, indiscriminate river construction, and the loss of freshwater clams as spawning hosts.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to Korea and restricted to Namwon-si, Gurye-gun, Imsil-gun, Sunchang-gun, and Gokseong-gun in the Seomjin River system.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Kichulchoia brevifasciata is 4 to 5 centimeters long and has a long, flattened body. The eyes are small, with a narrow gap between them, and there are no two-pronged spines (suborbital spines) under the eyes, unlike other members of the loach family. The edges of the mouth have three pairs of whiskers. The lateral line is incomplete and does not extend beyond the pectoral fins. Males lack the bony plate on the pectoral fin (osteophyte). Their body color is pale yellow with brown spots on the back and sides, and 13 to 19 brown horizontal stripes. The chest, belly, and dorsal fin are transparent but sometimes have black spots. Females are generally larger than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is the smallest member of the mudfish family. It was once found in Goheung Peninsula, Gegeumdo Island, and Geumo Island, but is not currently reported to be found in Goheung Peninsula.- Habitat: Inhabits sandy and gravelly water at a depth of 20 to 30 centimeters with a gentle flow rate - Food: It mainly feeds on aquatic insects and attached algae - Spawning season is June and July, the number of eggs carried by the female is 28 to 138, the size of the eggs is 1.4 to 1.5 mm, and they hatch 66 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 25°C, and they transition to juveniles 17 days after hatching.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is highly vulnerable to river modifications and water pollution, and its range and population are declining due to its limited habitat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea, with limited records in Goheung Peninsula, Gegeumdo, and Geumo Island in Jeollanam-do.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is usually between 8 and 10 centimeters, reaching about 12 centimeters in larger individuals. The head is very flattened, and the eyes are very small, biased towards the top of the head and covered by a crust. The upper and lower jaws are of similar length. There are four pairs of whiskers at the edges of the mouth. The body is long and rounded, with no scales and only traces or absent lateral lines. The pectoral fin spines are pointed and have three to five serrated teeth inside the spines, which increase in number as they grow. Their body color is mostly tan, with a pale yellow back and yellowish dorsal and anal fins.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Thought to be extirpated from the Umpqua River, where the stones it uses as habitat and spawning grounds have been destroyed by river works or threatened by turbidity.- Habitat: Inhabits midstream riffles in gravelly streams with moderate to gentle currents.- Food: Nocturnal, feeding primarily on aquatic insects.- Spawning season is May through June.- Spawns under large boulders in riffles with moderate to slow currents. Males build spawning nests under stones and attract females to lay an average of 100 eggs, with the fertilized egg masses (clutches) guarded by males. The spawning grounds are kept free of organic deposits and free of attached algae and aquatic vegetation. The fertilized eggs are deposited in a layer of jelly, forming a ball like a frog's egg.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution from animal waste, fertilizers, pesticides, and domestic sewage, and habitat destruction from indiscriminate river construction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed in the middle reaches of the Geumgang, Ungcheoncheon, Mankyung, and Yeongsan rivers. In the Ungcheoncheon River, it was thought to have been extirpated due to water pollution, but small populations were found in some areas immediately downstream of the Boryeong Dam. In the Mangyeong and Yeongsan rivers, habitat is declining rapidly due to water pollution.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 6 to 10 centimeters long, and the head is slightly flattened up and down. The eyes are relatively large and centered on the sides of the head, and the mouth is semicircular and pointed downward. The edges of the mouth have four pairs of white whiskers. The abdomen is flat, with the lateral rows complete, the first half curved slightly downward, and no scales on the abdomen at the base of the pectoral fins. The dorsal side is light brown and the ventral side is light blue, with six to eight dark spots arranged in the center of the sides of the body. All fins lack semi-openings, and the membrane between the spines and spines (basal membrane) is transparent.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is believed to migrate to the main stream during the spawning season to spawn and then return to tributary streams with its fry, but further research is needed.- Habitat: It inhabits calm pools with a fine sandy substrate at depths of 10 to 50 cm.- Food: It feeds mainly at night on stonefly larvae, thread worms, and polychaete larvae.- Spawning season is June to July, with females carrying 816 to 1,214 eggs, ranging in size from 0.7 to 0.8 mm. They hatch 26 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C, and 13 days after hatching, they transition to the juvenile stage.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution from pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction due to indiscriminate grading and aggregate extraction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is found in the Imjin, Han, Geum, and Nakdong rivers.

name: Slender dark sleeper
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Pseudopungtungia tenuicorpa is 8 to 10 centimeters long and has a very slender and elongated body. Its eyes are relatively large and centered on the sides of its head. The snout is pointed but has a rounded tip compared to the dolphin. The mouth is located below the snout and is small in size, with a pair of short whiskers at the edges of the mouth. The body color is dark brown on the dorsal side and pale gray on the ventral side. There is a wide stripe of blackish brown running down the center of the side of the body from the tip of the snout to the base of the tail fin. The number of lateral scales is between 42 and 45.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: 1-2 year olds live on rocks or large boulders in shallow water at the edge of streams, and 3+ year olds live on rocks and boulders in the middle of small streams at a depth of 100-200 cm.- Habitat: Inhabits clear pools with rocks or large boulders in the middle and upper reaches of streams.- Food: Mainly aquatic insects.- Spawning season: May to July, spawning under narrow stone crevices or in turbid spawning grounds. Females carry between 87 and 345 eggs, which hatch 240 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C and a size of 1.8 to 2.1 mm. About 70 days after hatching, the fry develop a blackish-brown spot at the base of the dorsal fin, resembling the appearance of an adult. During the spawning season, the male's body turns dark brown.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution from pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction due to indiscriminate grading and aggregate extraction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is known to inhabit some limited areas in the middle and upper reaches of the Han River and Imjin River.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is slender and long, 5 to 6 centimeters long, with a slightly flattened body and a very slender tail. There are usually 8 to 9 small sharp spines on the dorsal side, and the spines are connected to a membrane between the spines and the spines (called the basilar membrane). Its body color is pale brown, with a slightly mottled pattern on the sides. The lateral bands are complete. The tail is short and slender, with a rounded tip at the back of the caudal fin.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: During spawning season, the dorsal fin basal membrane of males has some deposits of black pigment, which fade in females. The dorsal fin basal membrane of the spiny dogfish is white, distinguishing it from the spiny dogfish. Outside of the spawning season, they live in groups.- Habitat: Does not descend to the sea but lives in fresh water. They live in the middle and lower reaches of streams with very slow currents and lots of vegetation.- Prey: Aquatic animals such as mayfly larvae, thread worms, and water fleas.- Spawning season is estimated to be April through August, and they prefer slow-moving or stagnant streams with lots of vegetation. Males build circular nests at the base of aquatic stems to attract females to spawn. Males care for the nest and eggs until the young hatch.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is in rapid decline due to habitat destruction caused by indiscriminate grading, aggregate extraction, and water pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to inhabit the middle and lower reaches of streams flowing into the East Sea in the north of Yeongdeok-gun, Gyeongsangbuk-do, South Korea. Known transplanted populations have been reported in reservoirs such as Jecheon City, Chungcheongbuk-do, Korea - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is about 13 centimeters long and has a fusiform body. The head and body are flattened sideways and have a high body profile. The mouth is large, the lower jaw is slightly longer than the upper, and the snout has a pointed tip. It has two sharp spines in a spot behind the gill covers. Behind the gills is a blue spot about the diameter of the eye, and a pale brown band runs from the tip of the snout to the beginning of the dorsal fin. The front of the body is a glossy dark brown, with the dorsal side being darker in color than the ventral side. The pectoral fins are colorless, and the other fins are light brown. There are 10 to 11 dark patterns running from the back to the belly.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Territorial behavior is observed in the juvenile stage, when the body shape and hemipenis resemble that of adults. Males use their pectoral fins to stir the water to provide oxygen to the fertilized eggs until they hatch. Even after the young emerge from the eggs, the male will protect them for a considerable period of time.- Habitat: Inhabits the middle reaches of rivers and lakes with sand and gravel bottoms, abundant aquatic vegetation, and slow water currents.- Food: Carnivorous, feeding on aquatic insects, terrestrial insects, and small fish.- Spawning season is May and June.- Females attach their eggs to the stems of reeds or snapdragons in areas with sandy or gravel bottoms and abundant aquatic vegetation. The number of eggs carried by a female ranges from 350 to 755, and the eggs hatch 194 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 18.2 to 22.0°C, with a size of 2.2 to 2.7 mm.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to water pollution caused by pesticides, domestic sewage, factory wastewater, and livestock wastewater, as well as habitat destruction caused by indiscriminate river construction and aggregate extraction. In particular, the Tamjin River has experienced habitat fragmentation since the construction of the Jangheung Dam and the construction of several beams in the river channel.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the Tamjin River, streams in the southwestern coastal region, and some Boseong and Yeongsan rivers flowing into the South Sea, and recently confirmed in the Geumgang River. In the past, it is known to have inhabited several rivers flowing into the Namhae Sea from Gyeongsangnam-do and Jeollanam-do.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species is 8 to 10 centimeters long, with an elongated body. The body is thicker at the front and thinner at the back. The head is slightly pointed and flattened at the base. It has four pairs of whiskers around the edges of the mouth and a flap over the eyes that allows them to open and close. Its body color is multicolored, with three or four dark brown horizontal stripes on the sides of the body between the dorsal and caudal fins. The lateral stripes are almost complete and straight.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: During spawning season, females are yellowish in color, while males are a deep chestnut color. They are the only freshwater fish in the world that can sense the brightness of the light outside and open and close their eyelids. When it's dark, they open to the sides, and when it's very bright, they close in the center: Inhabits fast pools with thick layers of gravel and boulders at depths of 10 to 30 centimeters where water velocities are very high.-Feeding: It feeds on aquatic insects such as mayfly larvae and stonefly larvae at night.- Spawning season is from April to June, spawning on the edges of shallow pools. Females carry 1,000 to 3,000 eggs, which hatch 107 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C and a size of 0.8 to 0.9 mm. They reach sexual maturity in the second year of life.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In recent years, its population has been declining due to habitat disturbance caused by civil engineering works such as river works and dam construction. It lives in the margins of second-rate or clearer waters, so it is highly affected by organic matter deposition in streams and damage to the substrate structure.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is known to inhabit the middle and upper reaches of the Imjin, Han, and Geum rivers.

name: Far Eastern brook lamprey
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This eel is 15 to 20 centimeters long and has a slender, eel-like body. It has 7 pairs of gill openings behind its eyes. The mouth is sucker-shaped, round, jawless, and has teeth (keratinized teeth) in the oral cavity and tongue. The dorsal side of the head has a single outer nostril (external nares) that is not connected to the oral cavity. The dorsal side of the body is dark brown or pale brown, and the belly is colorless. It lacks pectoral and belly fins, and its tail fin has a few black spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The color of the fins changes to tan during the spawning season. Adults die after spawning and fry are released - Habitat: This freshwater-adapted fish spends its larval stage buried in the middle and upper reaches of small streams or reservoir bottoms in sand and pearl. As adults, when eyes form, they inhabit the sandy, gravelly, slow-moving reaches of mid- to upper-streams.- Feeding: Hatchlings feed by filtering organic matter from the sandy riverbed. The juvenile stage takes three or more years to develop into an adult over the fall and winter of the fourth year. Adults do not feed at all, hiding during the day and becoming active only at night.- Spawning season is March and April, and they spawn in pools in sandy or gravelly riverbeds.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to habitat loss caused by environmental pollution and river construction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in rivers and reservoirs throughout Korea except Jeju Island, but the population is currently declining. - International: Distributed in northern China, Japan, and Sakhalin, Russia.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is about 10 to 15 centimeters long, with a slightly elongated body and a flat belly. The head is flattened from top to bottom, the snout is protruding and pointed, and there are four pairs of whiskers around the edges of the mouth. The eyes are relatively small and located slightly behind the center of the head. There's a black diagonal line under the eyes that runs toward the muzzle. The nostrils are close together at the front and back and are located closer to the front end of the eyes than the tip of the muzzle. Its body color is pale yellow with seven or eight wide vertical bands on the sides of the body and five or six on the dorsal side. It has a wide array of dark spots on its back.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: hides well under stones and moves quickly from one stone to another to hide.- Habitat: inhabits pools with clear, fast-moving water and large boulders at the bottom.- Food: feeds on aquatic insects such as mayfly larvae, stonefly larvae, and stonefly larvae.- Spawning season is April through May.- Eggs are laid among gravel at the edge of shallow pools. Females carry between 259 and 1,642 eggs, which hatch 120 hours after fertilization at a water temperature of 23°C and a size of 1.1 to 1.4 mm. They participate in spawning from 2 years of age.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is characterized by living in fast, stony pools, but its habitat has been greatly reduced in recent years due to the loss or disturbance of pool areas due to river works and dam construction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and has been observed in some limited areas of the Imjin River, Hongcheon River, Seom River, Namhan River, and Geum River.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 6 to 8 centimeters long, flattened from side to side, and has a high body profile. The muzzle is protruding and rounded at the end. The edges of the mouth have one pair of whiskers. The lateral line is complete, and males are taller than females and have a different body color. During the spawning season, males develop a darker dorsal patina and a yellowish belly and caudal fin, while the black and yellow bands on the dorsal and anal fins become more pronounced. During the spawning season, males develop bumps on the top of the snout and around the eyes. Females are dark brown overall, with yellowish dorsal and anal fins.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: There is a lot of competition among males for territory over freshwater clams. To avoid being ejected from the clam, protuberances are formed on the epidermis of the clam; all protuberances degenerate when it is time to leave the clam.- Habitat: Inhabits the middle and upper reaches of streams with gentle currents and large boulders and gravel in the bottom.- Food: It is omnivorous, feeding mainly on attached algae, but also on crustacean larvae and protozoa.- Spawning season is from April to June, and the eggs are laid in the gills of the gizzard clam or small horse clam. The number of eggs a female carries is small, around 50, and the eggs are egg-shaped. During the spawning season, the female elongates the gray-brown spawning tube of the reproductive pore. The female lays her eggs by inserting the long spawning tube into the freshwater clam's water outlet hole, and the male spawns by sperm.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The habitat of the spawning host clams is being disturbed by river construction and aggregate extraction in the middle and upper reaches of rivers, with a concomitant decline in the habitat of the signifer. As an ornamental fish, it is highly valued commercially, so there is always a risk of overfishing.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is found in the Han River system, and is known to inhabit the Daedong and Yalu rivers in North Korea.

name: Amur minnow
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is relatively short and thick, about 10 centimeters long. The head is large with a rounded snout, the lower jaw is shorter than the upper jaw, and the eyes are relatively large. Their body color is brownish, darker on the back and lighter on the belly. The scales are small and difficult to distinguish with the naked eye. There is a black spot at the base of the dorsal fin, and the body scales have dense brown pigmented vesicles at the edges, giving them a crescent shape. The pectoral fin base is dark yellow in color, and the dorsal, anal, and pectoral fins are yellowish in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A cold-water fish that lives in schools in well-preserved substrate.- Habitat: Inhabits mountain streams with clear water, low water temperatures, and rocky substrate or large boulders.- Food: It feeds mainly on aquatic insects, small crustaceans, and live worms.- Spawning season is estimated to be April through May, but little is known about its exact ecology. During the spawning season, males develop small bumps on the top of their heads and the front of their dorsal fins.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has a very narrow and restricted range, and its distribution and population are declining due to river development and water pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is known to inhabit some streams that flow into the East Sea in the eastern part of the Mintong Line. It lives in the mountain streams of Namgang and Songhyeoncheon in Goseong-gun, Gangwon-do. It is also distributed in North Korea, where it is believed to live in the upper reaches of the Red Wall River in Mount Kumgang.

name: Dwarf iksookimia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 6 to 8 centimeters long, cylindrical but slightly flattened. The head is large, the mouth is located under the snout, and there are three pairs of whiskers around the edges of the mouth. The eyes are small and biased toward the top of the head. The lateral rows are incomplete, and the body color is pale yellow with 5 to 10 horizontal stripes down the middle of the dorsal and lateral sides. The dorsal and caudal fins have 2 to 3 horizontal rows of stripes. The dorsal fin begins slightly before the anal fin and has a rounded outer edge, forming an overall triangular shape. Males have a long, bony plate at the base of their pectoral fins.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Males wrap their arms around the female's torso and squeeze to induce her to lay eggs. The subspecies is smaller than the true clownfish, the female carries fewer eggs, and the eggs are larger.- Habitat: Inhabits sandy and gravelly substrates at depths of 20 to 50 centimeters in areas with gentle currents - Food: Eats attached algae and aquatic insects attached to stones - Spawning season is April through June, and the number of eggs a female carries ranges from 142 to 878 (average 328).

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The construction of the Buan Dam on the Baekcheon in the 1990s created a small reservoir upstream, causing a sharp decline in habitat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is very limited to Baekcheon, Buanan-gun.

name: Common minnow
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Small, 6 to 8 centimeters long, with an elongated, laterally flattened body. The front end of the mouth is blunt and downward, and the lower jaw is shorter than the upper. It has no whiskers and its eyes have a golden shine. The body has 14 to 17 indistinct hemipenes arranged horizontally in rows, the lateral rows are incomplete, as they sometimes break off at the caudal region. The scales are small and thin, the dorsal fin is posterior to the anal fin, and the tail fin is deeply forked at the tip. It is greenish-brown or purplish-brown on the dorsal side and silvery-white on the ventral side. During the spawning season, males are deep orange with white and orange markings on the dorsal, pectoral, anal, and caudal fin bases.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Korea is the southernmost point of its distribution range, and it is a cold-water fish that is very sensitive to changes in water temperature, so its habitat is likely to decline due to climate change.- Habitat: It lives in schools in mountain streams with clear water and low water temperature. The substrate consists of bedrock and large boulders, and they prefer gravelly areas.- Food: They feed on aquatic insects, attached algae, and organic matter.- Spawning season is estimated to be April through May, and they spawn on gravel beds in fast-flowing streams and creeks. Females carry an average of 508 eggs, with an average egg size of 1.6 mm. They hatch six days after fertilization. A single female is followed by several males who burrow into the gravel in groups to spawn. During the spawning season, both sexes are mixed color, with males having distinct bumps on the top of the snout and around the eyes, and the back of the gill covers are dark blue.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to the destruction or narrowing of its habitat due to river maintenance, water pollution, and rising water temperatures.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Limited to the upper reaches of the Namhan River in the Han River system in Yeongwol County, Jeongseon County, Pyeongchang County, Taebaek City, and Samcheok Osipcheon, which flows into the East Sea. It is distributed from the upper reaches of the Yalu River and the Duman River to the Seongcheon River in Hamhung. - Overseas: Distributed in Europe, Siberia, and China.

name: Tsinling lenok
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Act of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is about 70 centimeters and the body is streamlined. The upper and lower jaws are about the same length, with the upper jaw slightly longer than the posterior margin of the eye. This member of the salmon family is characterized by its oily fins, almost straight lateral lines, and 124 to 133 scales. Their body color is brown on the back and light on the belly. The head and sides of the body, especially the dorsal side, are scattered with small dark brown spots, which are also scattered on the dorsal fin. The dorsal and anal fins are light orange in color. Young individuals have 9 to 10 blackish-brown horizontal stripes on their sides, characteristic of salmonid fishes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: A cold-water fish whose population is likely to decline due to climate change. The Korean Cultural Heritage Administration has designated the thermal woodfish colony at Jeongamsa Temple and the thermal woodfish colony at Bonghwa Seokpo-myeon as natural monuments and protects them.- Habitat: It lives in upstream areas with very clear water, low water temperature, and large stones.- Food: It feeds on small fish, insects, and small animals.- Spawns in early April and May when the water temperature is between 7 and 10°C. Eggs are 3.5 to 4.0 millimeters in size. After spawning, they cover the front with sand and gravel, and the spawning grounds are about 30 centimeters in diameter and about 5 centimeters high.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to habitat loss from river development and illegal harvesting, and is likely to decline due to rising water temperatures caused by climate change.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in parts of Gangwon-do and Gyeongsangbuk-do - International: Distributed in Manchuria and Siberia.

name: Japanese lamprey
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This eel is 40 to 50 centimeters long and has an elongated, eel-like body. It is characterized by seven pairs of gill slits behind its eyes, and its nostrils are located on the top of its head and are not connected to its mouth. It doesn't have a jaw, but a bump on its sucker-shaped mouth. The teeth are well developed, with two cusps on the upper jaw and six or seven cusps on the lower jaw. Its body color is brown to off-white, with a grayish-brown upper surface and a lighter underside.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: After the juvenile stage, it goes out to sea to grow and returns to streams to spawn. In the past, it was widely distributed in streams and rivers along the east coast, but is now very difficult to identify.- Habitat: Juveniles live in the mud in the middle and lower reaches of streams, while adults prefer gravelly pools for spawning.- Feeding: During the two to three years they spend at sea, they are parasitic, sucking blood from the bodies of other fish. They live in the mud of the middle and lower river bottoms for about four years, filtering organic matter at night to feed on it.- They come to rivers from the ocean in May and June to spawn in sandy and gravelly riverbeds. Both males and females die after spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population has plummeted due to environmental pollution, loss of shallow pools due to river construction, habitat destruction, and indiscriminate overfishing, especially for medicinal purposes.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in the Baebong Stream, Yangyang Namdae Stream, and Yeongok Stream, which flow into the East Sea; - International: Distributed in north-central Japan, the Heilongjiang River system in Siberia, Sakhalin, and North America.

name: Large bitterling
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 9 to 11 centimeters long, flattened from side to side, with a low profile. The head is small, the snout protrudes forward, and the eyes are large. The horseshoe-shaped mouth is relatively large, and the eyes are widely spaced apart. It has 37 to 40 lateral row scales, and its overall color is green, with a dark green band running from the 5th to 6th scale of the lateral row to the base of the caudal fin. The dorsal and caudal fin edges are red with alternating black and white bands on the inside. The edge of the anal fin lacks a white band.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This species is commonly found in the Nakdong River system, often in association with the rowfin. It was previously classified as the same species as the stringfin, but was separated by differences in size, microhabitat, and mixed coloration.- Habitat: Prefers stony or gravelly places with relatively deep and flowing water, around 1 meter in depth.- Food: Omnivorous, mainly feeding on aquatic insects and attached algae.- Spawning season is from April to June, and during the spawning season, females develop spawning tubes to spawn inside freshwater clams. Males form colonies centered around freshwater clams, and females spawn inside the gills of freshwater clams. During the spawning season, the male's eyes are reddish, his body is dark green and red, and his spiracles extend into his nostrils and around his eyes. The tip of his snout is rounded and protrudes.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to habitat disturbance and subsequent construction and aggregate extraction that disrupts the stable habitat of its spawning host bivalves*.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed in some limited areas of the Seomjin and Nakdong river systems.

name: False rose bitterling
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Rhodeus pseudosericeus is 5 to 7 centimeters long and has a flattened, oval-shaped body. The head is very small and the snout protrudes forward. It has 34 to 37 very large, tile-like scales, and the lateral rows are incomplete, with only the first 6 or 7 scales having holes. It's grayish-green on the dorsal side and silvery-white on the ventral side. A longitudinal blue band runs from about halfway down the side of the body to the base of the caudal fin. The dorsal and anal fins have three rows of black dots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: prominent black and yellow coloration on the sides of the body during the spawning season - Habitat: mid to upper reaches of streams where the bottom is composed of stones or gravel and the current is slow.- Food: Omnivorous, feeding primarily on aquatic insects, including mayfly and stonefly larvae, and phytoplankton, including attached algae and phytoplankton.- Spawning season is April through May, when the female lengthens the spawning tube near the reproductive pore and lays multiple eggs inside the gill cavity (bird cavity) of the clam. Eggs are a pear-shaped with a deep blue color and hatch in 70 hours at a water temperature of 17°C.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat, declining spawning host clams, and overfishing for ornamental purposes have reduced its population. The construction of transverse dams on island rivers in its former range has reduced its habitat and it is now found only rarely in some small streams.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is mainly found in Gapyeong-gun, Yangpyeong-gun, and Hwaseong-gun, which are part of the Han River system, and is also distributed in the upper reaches of the Woosan River, which flows into the West Sea. Currently, it is only observed to live in a very limited area.

name: Hangyeong sculpin
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Cottus hangiongensis is small, 10 to 15 centimeters long, with a streamlined body that is slightly flattened to the sides. The head is flattened from top to bottom and the mouth is large and straight. The head and lower jaw have no cortical protuberances, but the jaw and moisturizing bones (hyoid bone) are toothed. There are no scales and the lateral rows are complete. Its body color is grayish-brown, darker on the dorsal side and lighter on the ventral side. The sides of the body are scattered with brown spots. The dorsal fin is light in color with a dark green outline. The caudal fin is yellowish with four brown horizontal stripes, and the dorsal fin is white with black spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: the male's dorsal fin is longer than the female's and is characterized by a yellowish coloration interspersed with large white spots during the spawning season.- Habitat: inhabits gravelly, stony, fast pools in the lower reaches of rivers at depths of 20 to 50 cm.- Food: mainly aquatic insects.- Spawning season is March to April.- Eggs are deposited in clumps under stones in pools at depths of 20 to 40 cm. The eggs hatch 25 to 30 days after fertilization at a water temperature of 6°C. After hatching, they migrate down to the coast to live and then return to the river when they are strong enough to swim.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Water pollution from fertilizers, pesticides, factory wastewater, domestic sewage, and indiscriminate river construction are factors in the decline of the population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Inhabits the lower reaches of rivers along the east coast, and is believed to be present in the Tumen River region of North Korea.- International: Distributed in China and Japan.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: With a wingspan of 65 to 75 millimeters, this butterfly is one of the larger members of the mosquito family. The upper surface of the wings is white, but in the freshly allegorized individuals it may be yellowish. The forewings have a black circle pattern on the middle forewing thread and the fifth and seventh hindwing threads. The forewings are black and the hindwings have a black border, with a reddish underside. The hindwing bases also have a reddish pattern. Females have a darker base color than males, with darker red spots. It's similar to the mosquito butterfly, but the mosquito lacks the red spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: An annual springtime occurrence, adults can be seen in late April and early May and disappear later in the year. When mating, the male creates and attaches a mating sac to the end of the female's abdomen. The female stays near the food source and deposits her eggs one by one on dry leaves, stems, stones, etc. around the food source: Lives in treeless areas in the mountains and flatlands, and is most active in the mornings on rocky outcroppings.- Food: Nectar from raspberries, thistles, and giraffe grass.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the rapid loss of habitat, such as grasslands, and indiscriminate overfishing. The larvae's food is limited to giraffe grasses, and their habitat is very limited.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in Korea: Samcheok-si and Jeongseon-gun in Gangwon-do, Yeongju-si and Uisung-gun in Gyeongsangbuk-do, and some other areas; - Overseas: Far Eastern Russia and northeastern China.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This insect is a 30 to 40 millimeter-long member of the silkworm family. Its head is pentagonal in shape, and the males have protruding double eyes. Its body is green with a metallic sheen, and it has two red stripes on the pronotum and scutellum. The ventral side of the body is golden-green, with a golden-red center on the thorax and abdomen.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Appears in early July, peaking in mid-July, and disappears by mid-August. It spawns on dead or about to die spindle trees, zelkova, persimmon trees, etc. It is the largest of Korea's silkworms. Since ancient times, the green scab wings of adult beetles have been used as decorative objects, and artifacts using the green wings of silk beetles have been found in the tombs of the Silla Dynasty in Gyeongju: Largely inhabits dense forested areas - Food: Larvae feed on the woody parts of broadleaf trees such as yew, zelkova, and persimmon trees, while adults prefer to feed around older, larger trees.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Because of its brilliant color, it has been indiscriminately collected for ornamental purposes and its population has declined, and the decline of its habitat, forests with old-growth trees, is thought to have contributed to its decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In the past, it was distributed in Jeollabuk-do, Jeollanam-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Gangwon-do, and Jeju-do, but it is now found in parts of Jeollanam-do and Gyeongsangbuk-do.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 56 to 60 millimeters. The upper surface of the wings is blackish-brown, and the underside is pale yellow with a blackish-brown base. The wings have two black snake-eye-like patterns on the outer part of the wings, the abdomen, and a white band that extends down the forewing and hindwing. The wings are covered with many black feathers, and the wings are blackish-brown with grayish-white outer margins that undulate outward. The underside of the wings is more pronounced than the upper surface, and females are larger than males, with a noticeably thicker belly.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Occurs once a year in July and August, with peak populations in late July. Females lay eggs one by one on the leaves of their prey - Habitat: Inhabits grassy areas with exposed rocks from 1,300 meters up Hallasan Mountain, and dry grassy areas from Upper Seorim (1,700 meters) to Baekrokdam.- Food: It feeds on nectar from thyme, pine cones, matsutake, and honey grass. Larvae feed on rice plants (nori).

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The rapid spread of forestry in its native Hallasan alpine region has reduced the distribution range of its prey, the rice family plants, and the population is declining due to a variety of factors, including climate change.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: In Korea, it is found only in grasslands above 1,300 meters on Hallasan Mountain in Jeju Island. - International: Distributed from Far Eastern Russia to southeastern Europe, northwestern China, and Tibet.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 52 to 59 mm, the body is black, and the wings are covered with pale gray hairs that are white on both the upper and lower surfaces. The male's antennae have yellow tips, and there is a lot of white scale dust on the wings. Females have about half of their antennae yellow, with relatively little scale dust.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: An annual occurrence, adults emerge from late May through June and overwinter as larvae. Females lay 50 to 60 eggs in clusters attached to the caterpillar's food source. The outstretched wings are reminiscent of white people, hence the name Sangje butterfly, which refers to a person wearing a white robe and holding a prize.- Habitat: Prefers forest edges and open areas around human settlements in light shrubland, mainly in limestone areas; - Food: Caterpillars feed on the leaves of Rosaceae plants such as apples and apricots, while adults feed on nectar from thistles, cow parsley, shamrocks, weaselweed, and buttercups.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat destruction and overfishing are the direct causes of the population decline, and it is believed that global warming has shifted the southern limit of the monarch butterfly's range northward, so it is no longer observed in central and south-central Korea.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: It can be found in some areas such as Samcheok-si, Gangwon-do and Yeongwol-gun. Korea is the limit of the southern distribution of this butterfly. It has not been observed in South Korea since 1997. - Overseas: It is distributed in Japan, Asia and Europe, and northern Africa.

name: Manchurian laticollis scarab

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 30 to 37 millimeters long and 16 to 19 millimeters wide. It is characterized by its long antennae, which are the tips of the antennal segments; males have seven segments with a curved middle and females have five segments. The body is broadly oval and dark reddish-brown in color, and the back is mottled with an irregular covering of short grayish-white or yellowish-white scales. The underside of the chest is covered with long, straw-colored hairs, and males have two spines on the calf of the forelegs and females have three. The claws on the ankles are short and sharp.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Takes 4 years from egg to adult, overwinters annually as a larva, which pupates in June and then emerges as an adult. It appears mainly in June and July. It is the largest species in the black scarab family in Korea. - Habitat: It mainly lives in the grass of cultivated fields around rivers and sandbars along rivers. - Food: The larvae gnaw the roots of plants along the streamside such as reeds in the ground.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The larvae that live along rivers and streams are declining in numbers because their habitat has shrunk.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In the past, it was found in all parts of Korea, including Paju-si, Gyeonggi-do, Seoul, Jeju-do, and Nonsan-si, Chungcheongnam-do, but it is currently found only in Nonsan-si, Chungcheongnam-do, Buyeo-gun, and Cheongju-si, Chungcheongbuk-do.

name: Callipogon (Eoxenus) relictus
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 85 to 120 mm in males and 65 to 85 mm in females. The male's tusks are staghorn-like, thick and long, while the female's are smaller. Males have a mid antennal horn and dense spots on the pronotum, ventral plate, and mesothorax. Females lack a mid antennal horn and have a smooth breast plate. The lateral margins of the pronotum have serrations, and the scutellum is reddish-brown with short golden hairs. The wing tips are rounded, but the suture tips are sharply pointed like spines. The body is yellowish-brown or blackish-brown, covered with short yellow hairs.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults are active between June and September, with peak populations in August. It is the largest of the East Asian beetles - Habitat: It lives in dense broadleaf forests in lowland areas - Food: The larvae feed on the pith of large trees such as hornbeam, cypress, and ash. It is believed to oviposit in decayed wood rather than live wood, with an estimated number of 90 eggs. The adults feed on sap from the hump-like bumps on the trunks of redbud trees.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to climate change, habitat loss due to development, and overfishing.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Previously recorded from Bukhansan Mountain in Seoul, Chuncheon-si, Gangwon-do, Hwacheon-gun, Yang-gu-gun, and the Salt River in Gangneung-si, but currently only known from Pocheon National Arboretum in Pocheon-si, Gyeonggi-do.- Overseas: Distributed in northern China, Amur region. It is assessed as Red List in the Russian Red List.

conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
