extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: With a wingspan of 30 to 36 millimeters, this butterfly is the largest of the monarch butterfly family. The upper surface of the wings is dark brown and the underside is silvery white, which reflects well in sunlight. The underside of the wings has a short blackish-brown pattern at the tip of the midshaft, and a thin dark brown band running vertically from the center to the edges. The edges of the wings are rounded, with well-developed white markings. The hind wings have orange markings near the hindwing antennae and at the top of the caudal process. The caudal process is slender and long. Females have wider wings than males, with several white dots on the inside of the upper edge of the forewing.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults emerge once a year from mid-June to late August. Males perform occupancy behaviors near the tops of oak trees more than 10 meters high, and females lay eggs one by one under the winter snow of their prey starting in mid-July.- Habitat: Inhabits deciduous broadleaf forest mountains above 850 meters above sea level.- Prey: Prey is aspen trees in the willow family. They remain attached to their prey during the day and become active in the morning and at dusk.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is believed to be in decline due to overfishing, habitat loss, and climate change caused by indiscriminate illegal harvesting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in Korea: Inje-gun, Jeongseon-gun, Pyeongchang-gun, and Hwacheon-gun, Gangwon-do; - Overseas: Far Eastern Russia and central and northern China.

name: Korean scarlet dwarf dragonfly
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 15 and 17 millimeters. Males are reddish in color, while females are brown and yellow. The male's pronotum is black from the front, with two pairs of red spots and a black, bold line down the center of the dorsal plate of the mesothorax. The cephalothorax is black and the dorsal plate of the abdomen is red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Fables can be observed from late May to late August, with pupation occurring from June to August. Larvae live in mountainous wetlands with shallow, spring-fed water. They overwinter as adults and have one generation per year. They pupate in an upside-down handstand position and mature in about a week. After mating, the female flies across the water and spawns in swamps, agricultural ditches, and rice fields: Found in mountainous wetlands and fallow rice fields. Recently, it has been observed mainly in mountainous wetlands.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are plummeting due to the decline of its primary habitat, mountainous seepage wetlands, and the landing of fallow rice fields.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found mainly in forested wetlands or fallow rice fields in central and southern Korea.

name: Daimoji cruiser
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The total body length is 70 to 77 mm, hindwing length is 45 to 50 mm, and belly length is 55 to 60 mm. The double-eyes are bluish indigo, and the body is a dark turquoise color with a metallic sheen and yellow stripes. In females, the coloration is dorsal yellow. It looks similar to the gnatcatcher, but differs from it by having a round yellow pattern on the third segment of the abdomen with a broken center. The larvae are 26 to 28 millimeters long, with horn-like projections on the front of the head and small bumps on either side of the back of the head. The legs are slender and long, with three brown spots on the tarsi.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Mates perched in tall trees, and females spawn singly by splashing in the water, a method known as oviposition. Larvae overwinter as larvae (two years, one generation), hiding in the sand of wide rivers and streams. The size of the molted larvae is about 30 mm. Habitat: Inhabits low mountainous and hilly areas in the middle reaches of rivers and streams. Food: Both larvae and adults are carnivorous, feeding on small insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include sand extraction from rivers where the larvae live and changes in habitat conditions.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Limited distribution in some areas such as Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, and North Korea; - International: Distributed in the Far East, southern Russia, and Japan.

name: Cicindela (Abroscelis) anchoralis
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The head is 12 to 15 mm long, with a concavity between the eyes and a single sharp tooth in the center of the upper lip. The scutellum has a pair of coppery brown or green vertical stripes in the center of the wings and a yellow pattern along the outer edge. The pronotum is straight along the sides and widens toward the back. The male has a pointed tip on the scutellum, while the female has an inwardly curved tip. It is characterized by the anchor-shaped pattern on its scutellum.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults emerge and become active mainly in July and August. Mating is done by the male climbing on the female's back, and the female lays her eggs in the sandy soil.- Habitat: Found in coastal sand dunes.- Food: Larvae burrow vertically in the sand or soft soil of the beach to hide and feed on passing insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The degradation and loss of coastal sand dunes has resulted in habitat loss and population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: In the past, it was observed in some areas of the west coast, including Yongyu Island, Incheon, South Korea; Taean County, Chungcheongnam-do; Seosan City, Seosan Province; Jaeyeon Island, Jeollanam-do; and Gochang County, Jeollabuk-do, but it is now restricted to Taean County, Chungcheongnam-do and Sinnan County, Jeollanam-do. It is not found on the east and south coasts. - Overseas: Distributed in Japan, China, and Taiwan.

name: Angelina skimmer
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Females are smaller than males, with a belly length of 24 to 31 mm and a hindwing length of 30 to 34 mm. The body is elongated and oval in shape, brown in color, with fine hairs all over the body, and the pronotum and wingtips are generally small and narrow. The wings are marked with brown spots, which appear at the base, center, and wing tips. The legs are slender and hairy, especially at the calf joints.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Active from April to June. It overwinters as a larva, and after mating, the female oviposits eggs by slapping the water. The eggs hatch a week later and undergo 12 molts before overwintering as an imago (a larval stage just before reaching adulthood). The larval stage lasts about 10 months. Habitat: Lives in low-lying ponds or marshes with lots of aquatic vegetation, such as reeds, and rich organic matter due to plant deposits in the bottom layer.- Food: Both larvae and adults are carnivorous, feeding on small insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the loss of habitat as wetlands are reclaimed.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed in Incheon Metropolitan City, Gyeonggi Province, Gangwon Province, Gyeongsangnam-do, North and South Gyeongsang Province, Jeollanam-do, Chungcheongnam-do, and Jeju Island. It has been observed in wetlands along the west coast, but has recently been found in Gyeongsan-si, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and Jeju Island.- Overseas: Distributed in Japan and China.

name: Blanchardi stag beetle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 26 to 67 mm in males and 24 to 31 mm in females. The male's large jaw is slender, long, rounded, and curved inward. The jaw has a wide, pointed tooth on the inside, pointing towards the head, with four or five sharp teeth at the end. In smaller individuals, the inner teeth may be absent or the jaw may be flat instead of curved. Females have a shorter, more slender jaw with a rounded inward curve. The upper jaw has blunt teeth on the inside. The body is tan or light brown in color, with a vertical stripe down the center of the pronotum and black spots on either side. The scutellar sutures and marginal stripes are black to dark blackish brown.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults are active from June to September, and females lay their eggs in 3- to 7-mm depressions in decaying wood from June to August. Eggs hatch in about two weeks in natural conditions in summer. Most overwinter as larvae near the roots of host trees, but occasionally as adults. Life cycle: egg, larva, pupa, and adult - Habitat: evergreen broadleaf forests - Food: sucks sap from broadleaf trees.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has been overharvested due to its popularity with collectors and has declined in population, and its narrow habitat range is one of the threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed mainly in the broadleaf forests of Jeju Island, with a record of a 2001 observation at Jaejangsan Mountain in Jeongeup-si.

name: Brunneriana grasshopper
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Males are large and fat, 28 to 37 mm long, females 35 to 50 mm. The pronotum is spotted and granulated, with distinct wrinkled ridges and a conical bump on the ventral surface of the pronotum. The body is grayish-brown or dark brown, but there are many color variations. The wings are degenerate, scaly, and very short. The tympanic organ on the ventral side is well developed. In males, the tympanum is long and triangular, with a groove in the center. In females, the ovipositor is pointed and has no teeth.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults emerge in May and June, and because they are flightless and slow migrants, they may be lost if their habitat is destroyed. They overwinter as eggs, with each female laying a small clutch of an average of 17 eggs.- Habitat: Inhabits barren, semi-deserted environments, often hiding on the ground or in the leaf litter, camouflaged with protective colors.- Food: Both larvae and adults are herbivorous, gnawing on the leaves of many plants. They feed mainly on herbaceous plants such as rice, sedges, and leaves of small shrubs.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to habitat fragmentation caused by forest development and grassland loss, and its slow movements and small home range make it difficult to respond to environmental changes.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Formerly distributed nationwide, but recently found in some areas, including Yeongwol-gun, Gangwon-do, Korea - International: Distributed in northeastern China and Far Eastern Russia.

name: Mirabilissimus ground beetle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Males are 23 to 25 millimeters long, females 25 to 28 millimeters long. It has a large head with a strongly developed jaw, a thick neck, and long, oval scabby wings that are sculptured like net eyes. The body is brilliantly colored, with dark blue and turquoise sheen on a black background. The hind wings are degenerated and flightless.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Overwintered adults emerge from May and new adults emerge from mid-July to September. Both larvae and adults are nocturnal. - Habitat: Rarely found in primary forests in the mountains at altitudes above 900 meters. - Food: It feeds on ground-dwelling invertebrates such as earthworms and snails, and on the larvae of small insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The beautiful coloration of its scabby wings has led to a decline in its population due to indiscriminate illegal collection.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Korea has four subspecies, including the gourd beetle on Taebaeksan Mountain, the Deokyu gourd beetle on Deoksansan Mountain, the Odaesan gourd beetle on Odaesan Mountain, and the Ilwol gourd beetle on Ilwolsan Mountain. They are found in Gyeonggi-do, Gangwon-do, Jeollabuk-do, and parts of Gyeongsangbuk-do. It is endemic to Korea and does not live abroad.

name: Cybister (Cybister) chinensis
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species has an elongated, oval-shaped body, 35 to 40 millimeters long. It has a recessed area on each side of the head. The body surface has reticulated folds and is greenish-black on the dorsal side and tan on the ventral side. The pronotum and scutellum are dark green with yellow stripes on the lateral edges. Males are glossy, females are not. The legs are yellowish-brown, but the ankles of the middle and hind legs are blackish-brown. The three bases of the ankles of the forelegs of males are fan-shaped with intumescence (膨大) and oval suckers.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This is an elaborate, metamorphosing aquatic insect. Adults can be seen year-round and fly to lights at night. It lays elongated eggs, one on each stem of submerged plants. They breathe at the surface of the water by storing air in the tips of their scabby wings and creating air bubbles. Habitat: They live in flat water streams, ponds, swamps, and artificial lakes with lots of aquatic vegetation. Food: Both adults and larvae are carnivorous, feeding on tadpoles, fish, small aquatic organisms, and dead animals.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is declining due to pesticide use and environmental pollution.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Widely distributed throughout the Korean Peninsula in the past, but populations have declined in recent years, making it difficult to observe - International: Distributed in China, Japan, the Russian Far East, and Taiwan.

name: Deyrolli giant water bug
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 50 to 60 millimeters. It has a relatively small head with dark brown eyes. The body is yellowish-brown or brownish in color, narrow and flattened to an oblong-oval shape. The forelimbs are flattened and sickle-shaped, with a single hooked claw on the ankle of the forelimbs and two claws on the ankles of the middle and hind limbs. The eighth metatarsal has a pair of breathing tubes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: There is one generation per year or one generation every two or three years, and individuals emerge from hibernation in April. They mate from the end of June, and after mating, the female lays a clutch of 60 to 100 eggs, which she attaches to cattails and other water plants. The eggs are cared for by the male and hatch after 10 days. After reproductive activity, most adults die, but some overwinter in mud, stones, or under dead leaves near their habitat in moist places with little temperature fluctuation.- Habitat: Inhabits wetlands such as ponds, rice paddies, puddles, and farm ditches, which represent the purified environment of freshwater ecosystems.- Food: Eats a variety of aquatic organisms such as small fish, tadpoles, minnows, and caddisflies.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat destruction, water pollution due to overuse of pesticides, and agricultural land improvement projects have led to population declines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly distributed in islands and coastal areas, inland wetlands, and civilized areas along the east and west coasts; - International: Distributed in Japan, China, and Taiwan.

name: Gymnopleurus (Gymnopleurus) mopsus
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 10 to 16 millimeters. The front of the head shield is curved upwards and has a depression in the center. The antennae are black and short. The dorsal plate is matte black, pentagonal and flat, with a dense distribution of fine granules throughout. The pronotal dorsal plate is large, flat and circular, with a convex center and densely packed with fine grooves. No small shield plates are visible. The scutellum is narrower than the pronotum and has a deep depression near the base of the pronotal margin. There are seven rows of faint longitudinal grooves, with small granules between them. The forelegs have three large teeth (exopods) at the ends, and the ankles are very small.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Adults are active from late spring to fall, but peak activity is in June and July. They roll up feces from prey animals and carry it to burrows in the ground where they lay their eggs. They help clean the soil by decomposing animal feces. Habitat: They live in deserts, grasslands, and forests. Food: They eat the feces of large herbivores such as cattle, horses, and sheep.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Reduced livestock grazing, heavy use of pesticides, changes in livestock farming practices, and environmental pollution are thought to be factors in its decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: formerly distributed throughout South and North Korea, including Jeju Island, but is thought to have been extirpated from Korea in the 1970s. - International: distributed throughout the former Korean Peninsula, except Japan.

name: Takanonis silverline
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This butterfly has a wingspan of 26 to 32 millimeters, which is moderate for a monarch butterfly. The outer margin of the forewing is rounded in females, whereas in males it is smaller and more straight. The upper surface of the male's wings is bluish-purple at the base, while the female's is blackish-brown. The hindwings are orange near the caudal margin, and the underside of the wings is milky white with a yellowish tinge, lined with blackish-brown patterns with a white center.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Annual, with adults emerging from mid-June through July. Females lay eggs from mid-June through July in pine, sour oak, and juniper trees or rock crevices where host ants have homes. She lays one to three eggs at a time in the same place. It is the only butterfly in Korea that has two tail-like protrusions on its hind wings. - Habitat: It lives in pine forests in the mountains and less forested places during the day. - Food: It flies to the flowers of catnip, black swallowtail, and chestnut to collect nectar.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitat loss due to urbanization, a challenging reproductive ecology that requires symbiosis with ants in the larval stage, and overfishing are contributing factors to population declines.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in Korea: Yeongwol-gun, Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do, Gwangju Metropolitan City, Seoul, and parts of Chungcheongbuk-do - Distributed abroad: Japan.

name: Copris (Copris) tripartitus
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 13 to 19 millimeters. Males have an ivory horn on the forehead, and the head shield is broadly fan-shaped with a distinct anterior point. The body is glossy black with fine longitudinal grooves on the scutellum. The pronotum has distinct pits and bumps, with a deep, wide longitudinal groove in the center. Coarse spots are scattered around the projections and within the longitudinal groove, and small spots are densely distributed on the posterior margin near the base. The forelimbs have four calf tarsi.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults are observed from April to October and are most active before midsummer. Females lay their eggs in round dumplings made of feces. It is an environmental scavenger that decomposes the feces of herbivores.- Habitat: It lives in grassy areas in flatlands and wilderness.- Food: It digs burrows under the feces of mammals, such as cow dung and horse dung, and takes the feces to eat or make round dumplings.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Decreased grazing of livestock, heavy use of pesticides, changes in livestock farming practices, and environmental pollution are some of the factors contributing to the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout the country, but more common in the southwest coastal islands than inland. It has been found in Gangwon-do, Incheon, Jeollanam-do, Jeollanam-do, and Jeju-do.

name: Ambigua fritillary
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 34 to 42 millimeters. The upper surface of the wings is reddish-brown with a net-like pattern of black bands. The yellowish bristles are reddish-brown in each vein and appear as red dots. The undersides of the wings are lighter in color than the upper surface, with a broad yellow midwing band and a semicircular yellow pattern on the outer margins. Females have larger wings than males and a rounded outer margin.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Occurs once a year, with adults emerging in June and July. It overwinters as a larva and undergoes a full metamorphosis, passing through egg, larva, pupa, and adult stages. Males fly rapidly around the water's edge to search for females, but females are not active and are difficult to observe. Females lay their eggs on the backs of violet leaves, which is the caterpillar's food source.- Habitat: Inhabits forest edges in treeless grassy areas or around glades.- Food: Nectar from flowers such as cattails, thistles, chickweed, and black-eyed Susans.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to climate change, loss of grassland, and other factors.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Common in the interior of the Korean peninsula until the 1990s, but the population has declined and until recently was restricted to parts of Jeolla and Gangwon provinces. However, it is currently not found in Gangwon Province. - Overseas: Distributed in Russia, Japan, and China.

name: Nerippe fritillary
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: With a wingspan of 53 to 68 millimeters, Argynnis nerippe is the largest of the leopard butterfly family. The upper surface of the wings is orange with a black pattern, and the wing veins have a black heart (M) shaped dot at the tip. The undersides of the forewings are similar to the upper surface, and the undersides of the hindwings are spotted with silver. Males have a black sex marker on the second and third veins of the upper forewing to alert mates to their presence, while females have a white dot on the crown. The wings have a white spot near the tip. Females are larger, darker in color, and have a more pronounced black pattern than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: an annual occurrence, beginning to emerge in May, peaking in June and July, and reappearing in September after a summer hibernation. Females lay eggs until early October and overwinter as larvae.- Habitat: Meadows and forest edges in mountainous areas.- Food: Nectar feeds on dog's-bane, black-eyed Susans, thistles, etc.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations of this cold-tolerant species are thought to be affected by the loss of grassland due to deforestation of its habitat and climate change.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: limited distribution in parts of Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and Incheon, Korea; - International: distributed in Far Eastern Russia, Japan, China, and Tibet.

name: Unicolor skipper
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 31 to 35 millimeters. The upper surface of the wings is blackish-brown, the underside is tan, and the underside of the hindwing has a yellowish-brown base with a long horizontal silvery-white stripe in the center. In spring, this pattern is clearly visible, but in summer it fades to a pale tan and becomes more like the underlying color. There are no significant differences between males and females, but females have rounded wing edges and a plumper belly than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Occurs twice a year, adults are most abundant from May through August. Females lay single eggs on food items, which overwinter as larvae.- Habitat: Found in grassy areas around rivers, railroads, wetlands, and valleys. They make their homes by rolling up the leaves of plants such as basswood, etc. - Food: The larvae feed on the leaves of rice family plants (basswood, puppyweed, etc.), and the adults suck nectar from shamrocks, plum horsetail, and cattail.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the loss of its habitat, the tall grassland along streams, due to river improvement projects.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in parts of Chungcheongnam-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, Gangwon-do, and Jeollabuk-do; - International: Distributed in Japan and China.

name: Bombus (Megabombus) koreanus
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 10 to 21 millimeters long, with a strong setae on both sides of the middle of the cephalothorax. The queen's head is 4.5 to 5.2 millimeters wide. The hairs on the forehead shield are the longest, and the double eyes are hairless. The thorax is entirely covered with black hairs, except for the lighter colored hairs at the end of the abdomen. The long hairs on the dorsal surface of the fourth, fifth, and sixth tergites are pale yellow.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Active between early April and June. This is the largest of the domestic bumblebees. Its habit of gathering on various flowers makes it a potential pollinator. - Habitat: It is a pollinator insect with a long proboscis that feeds on deep flowers such as azaleas, rhododendrons, and azaleas, and lives in grassland and forested areas where these flowers bloom.- Food: It feeds on nectar from plants such as sesame, pumpkin, azalea, azalea, azalea, and astragalus.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to climate change.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Widely distributed throughout the country, including Jeju Island, but recently found locally in Gangwon-do, Chungcheongbuk-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, North Gyeongsangbuk-do, and Jeollabuk-do - International: Distributed in China.

name: Changeonlee ground beetle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is 25-27 mm in males and 26-29 mm in females. The dorsal surface is black with a dark blue, dark green, turquoise, or coppery metallic sheen, with black high spots. The head and pronotum are reddish-bronze in color, with a large head and thick neck. The pronotum is navy blue, the posterior plate and the rest of the thorax and abdomen are navy blue. The scutellum has eight rows of longitudinal grooves, and the scutellum is almost triangular in cross-section due to its high center.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: annual occurrence, adults emerge between May and September - Habitat: Lives in forested areas such as virgin forests.- Food: Eats earthworms, snails, and larvae of other insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is popular with collectors and is declining due to indiscriminate illegal harvesting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed in Jirisan Mountain in Gyeongsangnam-do and Jeollabuk-do.

name: Caeleste hermit beetle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species has an elongated body, 27 to 28 millimeters long and 14 to 17 millimeters wide. The head is flattened, with blackish-brown antennae and overlapping eyes. The overall color of the body is blackish-brown or reddish-brown, with a violet sheen. The pronotum is broad, and males have two strong longitudinal ridges in the middle of the pronotum, with two small bumps in front of the ridges. The ventral abdominal plate of males has a longitudinal indentation in the center, which is normal in females. The scutellum (small shield-shaped plate) is long and triangular with a deep rounded puncture, and there are three calf tarsi on the forelegs. There are two sharp, long spines on the outside of the middle and hind tarsi.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Mostly active in July and August, it has a musky odor when held in the hand. The larvae burrow into the humus of decaying wood or the xylem of dead conifers and emerge as adults in early summer, but their ecology is not well understood.- Habitat: Inhabits mountainous areas, preferring broadleaf forests with lots of fallen maple and ash trees.- Feeding: Adults feed on plant sap, while larvae burrow into the humus and woody pith of decaying trees.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include a limited, small population and decline due to illegal harvesting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Yangyang-gun, Inje-gun, Cheorwon-gun, Hwacheon-gun, Hongcheon-gun, Seoraksan, and Salt River in Gangwon-do Province, but the population itself is small - International: Distributed in Japan.

name: Divina hairstreak
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Delisted in 1998
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designations of 1996
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation Act of 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 31 to 36 millimeters. The upper surface of the wings is bluish-ashen, and the underside is white with a grayish tinge. On the underside of the wings, black dots are arranged in two rows on the forewings and three rows on the hindwings, alongside the edges. The hindwings have a small blue-ashy pattern on the underside and a reddish pattern on the inside of the edges. Females are slightly larger than males.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults emerge in May and June, and females lay single eggs in flower buds. They spend the larval period during the flowering of the ginseng, and pupate shortly afterward. Males fly quickly in the morning, resting in the shade during the hot day. In the afternoon, they fly slowly and search for females.- Habitat: Lives in grassy areas such as cemeteries and around bank banks in the wilderness and cultivated areas - Food: It feeds on nectar from catnip, thistles, ginseng, berries, shamrocks, and nectarweed.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Indiscriminate illegal overfishing and habitat loss due to shrinking grasslands are the main reasons for its decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in Yeongwol-gun, Gangwon-do, Danyang-gun, Chungcheongbuk-do, and Jecheon-si, Chungcheongbuk-do - International: Distributed in Japan.

name: Asian triangle mussel
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Cristaria plicata is the largest of the domestic freshwater bivalves, with an adult size of 18 centimeters in length and 13 centimeters in height. The shell is long and oval in shape, with a thick, blackish shell. The front and back of the carapace (shell tip) protrude in the shape of ears, but the feathers on the front of the carapace are worn off as the adult grows, leaving only the back. The inside of the carapace has a dark purplish sheen, and the surface of the carapace has rough growth veins. The tergites also have ear-like projections on the front and back of the pronotum, which are larger and sharper on the back. Greenish radiating bands are clearly visible on the carapace.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is known to have been used as a mother-of-pearl for pearl farming in the Nakdong River during the Japanese occupation.- Habitat: Found in swamps, streams, channels, and reservoirs with muddy bottoms at depths ranging from 0.2 to 2.0 m. - Food: It feeds on fine organic matter, including zooplankton and phytoplankton - Larvae released from inside the mother's shell from September through April attach to the gills or fins of fish and grow. After three years or so, the larvae develop into adult-like forms and live apart from the fish.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are drought-induced water level declines and changes, overfishing, and loss of host fish species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly distributed in the middle and lower reaches of the Nakdong River, also observed in Gyeongsangnam-do, Jeolla-do, Chungcheongnam-do, Gangwon-do, etc.

name: Knobbed triton
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Adults are the largest of our cephalopods, with a carapace height of 22 centimeters and a carapace width of 10 centimeters. The carapace (the entire layer above the body layer) is cone-shaped and high, with seven layers. The shell is very hard and thick, and the surface of the shell is yellowish white with irregular reddish-brown patterns. The sutures are not deep, so the boundaries of the sieve layers are unclear, and the sieve layers near the apex are sometimes calcareous and difficult to identify. The orbits are large, oblong-oval, and the outer labium is thick. There are long white projections on the oblique line above the inner labium, and several wrinkles below the axial labium, and the male tube is wide and short.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: the shell is ornamental and the flesh has been used for food - Habitat: distributed between 20 and 200 meters deep, often found on rocks at lower depths - Prey: starfish, mainly red fire starfish in Jeju Island - Sexes are separated, fertilization is internal, and spawning occurs from December to April.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Overfishing for food is a factor in its population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Jeju Island and the southern coast of Korea - International: Japan, Philippines, etc.

name: Subquadrate crab
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is small, about 2 centimeters long and 1.5 centimeters wide. The carapace is square in outline, and the forehead is tongue-shaped, short and tilted forward. The carapace is flat in the middle of the dorsal surface, but slopes sharply from the top of the center. The dorsal surface is densely covered with small granules and short hairs. Both pincer legs are symmetrical, relatively short and strong. Both the inner and outer surfaces of the forelegs are convex and densely packed with small granules. The male's first tarsus is slightly curved in the shape of a triangular column and is relatively short and thick.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The number and shape of the granules on the head below the eyes are important identifying traits that distinguish this species.- Habitat: Lives in burrows in a mixture of stones and sand in the upper mudflats of the tidal flats.- Food: It feeds mainly on carcasses and organic matter of various organisms.- It is believed to mate between May and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat area and habitat development are known to be the main threats to the declining population of the southern blue crab.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in parts of Jeollanam-do, Geomun-do, Jeju-do, and Udo; - International: Distributed in Japan, Taiwan, Australia, New Caledonia, East Africa, and Indonesia; - Tropical: Found in mangrove forests.

name: Korean freshwater mussel
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Aculamprotula coreana is a medium to large species of domestic freshwater bivalve, measuring about 7.4 centimeters long, 9.1 centimeters wide, and 4.5 centimeters high. The shell is rounded-ovoid, symmetrical to the left and right angles, thick and hard. Concentric, rough growth veins appear on the surface of the shell, and many bumps appear on the top of the shell. The shell is yellowish greenish-brown in color, with a pearly sheen on the inside of the shell.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Lives in deep, fast-moving water with a mixture of sand and gravel on the bottom.- Feeding: In its larval stage, it attaches itself to the fins or gills of fish and sucks up nutrients as it grows. Adults feed by filtering organic matter, plankton, etc.- Larval sacs form on the outer gills of females around October, and larvae are released in April of the following year. The larvae resemble castanets and have small hooks that allow them to attach to fish. They live parasitically on their hosts, such as fish, until they metamorphose into larvae.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are overfishing, disturbance of the riverbed by rapid flow changes, and the decline of host fish species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: The Han River population is presumed to be extinct as there have been no reports of observations since 1987, and is currently found in some areas of the Geumgang and Seomjin river systems. It is endemic to Korea.

name: Convex crab
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The carapace is up to 4 centimeters long and about 5 centimeters wide. The outline of the carapace is square with convex edges. The forehead is short and tongue-shaped, with rounded edges and a strong downward slope. The body is generally violet in color, and the dorsal surface has a deep longitudinal groove extending down the middle. The lateral edges of the carapace are very convex and have four broad teeth, including the eye teeth. The pincers are large and strong. The male's claw is larger than the female's, and both are similar in size. The claws are convex on both sides, smooth on the back and outside, but with granules on the inside and underside. The claws have an arrangement of large and small ones, with the larger ones near the center, so that when the claws are closed, they form a figure-eight gap.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Burrows in upper coastal grasslands, estuarine ditches, and marshes where tidal flats are developed.- Food: feeds primarily on carcasses and organic matter of various organisms.- Pupating individuals are observed from June through September, but breeding patterns are difficult to determine due to low numbers.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to the species are habitat development and garbage dumping.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It has been recorded around tidal flats nationwide, but has recently been found on the southern coast of Korea and Jeju Island.

name: Geoje snail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A terrestrial gastropod in the family Satsuma myomphala, a large species with six or seven layers. The shell is yellowish-brown and the body laminae are large and rounded, with a reddish-brown color band starting at the center of the body laminae and extending from the body laminae to the sutures. The suture is oblique with shallow, thin growth veins, and the provision closes near the axial labrum. The clypeus is semilunar, broad, and retracted in the axial region.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: endemic to Northeast Asia, it is a species of great scientific value among large terrestrial crustaceans due to its limited distribution and low population frequency in Korea.- Habitat: known to inhabit forests adjacent to coastal areas.- Food: mushrooms, mosses, berries, and trees.- It is a hermaphrodite and is known to spawn in the ground or under fallen leaves, but its exact life history has not been studied.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are overhunting and overexploitation by tourists, habitat development, small population size, and predation by natural enemies.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Geoje, Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea - International: Distributed in Japan.

name: Suenson's soft coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The cluster is a bifurcated mass, shaped like a broccoli. The branched clump is about 10.0 cm tall, 5.9 cm wide, and 4.5 cm thick, narrower than it is tall. The branches and stem are white, but the base of the stem is grayish white. The thin branches are orange-yellow, the polyps are dark red, and the polyp stalks are lightly colored. The dichotomous branches are cylindrical in shape, and the base of the lowest branch is lobed. The polyp head is 0.96 to 0.99 mm long and 0.84 to 0.91 mm wide, and the polyp stalk is 0.43 to 0.56 mm long and stands at an obtuse angle. Smaller polyps are present at the base of the polyp. The primary convergent osteophytes project above the polyp head, and the lower convergent osteophytes are arranged in three to four pairs converging at an obtuse angle, with one to two pairs arranged transversely. The supporting osteophyte bundle is robustly developed and protrudes about 0.7 mm above the polyp head. The ventral face of the polyp stalk is densely and obliquely arranged with large accessory osteophytes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: lives in colonies with other species of soft corals (stony corals) and has many internal and external symbionts, playing an important role in the ecosystem- Habitat: lives at depths of 5 to 20 meters in clean waters with strong currents- Food: feeds on small plankton and other prey using venomous spores- Breeding season is August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, marine pollution, and careless aquatic recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: restricted to the waters off the southern coast of Korea and Jeju Island; - International: distributed in Sagami Bay, Japan.

name: Orange cup coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is tree-like, measuring 5.5 to 6.3 centimeters tall, 7.0 to 7.5 centimeters wide, and 5.8 to 7.3 centimeters thick. The branches are slightly elongated, about three to four, with a narrow front-to-back angle. The entire colony is scarlet in color, with the bulb and tentacles light orange or reddish. The isthmus (lime ring) is cone-shaped, with new isthmus arising symmetrically to the previous one. The mandibles are round or oval, measuring 6.6×6.5 to 18.0×12.0 mm in diameter. The septum is complete with four annuli. In some isthmuses, a fifth annulus develops, but its upper end does not project above the isthmus wall. The isthmus is 10 to 22 millimeters deep, and the outer wall of the isthmus is densely lined with narrow rice-shaped projections. The axial column is elongated and spongy, 3.0×1.2 to 6.0×3.0 mm in diameter.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It plays an important role in ecosystems because it often forms colonies with other corals and lives in symbiosis with many species, both internally and externally. The growth and spread of golden bugle coral is slow compared to other species.- Habitat: Attached to reef slopes at depths of 5 to 20 meters in waters with clear, warm water and strong currents.- Feeding: Tentacles retract during the day and extend at night to feed on zooplankton.- Reproduction: Asexual or sexual, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Unauthorized collection for ornamental purposes is the main threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island; - International: Distributed in tropical waters from Sagami Bay, Japan, to the western Atlantic to the Indian and Pacific Oceans.

name: Retropictum nerite
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a small gastropod with an adult size of 1.0 to 1.5 centimeters in height and angular diameter. There are four lamellae, but in most adults the lamellae are eroded away, leaving only the body lamellae. The carapace is semicircular, with a slightly thickened outer labium, and small bony structures in the center of the inner labium. The carapace is greenish-brown with triangular yellow and black spots. The body layer has weak growth veins, with two or three rows of yellowish-brown bands. The cap is calcareous, with yellowish lines on the edges.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: brackish water fish have an estimated lifespan of 12 years - Habitat: inhabits brackish water areas where saltwater meets freshwater, preferring habitats with large and small stones in the stream bed - Food: crawls on stones in the water, feeding on attached algae or organic matter - Lays white clumps of eggs on stones in the summer, hatching from the eggs in September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Changes in the habitat, such as construction (roads, bridges, etc.), water pollution, and salinity changes are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Gangwon-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, Jeollanam-do, Jeollanam-do, and Jeju-do. Recently, it has been confirmed that the species is also found in the Gisu area of the east coast. - Overseas: Distributed in Japan.

name: Spiny plumarella
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is pinnate and completely flat, about 15 centimeters high and 8.8 centimeters wide. The colony is white, tan below the midrib, yellowish-white above, and apricot-colored overall. The branches are approximately 4.5 to 8.5 centimeters long and branch at a 50° angle. The trunk is flattened, branched, and glabrous. Within 5 cm of the trunk, there are about 15 twigs 2.0 to 2.5 cm long. Polyps are arranged in groups of 11 to 14 within about 10 mm, measuring 0.6 to 0.9 mm in length and 0.3 to 0.5 mm in diameter. The polyps have three to four poles projecting from the edge of the polyp, and there are about six osteophytes on the dorsal side of the polyp and three on the ventral side.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: a rare cold-water coral with many internal and external symbionts, which makes it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: attaches to rocks at depths of 50-100 m - Food: captures and feeds on small plankton and other prey using venomous spores - Ecological information on reproduction is scarce.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters off the southern coast of Korea and Jeju Island - International: Distributed in Sagami Bay, Japan and the Bering Sea.

name: Chinese ear snail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Ellobium chinense is a small species, with adults measuring about 2.7 centimeters in length and 1.4 centimeters in diameter. The shell is elongated-oval in shape, with a conical base and seven layers. The carapace is yellow or blackish-brown in color, and older individuals may have a white color. The growth veins and spiracles intersect at the apex to the edge of the sieve layer, forming a fine bristle pattern; below the edge to the base, there are no spiracles, only growth veins. The sclerenchyma is rounded and shallowly sutured, and the sclerenchyma is not inflated but is large, occupying most of the sclerenchyma. The angular bulb is located midway between the margins of the sieve layer, elongate-ovate, with a thickened outer and lower labium and three strong folds on the axial labium.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: distinctive scat around the burrowing holes, which can be used to locate the nesting sites of this species. It hibernates from November to March in burrows about 10 centimeters deep.- Habitat: It is found in the upper intertidal zone of brackish water mudflats, especially in grassy areas with mudflats or under stones.- Food: It feeds on organic matter in the sediments around its burrows.- It lays elongated, transparent, agaric egg masses in summer. They can reach 30 to 35 centimeters in length and are estimated to lay up to about 10,000 eggs.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threat is coastal development by various construction projects (roads, shoreline improvements, seawalls, etc.).

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in coastal tidal flats with freshwater inflow in Gyeonggi-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, Jeollanam-do, North Jeolla-do, and Chungcheongnam-do - Distributed internationally in China and Japan.

name: Crassum soft coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is fan-shaped, with a thick bundle of branches. Depending on the substrate, the coloration varies, with the polyps yellowish-brown, the shaft brown, and the overall coloration light brown. The colony is about 11.5 cm tall and 3.3 cm wide, with branches 2.3 to 3.0 mm apart. The main branches are 4 to 5 millimeters in diameter, and the side branches and twigs are about 4.2 millimeters. The internal osseous shaft of the colony is cylindrical, hard, and composed of keratin with a slight lime content. The polyps are arranged about 2 mm apart in a sclerenchyma about 1.5 mm thick. The horizontal and convergent trabeculae are irregular and opaque. The polyps are arranged in three to four pairs of convergent polyps, with the upper two or three pairs arranged vertically and the lower two pairs arranged in an inclined manner.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: lives in waters 15 to 40 meters deep with fast currents - Food: feeds on small plankton and other prey using venomous spores - Ecological information on reproduction is scarce.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Changes in ocean temperatures (they live in turbulent waters) and slow growth rates are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters off the southern coast of Yeosu, Tongyeong, Busan, and Jeju Island; - International: Distributed in Sagami Bay, Japan.

name: Reticulated sea fan
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is fan-shaped, about 19 centimeters tall and 8 centimeters wide, and branches several times from a single main branch. The colony is red, the polyps are white, and the osseous shaft is dark brown, glossy on the underside and tan on top. The base is about 4.5 cm in diameter, the center is about 3.0 mm, the tip is about 2 mm, and the twigs are about 5.0 to 25.0 mm. The sclerenchyma is thick and the osseous shaft is rounded-cylindrical and elastic. The polyps are embedded in the malleolus, and the bone fragments are fusiform with a spiny protrusion at one end.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: lives in waters 15 to 40 meters deep with fast currents - Food: captures and eats small plankton and other prey using venomous spines - Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment, by spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats to this species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only on Jeju Island - International: Distributed in Japan, the Taurus Strait, and the Malay Peninsula.

name: European water spider
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body length is between 9 and 12 millimeters in males and 8 to 15 millimeters in females. The cephalothorax is longer than wide, with a high head area, and is bright yellow or reddish-brown in color. The eyes are arranged in two rows of eight sockets, and the large jaw has two posterior cephalic teeth. The median groove is indistinct, but the throat and radial grooves are distinct. The legs are yellowish-brown and hairy, and the hind legs have many spiny hairs on the calf and sole of the foot. The abdomen is grayish-brown with no special patterns. It's densely covered with short hairs to keep air bubbles on its body.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It breathes through air bubbles that surround its abdomen, and when it runs out of oxygen, it rises to the surface to replenish it and dives back into the water. It is the only spider that spends its entire life underwater.- Habitat: It builds bell-shaped air houses among aquatic vegetation in low-depth water such as marshes and ponds.- Food: It feeds on aquatic insects and nematodes.- Spawning and mating takes place in the air houses in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Changes in rainfall timing, intense rainfall, extreme drought, and plants that terrestrialize wetlands are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do - International: Distributed in Japan, China, Mongolia, Russia, Turkestan, the Caucasus, Iran, Central Asia, and Europe.

name: Chestnut soft coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The clump is somewhat flattened, 2.3 to 2.4 centimeters tall, 2.5 to 4 centimeters wide, and 2.3 to 2.5 centimeters thick, very similar in appearance to broccoli. The terminal branches and polyp heads are orange in color, with the tips of the polyp heads and the supporting xylem bundles being lighter in color. The main branch is grayish-white with a gray base, and the tentacles are red. The main branch is about 1.6 centimeters long and has 5 to 10 polyps on the most terminal twig. The polyp head is about 0.73 mm long and 0.66 mm wide, and the polyp stalk is about 1.5 mm long. The polyp base has small polyps, the primary convergent osteophytes protrude above the polyp head, and the lower convergent osteophytes are in pairs of 1 to 3. The supporting trabecular bundle is very well developed, protruding 1.5 to 2.0 mm above the polyp head and consisting of two to three fusiform trabeculae.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: forms colonies with other species of soft corals and has many internal and external symbionts, playing an important role in the ecosystem - Habitat: inhabits waters 5 to 25 meters deep with strong currents - Food: feeds on small plankton using venomous spores - Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on habitat conditions, by spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats to this species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island - International: Distributed in the Kii Peninsula, Oshima Peninsula, and Tanabe Bay, Japan.

name: Ceratophyta sea whip
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is secondarily branched, reaching a height of about 11.5 centimeters and a width of about 3.3 centimeters, and is fan-shaped. They are generally flat, but often branched and not quite flat. The color is bright red overall, with white tentacles and spines, and red polyps. Branches are branched at 2.3 to 3.0 mm intervals. The lateral branches are slender and elongated, and branch secondarily without adhesions. The main branch is 4.0 to 5.0 mm in diameter, the side branches are 1.5 to 2.0 mm, and the twigs are 1.3 to 1.5 mm. The sclerenchyma is thin, the osteoderm is firm, and the xylem is rounded-cylindrical. Low, hump-shaped stipules are arranged over the entire surface at 2.5 to 3.0 mm intervals on the main branches and in four rows on the terminal branches.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Very slow growth rate and lives in colonies. It has many internal and external symbionts and occupies an important place in the ecosystem.- Habitat: Attaches to rocks in waters 20 to 40 meters deep where currents are fast.- Food: Uses venomous spores to feed on small plankton.- Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island - International: Distributed in the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean near the Malay Peninsula.

name: Red-clawed crab
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a medium-sized species with a carapace about 3 centimeters long and 3.5 centimeters wide. The dorsal surface of the carapace is convex, with distinct grooves separating each zone, and a single, distinct tooth on the lateral margin. The pincers and forehead area are bright red, the fingertips are very pale yellowish-white, and the entire body is sometimes red. The outer surface of the forelegs is densely covered with small and large granular setae, and the inner surface is lined with large granular setae.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Easily confused with the hermit crab because of similarities in habitat, carapace shape, and coloration of the pincers.- Habitat: Lives on stone walls, hillsides, and grasslands in the lower reaches of small streams that flow into the sea.- Food: Omnivorous, feeding on insects, dead fish, and leaves.- Mates in May and June, and spawning individuals are found in June and July. It descends to shallow waters only during spawning season.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat conditions and habitat loss due to subdivision development are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed along the southwest coast of Korea, including Incheon Metropolitan City, Chungcheongnam-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, and Jeollanam-do, and on Jeju Island; - International: Distributed in Indonesia, Taiwan, China, and Japan.

name: Line brittle star
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is 3.8 to 6.8 mm in diameter and the arms are 13.2 to 22.5 mm long. The body is similar to that of a starfish, but this smaller species has a clear distinction between the body and arms. The pattern on the middle of the body and on the clypeus is dark chestnut, and the arms have dark chestnut bands. The body is covered with transparent spines with many forked tips, which are raised very high above the arms. The upper surface of the arms is shaped like a triangle with an outer bulge. The underside of the arms is shaped like a hexagon with a very bulging outer surface, with distinct concentric stripes. The sides of the arms are flush with each other at the top and bottom and have similar stripes to the ventral surface. There are 9 to 11 spines on the tip of each limb, each up to four times as long as the limb.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Habitat: Lives on rocks, algae, and coral reef communities from the intertidal zone to depths of 50 to 100 m. - Food: Eats small animals and plankton in the bottom environment of the ocean. - Sexual reproduction: produces free-swimming larvae that undergo several metamorphoses to become adults.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat area is the main threat.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is found only in the waters off Jeju Island.

name: Soft coral

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The cluster is thick, tree-like, and bisected. The cluster is about 8.8 cm tall, 9.4 cm wide, and 2.2 cm thick, with the sterile segments measuring about 1.7 cm long. The stem is bright yellow, the branches are yellow, the polyps are red, and the tentacles are colorless. Overall, the branches are cylindrical, and the base of the lowest branch is lobed. Polyp masses of 10 to 12 polyps are arranged on the tips of the thin branches. The polyp heads are about 3.3 mm long and 0.95 mm wide, and the polyp stalks are 0.43 to 0.56 mm long and stand at an obtuse angle. The base of the polyp is lined with small polyps. The primary convergent osteophytes protrude above the polyp head, and the lower convergent osteophytes are in pairs of three to four. The bundle of supporting osteophytes protrudes about 1 mm above the polyp head.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: colonizes with other species of soft corals and has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem- Habitat: inhabits waters 5 to 30 meters deep with strong currents- Food: uses venomous spores to feed on small plankton and other prey- Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
