name: Nodifila snail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Adults are 1.1 to 1.4 centimeters long and about 1.2 centimeters in diameter. The shell has tiny bumps on it that are shaped like beads, hence the name beadstones. The shell is shaped like a cone with a high spire, and originally has four layers, but as the spire wears away, only two or three layers remain. The sutures are not deep enough to distinguish the layers. The exterior of the carapace is bordered by bumps or spiracles, and the body layer has 11 rows of spiracles and 5 rows of spiracles. The globules are oval, with the outer surface curved by the spiracles, and the inner surface white. The cap is chitinous, tough and hard.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Depending on the habitat, the skin may be yellowish green, blackish brown, or reddish brown in color.- Habitat: Inhabits the upper reaches of streams with good water quality and somewhat deeper waters.- Food: Not much is known about the ecology of the beadlefish, but like other beadlefish, it feeds on attached algae on stones, organic matter deposited on the bottom, and aquatic vegetation.- It is known to spawn twice a year in February and July. Males and females spawn separately, and females have a spawning groove between the right head and leg.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are construction (aggregate extraction, beams, roads, bridges, etc.), disturbance of the water column by heavy rainfall, and overfishing for food.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is mainly distributed in central and northern Korean rivers, including the upper reaches of the Namhan River and the Hantan River.

name: Ulleungdo snail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is one of the largest terrestrial gastropods found on Ulleungdo, with a low cone-shaped body with 4.5 layers, measuring about 7 mm in height and 11 mm in diameter. The feet are broad and flat, and the body is highly elastic. The head has two pairs of tentacles, with eyes on the tips of the tentacles. A distinct growth vein runs longitudinally across the carapace, and in some individuals, a dark reddish-brown band runs along the growth vein. The eye sockets are semicircular, with a narrow, deep opening.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: snails are slow migrants, so if their habitat is destroyed, the snails in the area are at risk of extinction.- Habitat: inhabits woodland and shrubland near human settlements.- Food: herbivorous, feeding on mushrooms, mosses, berries, and wood.- Exact breeding and spawning seasons are unknown. They are hermaphroditic and spawn in shallow pits or under fallen leaves. The fertilized eggs are laid at once and development is direct.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat area, habitat development, pesticide use for crop cultivation, and weeding are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found throughout Ulleungdo Island.

name: Cribrose tree coral

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The clump is tree-like, with the largest clump being about 30 cm tall, 45 cm wide, and 30 cm thick, with an overall orange color. The branches are cylindrical, with a thickness of 21×16 mm at the base, 18×16 mm in the center, and 6×5 mm on the thin branches. The quaternary annulus near the isthmus wall is only vestigial, the costae are distinct, and the intercostal grooves are porous. The isthmus is 2-3 mm deep. In clumps, it can grow up to 5 meters wide or more.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: rarely found at depths of about 100 meters - Food: grabs plankton with its tentacles - Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on its environment, by spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats to this species are fishing ropes, damage from discarded fishing gear, indiscriminate harvesting during marine recreational activities, and seagrass blooms.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed mainly along the south and east coasts of Japan - International: Distributed in Tokyo Bay and Sagami Bay, Japan.

name: Alta heart urchin
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This is a medium-sized species with a shell that measures about 6.3 centimeters long, 2.7 centimeters high, and 5.5 centimeters wide. It has a convex dorsal surface and a flat ventral surface, and is almost oval from above, but slightly narrower at the back. The fascia narrows towards the end, and the fascial plates are arranged in a regular rectangular pattern. The scutes and intercostals are almost horizontal to the ventral surface. Unlike other sea urchins, their shape is not symmetrical and varies depending on the direction of view. It's brownish gray in color, with pale purple markings.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Little studied worldwide - Habitat: Lives from the subtidal zone to depths of about 200 m. - Food: feeds on algae and other organic matter. - Both eggs and sperm are released into the sea by in vitro fertilization to produce larvae, which live as plankton for several months before undergoing a rapid metamorphosis to become juvenile sea urchins.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Nacospatangus alta lives on sandy bottoms at low water depths, so the main threat to its habitat is habitat loss due to sand mining.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in the waters off Jeju Island (Seogwipo City) and Ulleungdo Island; - International: Found from Sagami Bay to Kagoshima Bay, Japan; Luzon, Arafura Sea, Sri Lanka, and the Indian Ocean in the Philippines.

name: Putter's soft coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is branched and flattened, tree-like, 5.8 to 7.3 cm tall, 4.2 to 6.2 cm wide, and 2.5 to 3.6 cm thick, with sterile segments 1.7 to 2.7 cm long. The polyps are blackish-red, the tentacles are red, the stem and branches are white, the base of the stem is grayish-white, and the tips of the twigs are yellow. At the ends of thin branches, 10 to 13 polyps form a single polyp mass, and the bases of lower branches are leaf-like. The polyp head is 0.99 to 1.04 mm long and 0.92 to 0.98 mm wide, and the polyp stalk is about 1 mm long. The primary convergent osteophytes protrude above the polyp head and are arranged in three to four pairs transversely. The ventral side of the polyp stalk has a dense, sloping arrangement of large osteophytes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Slow-growing, clusters with other soft corals, such as the giant scleractinian, black scleractinian, and the boulder. It has many internal and external symbionts and occupies an important position in the ecosystem.- Habitat: It lives in waters with fast currents at a depth of 5 to 20 meters.- Food: It feeds on small plankton using its venomous spores.- Reproduction: It reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Slow growth rate, marine development, marine pollution, and careless aquatic recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island and Tongyeong City, Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea - International: Distributed in Sagami Bay and Legazpi Bay, Philippines.

name: Ijimai tree coral

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A colony is a tree-like structure made up of cylindrical individuals clinging to each other. The largest colonies are about 12.5 centimeters tall, 3.8 centimeters wide, and 2.7 centimeters thick. The stomata are circular or oval in shape, ranging from 8.5×7.0 to 10.0×8.0 mm in diameter and 4.0 to 6.0 mm in length. The secondary isthmuses at the front and back of the branch are 7.5×6.5 to 8.0×6.5 mm in diameter and 5.0 to 8.0 mm long. The septa are arranged in a four-way arrangement, with the first and second septa having irregularly scattered bumps on their sides, while the third and fourth septa are very small. The costal bones of the isthmus are covered with granular projections, and the grooves of the intercostal veins are lined with small projections.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: lives in waters 15 to 40 meters deep with fast currents - Food: uses poisonous spores to feed on small plankton - Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment, by spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island - International: Distributed in Japan, the Philippines, Fiji Island, Murai Island, and the Red Sea.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is completely planar and feathery, 15.5 to 16.0 cm tall and 10.5 to 20.0 cm wide. They are whitish in color, but brownish below the trunk and glossy bright yellow above. The twigs are 20 to 35 millimeters long, with 14 to 17 twigs arranged in opposite directions. The sclerenchyma is thin, and the xylem is flattened but calcareous and hard. The stems and branches have 11 to 13 cylindrical polyps on each side of the stem and branches, arranged in rows, with overlapping lamellae.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem - Habitat: attaches to rocks between 50 and 100 meters deep - Food: feeds on small plankton using venomous spores - Reproduces asexually or sexually by spawning, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island - International: Distributed in Sagami Bay and Okino Island, Japan.

name: Korean land snail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The shell is about 2.3 centimeters in diameter and 1.6 centimeters high, with a low, conical shape and about 1.8 centimeters square. The color of the shell varies from off-white, yellowish brown, and reddish brown, but is usually reddish brown. The body layer is large and rounded, with dense irregular growth veins on all layers except the carapace keratinization layer. The cloaca is narrow and deep, slightly obscured by the axial row of corneae. The clypeus is semicircular, and the edge of the clypeus in adults is thickened and weakly set back. The medial labium has traces of a weak live layer.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Due to the lack of public interest and few researchers, the species has not been surveyed and is in urgent need of protection.- Habitat: It lives in moist shrubland in forests, often under trees or on trees.- It is hermaphroditic, meaning that fertilized eggs are laid at one time and development is direct. They mate with other individuals and exchange sperm to fertilize their eggs. Little else is known about their ecology.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat area, habitat development, pesticide use for crop cultivation, and weeding are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and lives mainly on Hongdo Island in Sinan-gun, Jeollanam-do. It is mostly observed in the vicinity of human settlements and fields on Hongdo Island.

name: Complex sea fan
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The colony is fan-shaped, about 11 centimeters tall and 8.5 centimeters wide. The colony is dark red overall, the polyps are white, and the bony shaft is glossy brown on the underside and yellowish white on the top. The tentacles and osteophytes are colorless, while the polyps and stem sheaths are red. Branches staggered from the main branch, and the branches are straight, not sticking together. Branches first emerge from the stem at a height of about 7 mm, branching at right angles and growing parallel to the stem. Lateral branches are slender and long, spreading from side to side, parallel to each other, about 5 mm apart. Short twigs, 2 to 20 millimeters long, emerge from the lateral branches. The stem is about 3 mm in diameter, the main branch is about 2 mm, and the twigs are about 1.5 mm. The sclerenchyma is thin, the trunk is cylindrical and elastic, and the polyps are arranged 1.0 to 2.0 mm apart over the entire surface. The sclerenchyma has a spinous projection at one end.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The colony is composed of tetrapods, also called moss worms, and annelids, such as midges. It has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem.- Habitat: Attaches to rocks in waters 10 to 40 meters deep with strong currents.- Food: Uses venomous spores to feed on small plankton.- Reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters of Jeju Island (Seogwipo City) - International: Distributed in Japan, the Indian Ocean, and Pacific New Guinea.

name: Zeongog gammarid
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The body is about 12 mm long, flattened from side to side, with an overall light brown coloration. The first digit is slightly longer than half the body length. The hairs on the fourth and fifth digits of the second digit are very short and sparse, and the whip digits have calceoli (disk or cup-shaped sensory organs). The first digit is similar to that of the common lobster, and the second digit has one spine in the center of the palm and three spines on the distal end of the palm. The third and fourth tergites have long bristles, while the fifth through seventh tergites have no bristles and only spines. Both the inner and outer margins of the third digit have feathery setae, and the inner digit is about half the length of the outer digit.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: An important species as an indicator species for water quality conditions in freshwater ecosystems.- Habitat: Lives under stones in clear water with slow flow in mountain streams or under submerged broadleaf deciduous trees.- Food: Gnaws on decaying leaves.- Mates between March and June. Females are physiologically specialized to fertilize their eggs after molting. This causes the male to exhibit a behavior of holding onto the female until she molts.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Limited habitat area and habitat development are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed in Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do. Its native range has been destroyed by development.

name: Japanese black coral
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The largest individuals are about 125 centimeters tall, 100 centimeters wide, and 9 centimeters thick, with a diameter of about 2 centimeters at the base of the trunk. It has a pine-like appearance, with flat branches that overlap to form a large twig. The color of the trunk varies, but it is mostly white, with dark brown trunk and white polyps and sclerenchyma with milky spots. The twigs are 10 to 22 mm long, but the overall branch length varies. The phloem branches off the twigs at an angle of 45 to 55°, almost horizontal to the plane of the coral colony. The secondary branches branch anteriorly and laterally at 45° or more from the trunk, then extend horizontally and curve back upward at their tips. On all sides of the trunk, there are five rows of spines measuring 165×45 to 255×65 μm. The distance between the spines is about 45 to 120 micrometers, and the spines are curved, concave at the distal end, convex at the base, and slightly concave at the tip. On older parts of the axis, the spines are finer, sharper, and more branched. The polyps are located at right angles to one side of the branch.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It has many internal and external symbionts and occupies an important place in the ecosystem - Habitat: Distributed in waters around 15 meters deep with fast currents - Food: It feeds on small plankton using its venomous spores - Reproduction: It reproduces asexually or sexually, depending on the habitat environment, by spawning.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in the waters off Jeju Island and Gyeongsangnam-do; - International: Distributed in Sagami Bay and Enoshima, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Milky fiddler crab
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The carapace is about 9 mm long and 14 mm wide, trapezoidal in shape, wide at the front and narrow at the back. The dorsal surface of the carapace is grayish in color, with a blackish pattern. The forehead is wide, about 1/8 of the width of the carapace. The belly has seven segments in both sexes. In males, the claws are much larger on one side than the other, sometimes reaching more than twice the width of the carapace, and the outer surface of the large claw is smooth and free of bumps. The female's claws are smaller and symmetrical.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It has very keen eyesight and hides in its burrow when an intruder approaches. Males will vigorously wave their pincers, and females will judge the size and motion of a male's pincers to determine his health and suitability as a mate.- Habitat: Lives in vertical burrows in sandy, muddy bottoms in the upper intertidal zone of tidal marshes.- Food: It feeds on organic matter in the mud.- Breeds in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threats are habitat loss and fragmentation due to tidal flats development, and reduced genetic diversity due to habitat fragmentation.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in tidal flats along the southwestern coast of Australia - International: Distributed in Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, New Guinea, and Samoa.

name: White soft coral

Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: About 3.8 cm tall, 4.8 cm wide, and 1.8 cm thick, the body is flattened into a bifurcated, tree-like shape. The body is cream-colored, and the trunk is colorless. New branches emerge from the split twigs. At the ends of the twigs are arranged 7 to 10 polyps, the polyp head is 0.8 to 1.0 mm long, 0.7 to 0.9 mm wide, and the polyp stalk is 1.46 to 1.61 mm long. The base of the polyp contains smaller polyps. The primary convergent osteophytes project above the polyp head, and the lower convergent osteophytes are 4 to 6 pairs. The bundle of supporting osteophytes protrudes 0.73 to 1.32 millimeters above the polyp head. The ventral side of the polyp stalk has a dense, sloping arrangement of small accessory osteophytes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is a slow grower and lives in colonies with other species of soft corals. It has many internal and external symbionts, making it an important part of the ecosystem.- Habitat: Lives at depths of 15 to 30 meters in areas with strong currents.- Food: It feeds on small plankton using its venomous spores.- Reproduction: Asexual or sexual, depending on the environment.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Rising sea temperatures, ocean pollution, and careless water recreation are the main threats.

extra_sections.title: Source

extra_sections.title: Distribution

name: Japanese lady's slipper
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designations of 1996
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation Act of 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Grows up to 40 cm tall and roots from nodes on laterally extending underground stems. The main stem is 20 to 40 centimeters tall, hairy, with two large leaves at the top that are opposite, completely enclosing the stem and spreading in all directions, and 10 to 22 centimeters in diameter. From April to June, white to red flowers appear, one at the end of each stem, pointing downward. The flowers are about 8 centimeters in diameter. The peduncle is about 15 centimeters long and hairy, with a single leaf-like bract at the top. The fruit is a drupe, long and oval.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: It has the largest and most colorful flowers among the orchid family plants native to Korea. It is difficult to transplant and cultivate because it is symbiotic with a specific fungus in the soil. -Habitat: It is a perennial grass that lives in well-drained soil in mountain forests at 300 to 1,100 meters above sea level, and is found in semi-sound places with a well-developed understory and understory. It thrives in well-nourished, humusy soils and has a dormant underground habit, so the aboveground population fluctuates from year to year. Currently, some habitats are fenced to protect them. - Blooms from April to June, fruiting from July to August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Indiscriminate harvesting for ornamental purposes, habitat destruction and low fruiting rates, coupled with limited habitat conditions and ecological sensitivity to environmental change, have led to population declines. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered on the National Red List and Endangered on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Only small populations have been identified in parts of Gyeonggi-do, Gangwon-do, Chungcheongbuk-do, Jeollabuk-do, and Jeollanam-do; - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Brown-spotted gastrochilus
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are white and the stems are very short, 1 to 3 centimeters long. The leaves are narrow, long-oval, opposite, and thickly fleshed, with purple spots on both sides. It bears 1 to 4 light yellow-green flowers with purple spots at the ends of long peduncles extending from the leaf axils. The fruit is a drupe, obovate in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: It is a southern plant, and the southern coast of Korea is the northern limit of its distribution - Habitat: It is an evergreen perennial herb that is found in warm, moist forests. It is an epiphytic orchid that grows attached to trees, especially birch, maple, and pine trees.- It blooms in April and May and fruits in June and July.
					
					-Blooms in April and May, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to its very narrow distribution range, occupied area, and indiscriminate harvesting, it is very difficult to identify natural individuals. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number of individuals are known from extremely restricted habitats on Jeju Island and parts of the south coast of Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea; - International: Distributed in subtropical climates in Japan, Taiwan, and China.

name: Nara orchid
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Greenish aerial roots extend from the bottom of the stem. The stems are very short and are rarely observed. It has 3 to 6 rather thick, long elliptical leaves that hang unequally. The leaves are 8 to 15 centimeters long and 1.5 to 2.5 centimeters wide, with veins on the surface. The 4 to 10 light white-green flowers are borne in racemes, the peduncles are 5 to 12 centimeters long and emerge from the sides, and the petals are 0.4 to 0.5 centimeters long and egg-shaped. The side petals are small, and the lip petals are obovate-wedge-shaped with comb-like teeth, and have light red spots along with the side petals. The pedicels are barrel-shaped and bend forward. The fruit is a drupe, long and oval.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: Fragrant and beautiful flowers, evergreen leaves, and epiphytic habit make it a highly valued ornamental plant. It is considered difficult to propagate naturally in the wild due to difficulty germinating seeds.- Habitat: Evergreen perennial herb, epiphytic plant that grows on the outside of trees and rocks.- Blooms June through August, fruiting September through October.
					
					-Blooms from June to August and fruits from September to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: It is believed to be locally extinct due to habitat destruction by tourism, indiscriminate collection, and low fruiting rates. It is currently assessed as Regionally Extinct (RE) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: There are records of its distribution on Jeju Island and islands off the south coast, including Gageo Island, Daegeoksan Island, Hongdo Island, and Bogil Island, but there have been no observations in recent decades. It is believed to have been lost due to indiscriminate collection, and some artificially propagated individuals have been restored on Jeju Island.- Overseas: Distributed in East Asia, including China and Japan.

name: Japanese euchresta
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022

Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Grows to a height of 30 to 60 centimeters. The roots are slightly thick at the base, and the stems grow at an angle at the bottom. The leaves are 3-lobed, elliptical to obovate, dark green with dull edges, 5 to 8 centimeters long and 3 to 5 centimeters wide, rounded at the ends. The leaves have light brown hairs on the back and are whitish. The flowers are white, borne in racemes at the ends of the stems. The fruit is a drupe that looks like a drupe, does not open when ripe, is oval in shape, and ripens black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It was first discovered in Korea in 1970 and was named by combining the end of the discoverer's name (Kim Im-man) and the word 'year' meaning evergreen.- Habitat: It is an evergreen semi-deciduous tree that blooms in spring and lives in evergreen forests in valleys with little sunlight on the northern slopes of mountains. It is most often found in humus-rich soil around rocks with high air humidity. - Blooms in May and June and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by its narrow geographic range and habitat destruction due to tourism. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A very small number of individuals are known from the valley around Seogwipo City, Jeju Island, and some adjacent sites; - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Japanese thrixspermum
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The aerial roots are slender and long. The stems are 3 to 10 centimeters long and enveloped in a silky leaf sheath. The 10 to 20 long, elliptical or lanceolate leaves are 2 to 4 centimeters long and are arranged in two rows. The light yellow flowers are borne in clusters of 2 to 5 at the end of the peduncle. The flower stalk is slender and the lip petals are shallowly 3-parted. The peduncle is 2 to 4 centimeters long. The fruit is a drupe, obovate in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Jeju Island is the northern limit of its distribution - Habitat: An evergreen perennial herb that lives in evergreen forests including birch trees. It is usually found on old-growth trees in forests with high air humidity on the south slope at an altitude of 250~350 meters above sea level.- It blooms in April/May and fruits in June/July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to its extremely limited geographic distribution and occupied area, and indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes, it is currently assessed as Endangered (EN) in the National Red List of Threatened species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Formerly distributed around Jeju Island, including Hallasan Mountain, but the largest population was confirmed to have disappeared in 2012-2013, and the population has been declining every year, so there are only a few populations in Korea.- International: Distributed in China, Japan, etc.

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems up to 5 centimeters tall, growing recumbent and clustered in bunches like cushions. The leaves are leathery, obovate, 0.7 to 1.5 cm long and 0.3 to 0.5 cm wide, with dull edges, and slightly wrapped around the stem below the petiole. The flowers are white, borne in clusters at the end of the peduncle, with a deeply five-pronged edge and about 1.5 centimeters in diameter. The sepals are oblong-oval, with 5 yellow stamens at the end of the pedicel. The fruit is a drupe, surrounded by sepals and split into 3 parts, about 0.3 cm in diameter.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: It is the world's shortest growing tree. It is considered to be the southern limit of its global distribution.- Habitat: Evergreen small trembling tree, native to high mountains. It is widely scattered on the steep slopes of the north and west slopes of Hallasan Mountain in Jeju Island above 1,700 meters above sea level. It is known to grow in places with low insolation and abundant moisture. - It blooms in May and June and fruits in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by a very restricted geographic distribution, climate change, habitat loss due to rock weathering, and indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes, the species is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only on rocks and among boulders on the summit of Hallasan Mountain, Jeju Island, Korea - International: Distributed in the alpine regions of China, Japan, and the Russian boreal zone.

name: Lance-leaf cymbidium
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are white, linear, and thick. The leaves are 1 to 3 leaves, emerging from near the roots, long elliptical, 6 to 15 centimeters long and 2 to 4 centimeters wide. The leaf tips are finely toothed, pointed, and petiole-like at the base. Flower stalks are 7 to 20 centimeters long; flowers are pale grassy white, 2 to 6 in racemes; lip petals are 1.5 to 2 centimeters long and 0.7 to 1 centimeter wide, white with purplish-brown spots. The fruit is a drupe, long oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Although endangered in the wild, it is not known to be difficult to propagate in tissue culture or by cuttings. However, its highly ornamental flowers have led to indiscriminate collection, even in restored areas.- Habitat: An evergreen perennial herb that grows in slightly shaded areas at the edge of evergreen broadleaf forests at elevations up to 600 meters. It lives in environments with relatively good humus formation and a low density of herbaceous plants.- Blooms in July and August and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate harvesting and a very limited geographic range. It is also considered endangered in China and Japan, and is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the national Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Inhabits the adjacent valleys around Seogwipo City, Jeju Island, Korea, where the total population is currently estimated at only 20 individuals. - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, Thailand, and Malaysia.

name: Spotted lady's slipper
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem extends laterally and roots emerge from the nodes. The stem grows straight up to about 30 centimeters. The stems have 2 to 3 leaflets at the base and are long and hairy. The leaves are broadly elliptical, 2 to 3 opposite, wrapped around the stem, with hairs on the back and edges of the leaves. The flowers are borne 1 at the end of the stem and are white with reddish-purple spots. The upper sepals are ovate, and the lateral sepals are united to form an ellipse with two tips. The lip petals are pouch-like and hairy on the inside. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Mainly native to the high mountains of northern Gangwon Province, but also includes individuals transplanted through artificial propagation in the past. The species in the northern part of Gangwon Province and North Korea were treated as endemic to Korea, but are now considered to be the same species as those in Japan and China.- Habitat: It is a perennial grass that grows in forests and grasslands at high altitudes, including high mountains. It lives in alpine areas at an altitude of 1,000 to 1,400 meters above sea level, but at lower altitudes in high latitudes, and grows in clusters in sunny forests where the understory or understory is not developed.- It blooms in June and July and fruits in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by habitat destruction due to indiscriminate harvesting and tourism, it is currently rated Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Very rare in grasslands and forests at high mountain altitudes in parts of Gangwon-do, Korea - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Russia.

name: Wind orchid

2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are white, thick, and long. The stem is short with a leaf sheath at the base. The leaves are lanceolate, opposite, bending backwards, 2.5 to 10 centimeters long and 0.6 to 1 centimeter wide, thick, and V-shaped in cross-section. The flowers are white, borne in clusters of 3 to 5 at the ends of flower stalks that emerge from the lower leaf axils. The sepals and petals are lanceolate and about 1 cm long. The pedicels are bent forward and 3.5 to 5 cm long. The fruit is a drupe, cylindrical in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is indiscriminately harvested for its fragrant flowers. It is distributed throughout the southern part of its range but occupies a much smaller area in each habitat.- Habitat: Evergreen perennial herb that grows on rocks and trees. It is found in places that are well ventilated and easy to obtain aerial humidity. It is mostly found on cliffs and trees along the coast in the southern part of the country.- Flowering in July and August and fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by indiscriminate collection, tourism, and vegetation change in its habitat, it is currently listed as Endangered (EN) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed on Jeju Island and along the southern coast. It is found from Gagae-do, Sinan-gun, Jeollanam-do in the west to Geoje Island, Gyeongsangnam-do in the east. Currently, it is only found in some limited areas - Overseas: Distributed in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Halla edelweiss
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Grows up to 10 to 15 centimeters tall. The stems are erect and covered with grayish-white downy hairs. The leaves that emerge from the root are spatulate and the leaves on the stem are long elliptical, with white hairs on both sides of the leaf, especially on the back. The flowers are yellowish-white, borne at the ends of the stems in clusters of 5 to 9 whole flowers, which form a head-shaped inflorescence, and 5 to 8 of these head-shaped inflorescences form a spike. The flower petals are oval, leaf-like, and covered with white hairs on both sides. The fruit is an achene with bumps on the surface.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Because it is distributed in an isolated form in alpine areas, its distribution range may shrink due to environmental changes such as climate change, and the success rate of introduction through restoration is considered to be low.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb that lives above 1,500 meters above sea level and inhabits steep rocky areas and grassy areas on the southern slopes of Baekrokdam in Hallasan Mountain.- Flowering in June and fruiting in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has a very limited habitat distribution and is threatened by climate change, landslides caused by weathering, and illegal harvesting. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: -National: Endemic to Korea, with a small number of individuals found in rocky areas above 1,500 meters above sea level in the Halla Mountains.

name: Cold-growing cymbidium
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
2017 Endangered Wildlife Class I designation
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are white and thick; the leaves are linear, with a sharp tip, 20 to 60 centimeters long and 0.5 to 1.5 centimeters wide, leathery, with dull edges. The flowers are borne in racemes of 3 to 12 flowers on stalks 20 to 50 cm long. The flowers are fragrant and usually light green, but there is a lot of color variation, including red and purple. The fruit is a drupe, long and oval, 4 to 5 centimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: This plant is called kanran because it blooms in winter. It is similar to the bochun flower, but differs in having blunt leaf edges and 5 to 12 flowers at the end of the flower stalk. Jeju Island's Hanran and Jeju Sanghyo Island's Hanran are designated as natural monuments.- Habitat: An evergreen perennial herb that grows on the slopes of valleys in or around evergreen broadleaf forests at around 200 meters above sea level in slightly shaded places.- Blooms from October to December and fruits from January to March of the following year.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Cymbidium kanran is a species that is difficult to observe due to the fact that most of its habitat is adjacent to valleys, which are often damaged by typhoons and heavy rains, and indiscriminate collection. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in parts of Jeju Island and Jeollanam-do; - International: Found in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Korean lychnis
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems are upright, 50 to 100 centimeters tall, with hairs that curve downward. The leaves are glandular-lanceolate, 5 to 11 centimeters long and 6 to 12 millimeters wide, with a pointed tip and fine hairs on the leaf margins. The red flowers are borne in umbellate inflorescences at the ends of the stems. The sepals are cylindrical, 2.0 to 2.5 centimeters long, with a five-pronged tip and long hairs on the edges. The fruit is a drupe, cylindrical, about 1.4 centimeters long, with a thick sack. The seeds are bean-shaped and have a rough exterior.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Compared to violets, the leaves are glandular-lanceolate and the peduncles are distinguished by the presence of fine hairs. It is a globally rare plant distributed only in Korea and Japan, and even in Japan, there are only two habitats.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb and lives in sunny wetlands in the mountains.- It blooms in July and August and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species lives in mountainous wetlands, and its habitat is being degraded or lost due to land reclamation for development projects and overuse by tourists. It is not currently assessed for the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to be distributed in Gangwon-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, Chungcheongnam-do, and Incheon metropolitan area, but a small number of individuals are currently found in parts of Busan, South Korea - International: Distributed in Japan.

name: Fox nut
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designations of 1996
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation Act of 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is short and bears many bearded roots. The submerged leaves are small, arrow-shaped, and hairless. The above-water leaves are circular, 20 to 120 centimeters in diameter, glossy and wrinkled on the upper surface and blackish-red on the back. There are many spines on the petioles and many spines on both sides of the leaf. It bears a single bright purple flower, 4 cm in diameter, at the end of a spiny peduncle, which opens during the day and closes at night. The fruit is a berry, oval or round, 5 to 7 centimeters long, with a pointed calyx at the end and spines.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It lives in areas where water depths are maintained at 1.5 meters, usually in places where there is no water flow. It does not emerge at depths greater than 1.5 meters because the light intensity decreases rapidly, making it difficult for seeds to germinate. It is a completely independent species in 1 genus and 1 species - Habitat: A submersed annual herb that lives in water and is found in old ponds, reservoirs, and swamps - Flowering in August and September and fruiting in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is highly vulnerable to habitat loss due to wetland development and pollution. It is also vulnerable to competition from other plant species. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) in the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Widespread throughout the country, but recent habitat loss has been severe - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, and India.

name: Siberian ginseng
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are grayish-white and densely covered with needle-like spines. The leaves are opposite, palmately compound with 5 small leaves and serrated at the edges. The flowers are male and bisexual, yellowish-white in color, borne in umbellate inflorescences of several flowers, forming a rounded ball. There are 5 petals, stamens, and pistils each. The fruit is a drupe, black in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Highly overfished due to its medicinal use. It is distinguished by the large number of spines on its stem compared to other species.- Habitat: It is a deciduous quaking tree, cold and sound resistant and lives in deep mountainous areas under the shade of moist trees with good drainage, especially on the rim of valleys.- It flowers in July and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is used for medicinal purposes and is overharvested. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly distributed in the Baekdu-daegan region, including parts of Gyeongsangbuk-do, Chungcheongbuk-do, and the northern part of Gangwon-do; - International: Distributed in Northeast China, the Russian Far East, and Hokkaido, Japan.

name: Pygmy water lily
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is thick and short, with many roots that extend in all directions. The horseshoe-shaped leaves emerge from the roots in several sheets, split into arrows, float on the water, and are 2 to 6 centimeters long and 2 to 5 centimeters wide. The petioles are long and the leaf margins have indistinct serrations. The plant has single white flowers at the end of long peduncles that emerge from the roots, and the flowers are about 3 centimeters in diameter. The sepals are four long, oval pieces, about 1.5 centimeters long, with a pointed tip. The 10 or so lanceolate petals are arranged in two rows and are about 1.5 centimeters long. The fruit is a drupe, spherical, with calyx traces.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is considered to be relatively vulnerable to changes in the wetland environment. It has also been found in Gunsan-si, Jeollabuk-do, but it is believed to be a small water lily. The pistil head is yellow compared to the red water lily, and the leaves are the smallest among Korean water lily plants.- Habitat: It is a perennial epiphytic plant that roots in ponds and swamps with a depth of about 1 meter.- It blooms from May to July and fruits from July to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by habitat destruction due to the reclamation of wetlands for agricultural expansion or by visitors, as well as by its narrow geographic range and indiscriminate collection. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to the Korean Peninsula, distributed only in North Korea and South Korea. In Korea, it is found in Goseong-gun, Gangwon-do.

name: Gilva oak
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It grows up to 20 to 30 meters tall, and its branches are covered with tan hairs. The leaves are opposite, lanceolate, 5 to 12 centimeters long, and leathery. The leaf surface is glossy, and the back is densely covered with tan star-shaped hairs, with sharp teeth on the upper edge of the leaf. The petioles are about 1 centimeter long and hairy. The male inflorescence is dioecious, 5 to 16 centimeters long, borne at the base of newly emerging branches and drooping downward. The female inflorescence is about 1 cm long, borne in the leaf axils above the new branches. The entire inflorescence is hairy. The fruit is a nut, about 2 centimeters long and oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: new growth on the branches, petioles, and backs of the leaves is covered with tan hairs compared to other evergreen oaks native to the country.- Habitat: evergreen tall tree, living in evergreen forests at lower elevations below 350 meters above sea level. It is found in areas with a high percentage of exposed rocks and poor soil development.- It blooms in April and May and bears fruit from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Highly threatened by habitat fragmentation and degradation and vulnerable to competition from other trees. It is currently assessed as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: distributed in Jeju Island - International: distributed in southern China, Japan, Taiwan, etc.

name: Sea milkwort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are thick, lateral, and erect, 5 to 20 centimeters tall. The leaves are opposite, lanceolate, bluntly margined, and 0.6 to 1.5 centimeters long. The bright red flowers are borne single in leaf axils and have very short peduncles. There are no petals, and the sepals are deeply divided into five, giving the appearance of petals. One pistil and five stamens protrude from the flower. The fruit is a drupe, round and hairless.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Lives in places with high sand content in the soil. It appears along the east coast and lives in places affected by salty seawater. Its habitat is threatened by the construction of a coastal promenade, and in Ulsan, South Korea, its habitat has been damaged by the construction of a coastal deck.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb and lives in marshes in lagoons adjacent to the coast or in contact with seawater.- Flowering in May and June and fruiting in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened with habitat loss due to coastal pollution from littering by visitors, development of coastal roads and tourist attractions, and landfills. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: distributed along the east coast of Gangwon-do and Gyeongsang-do - International: relatively widely distributed in China, Japan, Russia, Europe, the United States, and Canada.

name: Interrupted cyclosorus
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Cyclosorus interruptus is 50 to 100 centimeters tall with a black underground stem that extends laterally and is 4 to 6 millimeters in diameter. The petioles are 20 to 50 centimeters long, brown with a black base. The leaves are uniseriate, deeply divided, 30 to 50 centimeters long, and somewhat leathery. The petioles are ligulate but fall off when mature. The stipules are 20 to 30 pairs, short-petiolate, glandular-lanceolate, 5 to 15 centimeters long and 1 to 1.5 centimeters wide. The back of the conidia has yellowish-brown glandular hairs. The sporangiophore clusters are attached to the margins of the conidia, and the perithecium is horseshoe-shaped with hairy margins.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The common name is derived from the black color of the underground stem and base of the petioles, as well as the spores, which turn somewhat black when the leaves wither.- Habitat: Evergreen, perennial ferns that colonize coastal and adjacent wetland areas.- Spore season is July through October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The threats to this species are the development of its habitat and its extremely limited distribution area. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) in the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Limited to coastal wetlands of Jeju Island, Korea - International: Distributed throughout tropical, subtropical, and temperate regions of the world, including China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Hooded neottianthe
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Neottianthe cucullata is 10 to 25 centimeters tall and has a root system of rounded tuberous roots and fleshy bearded roots. The leaves that emerge from the roots are 2 to 3 leaves, elliptical or lanceolate, 3 to 6 centimeters long and 1 to 3 centimeters wide. The stems are erect and bear 5 to 25 flowers in lopsided racemes. The flowers are pink in color and the petals are linear with a pointed tip. The lip petals have purple spots on the outside and are three-pronged at the tip. The cones are bent forward. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: geographically occupies a remarkably small area, and is expected to shrink or decline as the alpine environment changes under the influence of climate change.- Habitat: a perennial grass that lives in high mountain meadows or under saline forests.- Blooms from July to September, fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by shrinking geographic range due to climate change and habitat loss due to overharvesting and tourism. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Limited to relatively high mountains such as Gaya Mountain, Jirisan Mountain, Deoksansan Mountain, and Deoksansan Mountain in southern Gangwon-do Province, including Baekdu Daegan Mountain.

name: Arctic starflower
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems are erect, 5 to 20 centimeters tall. A white threadlike underground stem extends from it, bearing scaly leaves at the base of the stem and a cluster of 5 to 10 leaves at the top. The leaves are thin, broadly lanceolate, elliptical, or egg-shaped, 2 to 7 centimeters long and 1 to 2.5 centimeters wide. The flowers are white, borne in 1 to 2 clusters at the end of the stem, either in a raceme or deeply divided into 5 to 9 leaflets. The fruit is a drupe, rounded in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This boreal plant is restricted to alpine areas in Korea, where it grows in clusters. There are more than 20 habitats, but it is found in small numbers. It is common in the world but rare in Korea.- Habitat: It is a perennial grass that grows in high mountain wetlands and shady rocks in shrubby areas with little humus layer and very shallow soil core.- It blooms in June and July and fruits in August and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Although its habitat is in national parks, some of its habitat is adjacent to hiking trails, and it is threatened by anthropogenic disturbance, such as entry into its habitat and illegal harvesting. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: distributed in Gangwon-do and Gyeongsang-do - International: distributed in Japan, Sakhalin, eastern Siberia, and North America.

name: Shield sundew
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It has an underground, rounded tuber. The leaves from the roots die off when the plant flowers, and the stems are straight and 10 to 40 centimeters tall. The leaves on the stem are crescent-shaped, 2 to 3 mm long and 4 to 6 mm wide, with petioles 8 to 17 mm long. The leaves have long glandular hairs that secrete a mucus that catches insects. The flowers are white, 1.0 to 1.5 centimeters in diameter, borne in racemes at the ends of the stems or in umbels against the leaves. They have five petals, five stamens, and three pistils. The fruit is a drupe, rounded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Unlike the sticky spatula, this plant has a stem 10 to 40 centimeters tall. It captures insects with mucus from long glandular hairs on its leaves, which it slowly digests and absorbs with its digestive juices.- Habitat: A perennial carnivorous plant, it lives in clusters in coastal fields or meadows around sunny marshes in low coastal mountains, especially in well-groomed graves.- Flowering from April to June and fruiting from July to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to its carnivorous nature, it is overharvested and threatened by habitat destruction. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Biological Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rarely distributed in coastal mountain grasslands along the coast of Jeollanam-do and Busan, South Korea - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, Australia, New Zealand, and Southeast Asia.

name: Korean kirengeshoma
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Designations of 1998
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designations of 1996
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation Act of 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: 30 to 100 centimeters tall with a thick underground stem that extends laterally. Leaves are opposite, oval or circular, palmately lobed, and shallowly divided. Flowers are yellow, borne in racemes of 1 to 5 at the ends of stems and branches. Calyx is bell-shaped with a 5-pointed tip, and petals are 2 to 4 centimeters long. There are 15 stamens and 3 to 4 pistils. The fruit is a drupe, about 1.5 centimeters in diameter and round.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is also known as the horse horse because of its resemblance in height and leaf shape to the horse horse of the family Buttercup, which is used for medicinal purposes.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb, rarely found in the valleys around 800 meters above sea level in southern regions. It grows in high soil moisture under typical temperate southern broadleaf forests. - Blooms in July and August and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species prefers outcross fertilization, so individuals of the same genotype do not produce seeds together, and the flowering season is in July, which is affected by the rainy season. It is severely threatened by anthropogenic disturbance and habitat loss by tourists. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List and the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to the Korean Peninsula, with a limited distribution in Baekunsan, Jeollanam-do and Sancheong-gun, Gyeongsangnam-do, and is also found in North Korea. Recently, a wide range has been confirmed at 1,000 meters on Jirisan Mountain.

name: Siberian lily
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It is usually 60 to 90 centimeters tall, but can grow up to 1.5 meters, with narrow wings on the stem. The underground scaly stems are white, rounded, and 3 to 5 centimeters in diameter. There is an annulus in the upper center of the stem, from which branches extend laterally. The lanceolate leaves are 5 to 12 centimeters long, petiolate, and run opposite the stem, with 3 to 5 leaf veins and a margin. The flowers are red and bloom upward at the end of the stem; they have six petals, 7 to 8 centimeters long, spreading at an angle and tipping back slightly at the tip. They have purple spots centered on the inside of the flower. The fruit is a drupe, narrowly obovate.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: tends to decline easily when shrub beds develop or competing plants are introduced. The large, showy, skyward flowers are highly prized for their ornamental value and are subject to overfishing.- Habitat: A perennial herb, found on mountain ridges up to 1,400 meters above sea level.- Flowers in June and July, fruiting in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: is threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed in some alpine areas of Gangwon-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and Jeolla-do - Internationally: Distributed in China, Japan, Russia, and North Korea.

name: Wonder violet
conservation_history: Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Grows up to 30 centimeters tall. In early spring it appears stemless, but after the flowers have faded, a leafy stem develops. The primary stem enlarges after flowering and is hairless. The rounded, heart-shaped leaves are 2 to 4 centimeters long, clustered at the root, with wavy serrations on the edges and hairs on the leaf veins. The light purple flowers are borne at the ends of the stems and have closed petals that do not open. The sepals are narrowly ovate and dull. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: A perennial grass that lives in relatively sunny places at the bottom of deciduous forests in the mountains. It blooms from April to May.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: In Korea, it is found in limestone areas of Gangwon-do and Chungcheongbuk-do. Globally, it is distributed in China, Japan, Mongolia, and Russia.

name: Rhododendron aureum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Grows to a height of about 1 m. Leaves are borne on the stem, opposite, long elliptical, 3 to 10 cm long and 1 to 3 cm wide, glossy leathery, with dull edges and slightly curled back. Flowers are borne in clusters of 2 to 10 at the ends of the branches, yellowish-white, in racemes of 5-parted margins. The flower diameter is 1.5 to 3.0 cm, and the peduncle is 2.5 to 3.5 cm long. There are 10 stamens and 1 pistil. The fruit is a drupe, narrowly oval with a long pistil at the end.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: shorter in stature than the rhododendron, and can be recognized by the absence of brown hairs on the back of the leaves - Habitat: evergreen, quaking tree, found in sunny shrubby forests in alpine regions above 1,600 meters - Flowering in May and June, fruiting in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Habitats along hiking trails are threatened by degradation and exposed to the effects of extreme climate change. Competition from neighboring plants is also a threat. It's currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: There are records of observations on Mount Taebaek in the past, but it is currently restricted to Gangwon Province. - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Russia.

name: Korean iris
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are long, slender, laterally extending, glandular, yellowish-white, with bearded roots. The leaves are broadly linear, growing up to 15 to 40 centimeters long. The flower stalks are 5 to 10 centimeters long, with sepals at the end that enclose the flowers. The peduncles are divided into two, each bearing one yellow flower, 2.0 to 2.5 centimeters in diameter. The flowers are divided into three outer and inner sepals, each with a brown pattern at the base. The pistil is divided into three and looks like linear petals. The fruit is a drupe, subglobose, with a short beak-like tip.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Yellow flowers, like those of the iris, but with two flowers on a stem, which distinguish them from each other. It is highly valued as a horticultural plant and is often overfished because it blooms in conspicuous places.- Habitat: A perennial herb, it grows on the lower part of mountain slopes, at the edge of forests and in valleys adjacent to trails. It prefers moderately moist soils.- Blooms in April and May, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) on the National Red List and Endangered (EN) on the IUCN Red List due to overharvesting and overharvesting by tourists, road construction around its habitat, and damage from flooding.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to the Korean Peninsula, distributed in parts of Jeolla Province, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and North Korea.

name: Aster altaicus var. uchiyamae
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stem grows to 0.4 to 1.0 meters tall, splitting at the top and spreading widely. The leaves from the roots disappear when the flowers bloom, and the leaves from the stems are linear, 3.5 to 5.5 cm long and 0.1 to 0.3 cm wide, without petioles, with blunt edges. The flowers are borne in head-like inflorescences at the ends of the branches and are 4.0 to 4.5 centimeters in diameter. The florets are yellow with a five-pronged tip, and the tongue flowers are pale purple, 25 to 35 per inflorescence, in two rows. The fruit is an achene, flattened, egg-shaped, with dense short hairs on the outside.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The leaves on the stem are linear and very thin compared to other wormwoods with the same flowering time.- Habitat: A dioecious herb that grows in colonies on sandy or gravelly ground along rivers. The soil is relatively barren and dry.- Blooms from August to October and fruits from October to December.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Aster altaicus var. uchiyamae is a riverine species that lives mainly along the banks of rivers and is subject to high population fluctuations due to habitat disturbance during river flooding. Its population has also declined due to habitat development, such as river channelization. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (EN), a category of endangered, on the National Biological Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed in parts of Gyeonggi-do and Chungcheongbuk-do.

name: Dichotomous swertia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stem grows up to 10 to 20 centimeters long and is Y-shaped, spreading obliquely. Several branches extend from the lower part of the stem, which has four ridges and narrow wings on its surface. The leaves that emerge from the roots are spatulate or egg-shaped, and the leaves that emerge from the stems are opposite and egg-shaped. The white-green panicles of flowers are four-parted and borne in leaf axils and at the ends of stems. The fruit is a drupe, egg-shaped.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
