extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: At the time of discovery, the first place where it was located was Mumyongsan Mountain, and the mountain was named Daesungsan Mountain, so it was called Daesungsan grass, but later the mountain was named Geumdae Peak.- Habitat: It is an annual herb that grows in forested valleys in limestone areas, along hiking trails, and along road cuts.- It blooms in May and June and fruits in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by habitat loss due to the expansion of hiking trails and visits by tourists. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Taebaeksan and Jeongseon-gun, Gangwon-do, Korea - International: Distributed in China, Mongolia, Russia, Kazakhstan, etc.

name: Vesper iris
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground roots are short and thick, and the taproot is long and thick. The stem is upright and grows to a height of 0.5 to 1.0 meters. The flat, knife-shaped leaves are borne on the underside of the stem in clusters of 6 to 8, 20 to 30 centimeters long and 2 to 3 centimeters wide. The pinkish-purple flowers are borne in corymbose inflorescences on Y-shaped stems and are 4 to 5 centimeters in diameter. The stamens are 3, 1.6 to 1.8 centimeters long, and the pistil is 3-parted, deeply cleft, and petal-like. The fruit is a drupe, 3 to 5 centimeters long, yellowish-green oval. The seeds are oval, black, and winged.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The flowers open in the afternoon and close at night. It is distinguished from other members of the Iris family by the fact that the flower stalks form a Y-shaped inflorescence that splits several times.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb that is distributed in Korea in rocky coastal areas or sandy areas in grassy fields, but in other countries it is mainly distributed inland.- Blooms in August and September and fruits from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has a small population and is threatened by habitat destruction due to overgrazing livestock. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed only in Daecheong-do, Baekryeong-do, Incheon Metropolitan City, and Taean-gun, Chungcheongnam-do, South Chungcheong Province - Overseas: Distributed in North Korea, China, Russia, Mongolia, etc.

name: Large-root cymbidium
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are fleshy and long. The stems are upright and grow to a height of 10 to 30 centimeters. The stem is upright and grows 10 to 30 centimeters tall. It has no green parts, but the stem and fruit are dark green when the fruit is ripe. The leaves are thin, papery, translucent, membranous, and scaly. The flowers are borne in clusters of 2 to 6 on the top of the stem, and are white with a magenta tinge. The sepals are obovate, 2 centimeters long and 0.3 to 0.4 centimeters wide, with a pointed tip like a carapace, and the petals are long, oval, and shorter than the sepals. The lip petals are wedge-shaped, about 1.5 centimeters long, shallowly 3-parted at the tip; the central segment is triangular, slightly recurved, and the margins are acuminate with 2 distinct rows. The fruit is a drupe, pointing upward.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Named after Daesungsa Temple in Daedunsan, Jeollanam-do, where it was first discovered - Habitat: It is an epiphyte of many sea grasses and lives in humus-rich forests. In Jeju Island, it is mainly found in dark evergreen forests, but in higher latitudes, it can be found in sunlit areas such as seasong forests. It lives in forests on sloping mountains at an altitude of about 500 meters above sea level.- It blooms from June to August and fruits from August to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This beautifully flowering epiphytic orchid has been indiscriminately harvested in the past, and about half of its habitat on Jeju Island has been completely destroyed by forest clearance and road construction. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) on the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed along the southern coast of Korea, including Jeju Island and Samcheok City. There are very few populations in the central part of the country. - International: Distributed in China, Japan, northern India, Laos, Myanmar, Nepal, Pakistan, and Taiwan.

name: Cowbane
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is thick, 2-5 cm in diameter, and the stem grows to about 1 meter, entirely hairless and hollow. The leaves are pinnately obovate, 30 to 50 centimeters long. The petioles on the lower leaves are long and disappear as the leaves get smaller toward the top. The smaller leaves that make up the leaf blade are lanceolate, pointed, and toothed. The white flowers are borne in clusters in umbellate inflorescences at the ends of the stems. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: This northern aquatic plant is distributed throughout the northern part of Daegwallyeong, Gangwon-do, and has a very limited range in Korea. It is no longer found in Daegwallyeong, where it was first discovered, and its habitat in the Jeongseon area has been damaged by road construction. The roots are also used for medicinal purposes. - Habitat: The perennial aquatic plant is poisonous. It lives in clusters around forest edges, mountainous wetlands, streams, and old reservoirs. - Blooms from July to September and fruits from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by habitat loss and disturbance due to wetland development. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Native to Gangwon Province. Some areas of North Jeolla Province have surviving populations that are believed to have been cultivated for medicinal purposes in the past.- Internationally: Distributed in China, Japan, Mongolia, Russia, and Europe.

name: Two-leaf cremastra
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It has underground egg stalks, and 1 to 2 leaves emerge from the egg stalks. The leaves are oblong-oval, 10 to 15 centimeters long and 3 to 5 centimeters wide, with 3 main veins on the petiole. The flower stalk is 25 to 40 centimeters long with two sheath-like leaves. The petals are lanceolate and have a thin, papery, translucent membrane. The flowers have a yellowish-brown color with purple spots. The lip petals surround the pistil and don't swell at the base. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: similar in appearance to the medicinal orchid, but differs in having one or two leaves and purple spots on the flowers; - Habitat: on the slopes of hillsides in perennial grasses, under deciduous broadleaf forests, with a thick layer of fallen leaves, in semi-shade with high humidity; - Blooms in May and June, fruiting in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by a very narrow geographic range and habitat destruction due to indiscriminate collection and tourism for medicinal and ornamental purposes. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Two to three populations are known to be locally distributed on Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Kadzusa water crowfoot
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Roots from stem nodes, the stem is hollow. The branches branch and grow to a total length of about 50 centimeters. In the water, the leaves are opposite and the petioles are divided into three or four thin threads. In plants that grow above ground, the leaves are relatively thick. The peduncles that face the leaves emerge from the water and bear a single white flower at the end. The flowers are 1 centimeter in diameter, with five sepals, green, five petals, and a yellow base with stamens. The fruit is an achene, several in number, rounded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: shows morphological differences with water depth, such as reduced growth by shading and increased length growth with increasing water depth.- Habitat: A one- or two-year aquatic plant, commonly found in clusters in rice paddies and surrounding waterways, swamps, and ponds where the water flow is stagnant, but also in places that are not filled with water.- Flowering in April and May and fruiting in May and June.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species lives mainly in agricultural lands, where it is likely to be damaged by herbicides and plowing, and its habitat is being destroyed by roads and housing developments. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Grows in rice paddies along the coast, especially along the west coast. It is also found in some east coastal and inland areas. - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Mongolia, Russia, and Europe.

name: Japanese lasianthus
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Leaves are opposite, oblong-elliptic or broadly lanceolate, 8 to 15 centimeters long and 2 to 4 centimeters wide. The front of the leaf is hairless and the back is almost hairless or with a few flat hairs. The leaf blades are triangular with a pointed tip. The plant produces several white, five-parted, cylindrical flowers in the leaf axils, which have no peduncles and run alongside the leaves. The flower spikes are five-parted, about 1 cm long, and have light hairs on the inside. The fruit is a berry, round, 4 to 6 mm in diameter, navy blue in color, containing 4 to 5 seeds.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The habitat is characterized by a mixture of trees, such as pseudo-chestnut, birch, yellow lacquer, and camellia, and shrubs, such as sassafras, platinum, and coral.- Habitat: This evergreen quaking tree lives on the valley slopes of evergreen broadleaf forests, preferring places with high air humidity and rich humus. It grows in places similar to the environment where hanlan and bamboo shoots live. - It blooms in May and June and bears fruit from July to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Lasianthus japonicus is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List of Threatened Species due to its narrow geographic range and extremely small number of individuals.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number of individuals are distributed in some areas of Seogwipo City, Jeju Island, Korea - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, India, and Vietnam.

name: Water sprite
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The leaves are borne in clusters on underground stems, with separate nutrient and spore lobes. The nutrient lobes are ovate-triangular, 5 to 20 cm long and 2 to 17 cm wide, pinnately divided 2 to 3 times. The sporangial lobes are larger than the trophic lobes and are pinnately divided 1 to 3 times, with a narrower row and no sack. The sporangia are located on the inner side of the pileus with the edge of the pileus curled back. The spores are tridentate and the surface pattern is granular.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Once considered extinct in Korea, it has been reported from the Yeongsan River in 1994 and has since been confirmed in several localities.- Habitat: It is an annual aquatic plant that lives in sunny rice fields, puddles, rice banks, and waterways with little water flow.- Spore season is from September to December.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The main threat to this species is the reclamation of its habitat, rice fields and wetlands. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in Jeolla Province, Chungcheong Province, Busan Metropolitan City, and parts of Jeju Island - International: Found in China, Japan, Taiwan, India, Vietnam, and Africa.

name: Whip-lip habenaria
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems are spherical, 1 cm long; leaves are opposite, broadly lanceolate, 5 to 10 cm long, 1.5 to 2.5 cm wide, and wrap around the stem at the base; flowers are borne in raceme inflorescences of 7 to 25; petals are lanceolate with a pointed tip, 10 to 15 mm long and 4 to 5 mm wide; sepals are ovate, 3 mm long and 1.5 to 2.0 mm wide. The sepals are long-oval, concave in the center. The lateral petals form a covering with the sepals. The lip petals are 3-parted: the center petal is wedge-shaped, 2 mm long and 1 mm wide, and the lateral petals are laterally spreading linear, 4 to 7 mm long. The pedicels are club-shaped, and the fruit is an oval drupe, 1 cm long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Once thought to be found at the top of Jeju Island. It is distinguished from the chrysanthemum orchid by having leaves on the flower stalk and a short, cylindrical flower, whereas the chrysanthemum orchid has leaves on the flower stalk and a club-shaped flower.- Habitat: A perennial herb, it lives on moist, clayey soil on hillsides.- Blooms in September and October and fruits in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by a very narrow geographic range, a high number of extreme introductions, and habitat loss due to hill development and tourism. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rarely found in forests and wetlands in southern Jeju Island. - International: Distributed in North Korea and Japan.

name: Korean aconite
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Develops tuberous roots. The stems are erect, growing 0.4 to 1.3 m tall. The leaves are opposite, 4.0 to 6.5 cm long and 3.5 to 6.5 cm wide, deeply divided into three lobes, then divided again two to three times, and the last lobe is linear. The stem-tip racemes bear yellow or white, purplish flowers in umbels. The peduncles have short, dense, curved, light hairs. The sepals are 5-petaled, curved and hairy. The upper petals are helmet-shaped and 1.5 to 2.0 centimeters long. The lateral sepals are ovate. The petals are 2-petaled, contained within the upper sepals, with many stamens and 3 pistils. The fruit is a drupe, 1 to 2 centimeters long. The seeds are oval with narrow wings.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is also known as the 'yellow stonecrop'. Recently, its population has been declining rapidly due to its medicinal properties.- Habitat: A perennial herb that grows under shrubs and in grassy areas at the foot of mountains.- Flowering from July to September and fruiting from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The species is threatened by indiscriminate collection for medicinal purposes, land use in its range, and habitat disturbance due to uncontrolled tourism. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU) on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Distributed in the limestone areas of Gangwon-do, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and parts of Chungcheongbuk-do and Gyeonggi-do; - Internationally: Distributed in North Korea, China, and Russia.

name: Fern broomrape
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems are clustered in bunches, brownish in color, 10 to 30 centimeters tall, with many glandular hairs on the surface. Leaves are scaly, egg-shaped or lanceolate, 0.7 to 1.4 centimeters long and 0.2 to 0.4 centimeters wide. The surface is densely covered with fine hairs. The stems bear 10 to 30 blue-purple flowers in terminal spikelet inflorescences, which are 1.3 to 2.2 centimeters long. The inflorescence is 6 to 17 centimeters long, longer than the rest of the stem. The petals are glandular-lanceolate, 1.0 to 1.6 centimeters long. The sepals are bifurcated, 0.8 to 1.1 centimeters long. The beak is lip-like, with a blue-purple upper lip and a white lower lip. The stamens are 4, the pistil head is 2-parted, and the fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It was considered extinct after a specimen was collected in 1928 from Jaejusan Mountain, Jeollabuk-do, but was rediscovered in 2003 in Jeongeup-si, Jeollabuk-do.- Habitat: It is a parasitic perennial grass that is very rare along streams. It grows parasitically on wormwood in gravelly or sandy soil in sunny areas with little leaf litter.- Blooms in April and May and fruits in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by habitat loss and degradation due to river and road development, population decline due to changes in the vegetation surrounding its habitat, and habitat destruction due to indiscriminate collection and tourism. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to the Korean Peninsula, where it is found in parts of Jeolla and Jeju Island and North Korea.

name: Kuhlhasseltia nakaiana
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem extends laterally and roots emerge from the nodes. The stem grows 4 to 13 centimeters tall, and the leaves are borne in 2 to 5 staggered leaflets at the base of the stem. The leaves are ovate-circular, 3 to 7 millimeters long and 2.5 to 7.0 millimeters wide, with dull edges, and the petioles wrap around the stem. The white flowers are borne in spikelet inflorescences of 3 to 8 at the ends of the flower stalks, the flower stalks are 5 to 12 centimeters long, and the petals are lanceolate, 5 to 7 mm long, with fine hairs on the back. The lip petals are inverted T-shaped, 2-parted, with a needle-like point in the center. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: First discovered in 1934 on Baekunsan Mountain - Habitat: Lives in shady forests in the mountains with perennial grasses. On Jeju Island, it lives in deciduous broadleaf forests at 300 to 700 meters above sea level in humid, humus-rich places.- Blooms in July and August and fruits in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by low genetic diversity, habitat destruction due to tourism, indiscriminate collection, small occupied area, and fragmentation. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed from Yanggu-gun, Gangwon-do to Jeolla-do, Jeju-do, and Ulleung-do, with the northernmost habitat in Yanggu-gun, Gangwon-do.

name: Large-flowered lady's slipper
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are slender, coming from underground stems, and the underground stems are thick. The stems are upright, 20 to 40 centimeters tall, with 2 to 3 leaf sheaths at the base. The stems are erect, 20 to 40 centimeters tall, with 2 to 3 leaflets at the base. The flowers are borne in clusters of 1 to 2 at the end of the stem, and the petals are elliptical and leaf-like. The flowers are light reddish-purple, pink, or white, and the lip petals are puffed up like a pouch. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Off-white cypripedium, pink cypripedium, reciprocating cypripedium, and red cypripedium are all floral variants of cypripedium macranthos - Habitat: A perennial herb, it lives in sunny, well-drained areas in grassy areas on ridges and in woodlands around mountains - Flowering in May and June, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to the high ornamental value of its flowers, indiscriminate collection and tourism has led to population declines. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed throughout Korea except Jeju Island and Ulleung Island; - International: Distributed in Eastern Europe, the Russian Amur, Ussuri, Sakhalin, Siberia, Northeast China, and Japan.

name: Capitate silene
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Growing obliquely, the entire plant is hairy, and the stems grow to 25 to 40 cm. The leaves are opposite, long ovate or lanceolate with a pointed tip, 1 to 4 cm long. The pink flowers are borne in clusters at the ends of the branches. The petals are 5-petaled and 2-parted at the ends. The sepals are barrel-shaped with 10 veins on the outside and 5-parted at the ends. The stamens are 10 in number and extend outward. The fruit is a drupe, ovoid, with bumps on the surface.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is a northern plant with a relatively narrow distribution range in Korea - Habitat: It is a perennial herb that grows in sunny rocky places in the mountains and clings to the surface - Flowering in September and October and fruiting in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by habitat disturbance due to land use, overharvesting, and tourism near its habitat. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in Korea: Yeongwol-gun and Hongcheon-gun, Gangwon-do, and Yeoncheon-gun, Cheorwon-gun, Pocheon-gun, Okcheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do, Korea; - Overseas: North Korea and Northeast China.

name: Bureja viburnum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Growing to 2 to 3 meters tall with many branches. The stems are dark gray with star-shaped hairs on the younger branches. The leaves are opposite, elliptical, 5 to 8 centimeters long and 3 to 5 centimeters wide, with serrated edges. The leaves are slightly hairy on the front, with more hairs on the back leaf veins that gradually disappear. The white flowers are borne in corymbose inflorescences at the ends of new branches. The fruit is a drupe that ripens red and gradually turns black, and is oblong-oval to oval, about 1 cm long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: It differs from the bunchberry in having elliptical leaves with finely toothed margins, a very short flowering spike, and white flowers.- Habitat: A deciduous, broad-leaved shrub that grows with other shrubs on sunny hillsides, usually on limestone mountainsides or valley edges.- Blooms in May and fruits in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by its narrow geographic range, low population size, and indiscriminate harvesting. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to be found in Yeoncheon-gun, Gyeonggi-do, Pyeongchang-gun, Gangwon-do, and Seoraksan, and according to recent surveys, in small numbers in other provinces.- International: Distributed in the Russian Far East, Mongolia, and Northeast China.

name: Obovate peony
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Roots are branched and long. Stems are erect, 40 to 70 centimeters tall, and branched. It has staggered, 3-pinnate leaves that split into 2 or 3 leaflets. The smaller leaves are obovate and have dull edges. The leaves are green on the front and light green on the back, hairless or with soft hairs only on the veins. The flowers are borne in single clusters at the ends of the stems and are 7 to 10 centimeters in diameter. They have 5 to 7 petals and are usually light pink or red. The stamens are numerous. The pistils are 3 or 4-petaled and curve back at the end as they grow. The fruit is a drupe with a long, hooked pistil at the end.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: differs from peonies in that it has 9 or fewer petals, single flowers at the end of the flower stalk, and the flowers do not fully open - Habitat: perennial herb, lives in moist soil in semi-shaded areas of deciduous and mixed deciduous forests - Blooms in May and June, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate collection for medicinal and ornamental purposes and habitat loss due to tourism. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of Critically Endangered, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found mainly in the limestone mountains of Gangwon-do, other parts of Gyeonggi-do and Chungcheongbuk-do - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Chinese lizard's tail
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are white and grow laterally. The stems are erect, 50 to 100 centimeters tall. The leaves are ovate-elliptical, 5 to 15 centimeters long and 3 to 8 centimeters wide, arranged in opposite rows. The leaf tips are pointed, cordate at the base, and the edges are dull. The backs of the leaves are pale white, and the upper two or three leaves turn white on the front when in bloom. The petioles are 1 to 5 centimeters long and slightly wrap around the stem at the base. The flowers are white and borne in racemes from the leaf axils at the ends of the stems. The inflorescence is 10 to 15 centimeters long, initially pointing downward but later erect. There are no petals and sepals, 6 to 7 stamens and 3 to 5 pistils. The fruit is a drupe, rounded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: It is distinguishable from the wild species in the southern provinces and Ulleungdo by its taller stature, longer inflorescence, and lack of foul odor. All individuals found on land are believed to be introduced - Habitat: This perennial aquatic plant lives around ponds and wetlands in low-elevation areas. It grows in abandoned agricultural fields and along drainage ditches in lowland coastal areas below 50 meters elevation, and forms clusters in the lower reaches of small streams.- Blooms from June to August, fruiting from August to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: It is exposed to development pressure due to indiscriminate collection for medicinal use and because its habitat is mainly wetlands at low altitudes. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (EN), a category of endangered, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed only in Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China, India, Japan, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

name: Japanese chain fern
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It has a thick, short, laterally creeping underground stem, and the leaves are clustered. The petioles are 30 to 50 centimeters long and covered with brown scales at the base. The leaf blade is 40 to 80 centimeters long and 20 to 35 centimeters wide, elliptic-ovate, with a single pinnate division. The stipules are 10 to 15 pairs, glandular-lanceolate, pointed, with brown scales on the back. The sporangia are linear, 2 to 5 mm long, running close to the midrib, and the perithecium is thick, linear, and brown.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: highly prized for its ornamental value and subject to overfishing, resulting in declining populations.- Habitat: an evergreen, perennial fern, usually found on valley slopes and stream sides in broadleaf forests. It prefers areas with an abundant deciduous layer and occasionally colonizes rocks and trees.- Sporulation period is from July to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes, a narrow geographic distribution range, and a population of ectoparasites. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of Critically Endangered, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Rarely found in Jeju Island and Jeollanam-do; - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, Vietnam, and Myanmar.

name: Seoul pterygopleurum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Roots are white, fleshy, thickened, with short underground stems. The stems are erect, angular, hollow, 80 to 180 cm tall, branching at the top. The leaves are opposite, the leaves and petioles becoming smaller and shorter towards the top of the stem. The leaves are pinnately divided 2 to 3 times and the lobes are linear with dull edges. The flowers are white in color and form an umbellate inflorescence. The flower stalks have wing-like folds and may or may not have petals. The petals are 5-petaled, white, with a concave tip. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape, 3.5 to 4.0 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: first discovered in 1902 in Cheongnyang-ri, Seoul, Korea, but thought to be extinct after 1967 and rediscovered in 2011 in Gyeongsangnam-do, South Korea - Habitat: a perennial herb, inhabiting sunny streamside wetlands - Flowers from July to September, fruiting from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is highly exposed to predation by neighboring plants such as reeds and reed grasses, and is also threatened by habitat disturbance due to the development of waterfront areas near its habitat. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Seoul, Jeolla-do, and Gyeongsangnam-do, but currently only found in one area in Gyeongsangnam-do - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Snow orchid
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is short and produces many thick roots. The stems are greenish-brown, clustered, 10 to 30 centimeters tall, and many-nodded. The lanceolate leaves, which resemble a spear with a pointed tip, are opposite, 4 to 7 centimeters long, dark green, glabrous, and live for 2 to 3 years. The flowers are usually borne in clusters of one or two at the end of stems that emerged two years earlier, and are white or light red in color and fragrant. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Phylogenetic analysis shows that Korean and Japanese dendrobiums form a monophyletic group, but Chinese and Taiwanese dendrobiums are very different from Korean and Japanese dendrobiums, forming a paraphyletic or polyphyletic group.- Habitat: Epiphytic, evergreen perennial herb that grows on rocks and trees. It grows in semi-shady or sunny places with high air humidity and good ventilation. - It blooms in May and June and fruits in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by overharvesting for ornamental purposes and habitat loss. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to be distributed throughout the coastal and island areas of Jeju and Jeollanam-do, and recent surveys have confirmed it in parts of Gyeongsangnam-do and Jeollabuk-do.- International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Radde's violet
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are short, clustered, erect, and 30 to 70 centimeters tall. The leaves are unequal, triangular-lanceolate, shallowly cordate at the base, gradually pointed toward the tip, and with low serrations on the margins. Leaves are 4 to 8 centimeters long and 1 to 2 centimeters wide. Petioles are 3 to 6 centimeters long and winged at the top. The jaw leaves are glandular-lanceolate, 3 to 6 centimeters long, with large serrations on the margins. The light purple flowers are borne on single, 5-10 cm long flower stalks that emerge from the leaf axils and are 1 cm long. The lateral petals have purple streaks and hairs, and the cones are hemispherical, 1.5 to 2.0 mm long. The fruit is a drupe, oblong-oval, 8 to 12 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Once known to have been distributed in water sources in Gyeonggi Province, it is believed to have been extirpated - Habitat: A perennial herb, it is found in lowland marshes and stream-flood prone grasslands, leaning against water purifying plants such as reeds and water milfoil - Flowering in May and June, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by its limited range and habitat loss due to river development and maintenance projects. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR), a category of concern for extinction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to be distributed only in Yeoncheon County, Gyeonggi-do and Yangsan City, Gyeongsangnam-do - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Russia.

name: Wilson cotoneaster
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class I Endangered Wildlife Listed in 2012
Designated as Class I Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This tree is about 1.5 meters tall. The stems are gray, with young branches reddish-brown and hairy. The leaves are opposite, egg-shaped, 2 to 5 centimeters long, with dull edges. Leaves on newly emerged branches initially have white hairs on the back that gradually disappear. The petioles are hairy, with a 1 to 4 millimeter long pinnate leaf at the tip. The flowers are white or pale pink, borne in umbels at the ends of the branches. They have 5 rounded petals, with stamens shorter than the petals and 2 pistils. The calyx is hairless, but the edges of the sepals are hairy. The fruit is a pomegranate, oval-shaped fruit that ripens to a dark red color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The colonies of cotoneaster wilsonii and cotoneaster wilsonii in Dodong, Ulleungdo are protected as natural monuments.- Habitat: A deciduous trembling tree that grows in sunny places near cliffs or bluffs with shallow soil at an elevation of 110 to 130 meters in the inter-coastal mountains.- Flowers in May and June and fruits in August and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by habitat fragmentation, overharvesting, and anthropogenic damage. Its current habitat is concentrated on cliffs, which can be damaged by natural disasters such as strong winds and heavy rainfall. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to the Korean Peninsula, distributed in Ulleungdo and North Korea.

name: Ulleung scrophularia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems up to 1 meter tall, branched and quadrangular. Leaves are opposite, broadly egg-shaped, rounded, with serrated edges. The flowers are in panicles, 15 to 40 centimeters long, developed at the ends of the stems, with glandular hairs on the pedicels. The sepals and pedicels are 5-parted, and the pedicels are greenish-purple in color. The fruit is a drupe, egg-shaped, with a pointed tip.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: a salt-tolerant, salt-averse salt plant that occurs alongside bindweed and cordgrass.- Habitat: a dioecious perennial that lives on islands, shoreline pebbles, and road cobblestones, although young individuals may live in sandy areas.- Blooms May through July and fruits in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: In addition to its limited distribution, this species is threatened by habitat loss due to coastal road construction and typhoon damage. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found only on Ulleungdo Island.

name: Ulleung bupleurum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems erect, 70 to 130 cm tall, branching at the top; leaves from the roots are kidney-shaped, broadly elliptical with 10 to 20 cm petioles; leaves from the stems are opposite, with petioles that become shorter toward the top of the stem and wrap around the stem; flowers are yellow, borne in umbellate inflorescences at the ends of the stems and branches; petals are obovate, borne opposite the stamens; fruit is a drupe, broadly elliptical.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Announced as endemic to Wollongong in 1917, it was observed along the coast of Wollongong until the 1970s, when it rapidly disappeared due to changes in its habitat and was not recognized until 2000, when it was rediscovered. In the first year of growth, only leaves from the roots grow, but the following year it grows a stem, flowers, and bears fruit, and then dies.- Habitat: It is a dioecious plant found in forests in the mountains around the coast. It is mostly found on sunny northwestern slopes between 40 and 300 meters above sea level, but can also be found on southern and western slopes, where it is shaded by the upper tree canopy.- It blooms in May and June and fruits in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened due to its narrow distribution range and occupied area, disturbance and loss of habitat due to land use. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN) in the category of Near Threatened on the National Red List of Threatened Species and Critically Endangered (CR) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found only on Ulleungdo Island.

name: South Korean aconite
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are unbranched, 60 to 80 centimeters long, growing mostly at an angle and densely covered with short hairs on the upper part. The leaves are opposite, the lower few on the stem are rounded, while the upper ones are 3- or 5-pinnate and shallowly divided, forming a triangle or pentagon. The yellowish-purple, helmet-shaped flowers are borne singly in leaf axils or in racemes at the ends of the stems. The long, oval fruit is a fine-haired drupe with 3 to 4 seeds.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Leaves become triangular toward the top of the stem, giving the plant its name from the appearance of three horns. It is also known as 'white barflower' and 'golden hornwort'.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb that grows in deciduous and hardwood forests at altitudes of 200 to 600 meters and slopes of 10 to 30 degrees.- It blooms in August and September and fruits in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by natural degradation due to its stony habitat, and by overharvesting and tourism for medicinal purposes. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to the Korean Peninsula, where it is found only in Gyeongsangbuk-do and parts of Jeolla-do, with a known distribution in North Korea.

name: Fragrant orchid
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The tuber is 2-palmate with several bearded roots. The stems are erect, 30 to 60 cm tall. The leaves are long elliptical or broadly lanceolate, 6 to 20 cm long and 1 to 4 cm wide, in clusters of 4 to 6 at the base of the stem. The flowers are light reddish-purple, borne in dense 7 to 15 cm spikelike inflorescences. The petals are green, lanceolate with a pointed tip. The fruit is an oval drupe, 1 centimeter long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: also known as 'root orchid', 'hand root orchid', 'palm orchid', and in some Asian countries the tuber is used for medicinal purposes.- Habitat: a perennial herb that lives in sunny grassy areas of high mountains. It grows where the soil is relatively moist. - Blooms in July and August and fruits in September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by its very narrow geographic range and occupied area, indiscriminate harvesting and tourism, and changes in habitat vegetation. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: restricted to Hallasan, Jeju Island, Korea - International: distributed in Japan, Mongolia, China, Amur, Siberia, Ussuri, Sakhalin, Kamchatka, and Europe.

name: Whisk fern
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are long, covered with brown bushy roots that branch irregularly and intermittently. The stems are hairy, greenish in color, 10 to 30 centimeters tall, and continuously Y-shaped from the base. Leaves like small lobes are attached to the stem at random. The sporangia are rounded, 2 mm in diameter, borne in the leaf axils, green at first, yellow when ripe, and three-celled.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A tropical and subtropical fern, the southern coast of Korea is considered the northern limit of its distribution.- Habitat: An evergreen perennial fern that grows along rocky incisions such as ravines and cliffs, although some populations live close to sea level and prefer full sun.- Spore season is June through September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The species is threatened by landslides and epiphytic vegetation around its habitat. It is also threatened by overharvesting. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN) in the National Red List of Threatened Species and Least Concern (LC) in the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Jeju Island and parts of the south coast; - International: Central Japan, China, and the Philippines; - Australia and New Zealand; - Southeastern United States and southwestern Europe.

name: Water shield
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stem grows long underwater, reaching up to 100 centimeters in length. The buds emerge wrapped in a mucilage, and the mature leaves float on the surface of the water and are elliptical, 8 to 12 centimeters long and 4 to 6 centimeters wide, with blunt edges. The petiole is attached to the back center of the leaf, forming a shield. The reddish-purple flowers are borne on one peduncle in the leaf axils, 2 centimeters in diameter, with three petals and three sepals. There are 6 to 18 pistils and several stamens. The fruit is egg-shaped and ripens in water.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The young shoots that emerge enveloped in a mucilage are called 'turnips' and are edible, and were cultivated in rice fields. It has two flowering days, with only the female flowers mature on the first day and the male flowers mature on the second day.- Habitat: A submerged perennial that lives in shallow water within 1.5 meters of old reservoirs or nails.- Blooms from May to July, fruiting in October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by low population numbers, indiscriminate harvesting for food and medicinal purposes, and habitat loss due to wetland development. It is currently rated as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Distributed in Korea: Gangwon-do, Gyeongsangnam-do, Ulsan, Ulsan Metropolitan City, Chungcheongbuk-do, and parts of Jeju Island and the southern coast of Korea - Distributed internationally: China, Japan, Russia, India, the United States, and Africa.

name: Awned calanthe
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It grows 25 to 50 centimeters tall. The roots emerge from pseudobulbs, which increase by one each year, and are short, thick, and many-nodded, shrimp-like. The leaves are 2 to 3 leaves, long elliptical, 20 to 40 centimeters long and 3 to 8 centimeters wide, longitudinally corrugated, with fine hairs on the back and wavy edges. The flower stalks emerge from a false scaly stem and are 30 to 40 centimeters long. The flowers are light red, 10 to 20 in racemes. The pedicels are raised above the seed chambers, and the fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: hairs on the back of the leaves and upturned flower spikes distinguish it from other species in the genus Calanthe.- Habitat: evergreen perennial herb that lives in forests in warm, humid southern islands. It overlaps its habitat with other shrimp orchids such as the golden shrimp orchid. - Blooms in May and fruits from June to August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by its narrow range and occupied area, and by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in Sinan-gun, Jeollanam-do, South Jeolla Province - International: Distributed in southern China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Ishidoya lousewort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The entire plant has fine hairs. There is no stem; the leaves are clustered at the root, 25 to 30 centimeters long, pinnately lobed, and toothed at the edges. The flowers are light reddish-purple, borne on peduncles 6 centimeters long. The sepals are long and cylindrical, with a five-pronged tip. The beak is two-pronged, the upper one bending forward like a bow, and the lower one bifurcating again into three prongs. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: semi-parasitic, photosynthesizing while simultaneously obtaining nutrients and moisture from other plants - Habitat: perennial, distributed in cool places around streams with abundant flow, often on shady north slopes of mountains - Flowering in April and May, fruiting in May and June.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by environmental changes caused by climate change, flooding in its valleys, and habitat destruction due to indiscriminate collection and tourism. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to the Korean Peninsula, distributed in Gyeonggi-do, Gangwon-do, Gyeongsang-do, and Cheonmasan, Kaesong, North Korea.

name: Korean meadow rue
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are blackish-brown and have a thick, club-shaped taproot. It grows to a height of 30 to 60 centimeters. The leaves are 1 to 2 times 3-pinnately divided, and the smaller leaves are 5.5 to 7.5 centimeters long and 6 to 8 centimeters wide, with wavy serrations on the edges, and whitish on the back. The petioles are attached to the back of the leaves like a shield. The flowers are borne in panicles at the end of the stem, with 4 or 5 sepals that fall off as soon as the flower opens. The petals are absent, and the stamens are purple or white and multiple. The fruit is an achene and the pedicel is very short, less than 0.5 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The leaves are slightly smaller than those of the same shield-shaped species, 2 to 4 centimeters long and 1.5 to 4 centimeters wide; the pedicels are long, 1.5 millimeters long, and have no coarse, club-shaped roots; - Habitat: A perennial herb, it grows in sunny grassy areas in rocky areas, in rocky crevices or near rocks. It prefers well-drained, dry areas with poor humus soils - Blooms from May to August and fruits from August to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Thalictrum coreanum is threatened by its narrow geographic range and occupied area, indiscriminate collection and tourism, and the establishment of hiking trails around its habitat. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to the Korean Peninsula, distributed in Seoraksan, Gangwon Province and North Korea.

name: Webster's violet
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are slender and short. The stems are erect, 40 to 60 centimeters tall. The leaves are opposite, long elliptical, 8 to 12 centimeters long and 2 to 3 centimeters wide, with serrations on the edges. The pinnate leaves are narrowly triangular, 2.5 to 3.5 centimeters long and 0.4 to 1.0 centimeters wide. The white flowers are borne in leaf axils or on peduncles at the ends of the stems. The sepals are 5 to 6 mm long, with 5 petals, the petals are 12 to 13 mm long, with no hairs on the inside of the lateral petals, and the pedicels are 2 to 4 mm long. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape, 4 to 6 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is one of the largest members of the violet family, along with the violets, and is characterized by its leaves, which are long and elliptical with the widest center compared to the triangular-lanceolate leaves of the violets. Habitat: It is a boreal plant that grows on relatively gently sloping forest ridges or moist slopes and valleys at an altitude of 350 to 1,000 meters above sea level. Habitat is limited to areas with coarse-grained soils that allow relatively free movement of moisture.- Blooms from April to June and fruits from June to July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by habitat destruction due to indiscriminate harvesting and tourism, as well as by the establishment of hiking trails. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Native to the northern regions of Korea, including Gyeonggi-do, Gangwon-do, and Chungcheongbuk-do; - Foreign: Distributed in North Korea and Northeast China.

name: Northern cyrtosia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: No green parts throughout. The underground stems extend laterally and are fleshy. The stems are erect, 50 to 100 centimeters tall, and branching at the top. The leaves are scaly and appear to be absent. The flowers are yellowish-brown, 2.5 centimeters in diameter, borne in double racemes, and have brown hairs on the peduncle and seed chambers. The lip petals are broadly egg-shaped, yellow, fleshy, with an inner row of bumps, and finely divided at the edges. The fruit is a long cylindrical, 6 to 8 centimeters long, berry-like fruit that ripens to red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is a southern plant, but in Korea it is distributed as far as the Chungcheong-do Peninsula - Habitat: It is a saprophytic egg parasitizing on the decaying hyphae of perennial grasses. It grows in areas with good forest formation and humus at an altitude of 300 to 1,000 meters above sea level, and grows in almost flat places in relatively shallow valleys in terms of topography.- It blooms in June and July and fruits in July and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes and habitat disturbance from tourism. It is currently assessed as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in Jeju Island and parts of Jeolla Province, Chungcheongnam-do, Chungcheongnam-do, and Gyeongsangbuk-do - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Yakushima bladderwort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem extends like a thread and bears a cyst. It grows up to 10 centimeters tall, with leaves that are mostly spatulate and emerge in clusters directly from the underground stem. The flowers are bluish-purple in color, borne in racemes of 1 to 10 at the end of the stem. The flower buds have a lip-like tip, and the pointed pedicels point downward. The fruit is a drupe, rounded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is the smallest of the carnivorous plants native to Korea. It is similar to the spikelet earwort, but differs in that the flower cones extend downward.- Habitat: It is found in wetlands and valleys in the mountains with annual grasses. It grows in places where there are no woody plants around and the water is kept very shallow with lots of sunlight, or where the soil moisture is saturated even if the water is not full.- It blooms in August and September and fruits in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Its habitat is decreasing due to wetland development. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in wetlands in Jeju, Jeollanam-do, and Gyeongsang-do provinces; - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Southeast Asia, Australia, and the Pacific islands.

name: Yatabe dysophylla
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem extends long and produces stems. The stems are erect, 40 to 60 centimeters tall, and rarely branched. The leaves are 3 to 4-lobed, 3 to 5 centimeters long and 5 to 7 millimeters wide, narrowly lanceolate, with blunt or shallowly toothed margins. The flowers are light purple, borne in spikelet inflorescences at the end of a panicle. The sepals are 5-parted and have soft hairs along with the petals. The beak is 4-parted, with 4 stamens, 2 of which are long, and long hairs spreading across the stamens. The fruit is a small drupe, rounded.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: First discovered in Jeonju in 1912, it was thought to be extinct in Korea, but was rediscovered in the mid-1980s in the eastern part of Jeju Island.- Habitat: A perennial grass, it is found in low-lying grassy marshes at about 130 meters above sea level on Jeju Island.- Flowers from August to October, fruiting in October and November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by the reclamation of wetlands and environmental pollution. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Biological Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: The population has been extirpated from Jeollabuk-do, and only the Jeju Island population survives today - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Elliptic amsonia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems extend laterally. The stems are erect, growing 40 to 80 centimeters tall and branching somewhat at the top. The leaves are opposite, lanceolate, 6 to 10 centimeters long and 1 to 2 centimeters wide, with dull edges. The flowers are light blue, borne in panicles at the ends of the stems, and about 13 mm in diameter. The sepals and pedicels are 5-parted, with hairs growing on the inside of the pedicels. There are 5 stamens. The fruit is a drupe, cylindrical, 5 to 6 centimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: named for the resemblance of its flowers to a square, it is also known as 'spermwort'- Habitat: a perennial herb that grows in sandy soil or grassy areas along the coast- Blooms in May and June and fruits in July and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has extremely limited habitat, is being lost to development, and is indiscriminately harvested for ornamental and medicinal purposes. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Limited to Ongjin-gun, Incheon, and Wando-gun, Jeollanam-do. Recently, a new colony has been observed in Sokcho, Gangwon-do, which requires further investigation to determine whether it is native or introduced.- Overseas: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Wilford's lychnis
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It's 45 to 100 centimeters tall. The stems are erect, sometimes branching at the top. The leaves are opposite, lanceolate, and 3 to 12 centimeters long. The flowers are borne in corymbose inflorescences at the ends of the stems and branches, 2.5 to 3.0 centimeters in diameter, and deep red in color. The petals are five-petaled and finely divided into four lobes. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: the petals are finely divided and feathered at the tips, the flowers are a deeper red, and the leaves are more slender than those of the dongonflower - Habitat: a perennial, very rarely found in high mountain bogs - Blooms in July and August, fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by wetland development, habitat alteration due to surrounding land uses, and indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in the relatively high mountains of Gangwon Province. Its distribution has been confirmed in less than 10 localities, and the total population is estimated to be less than 300 individuals. - International: Distributed in Mongolia, China, Russia, and Japan.

name: Rabbit-ear iris
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem grows by creeping sideways. The stems are erect, 50 to 80 cm tall, with two rows of leaves at the base. The leaves are broadly linear, with a pointed tip, 40 to 100 cm long and 2 to 3 cm wide. The petals are narrowly elliptical, 5 to 7 cm long. The flowers are borne in clusters of 2 to 3 at the end of the stem, dark purple in color, 10 to 15 cm in diameter. The flowers are divided into 3 outer and inner sepals, the outer sepals drooping downward and the inner sepals standing upright. The pistil is divided into three and looks like petals. The fruit is a drupe, cylindrical, about 5 centimeters long. The seeds are semicircular, brown and shiny.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is characterized by the absence of prominent leaf veins on the leaves and a white pattern on the inside of the outer sheath, compared to the iris, which has a yellow pattern on the inside of the outer sheath. It is a northern plant with high ornamental value, so it is likely to be transported overseas - Habitat: It is a perennial grass and is found in wetlands such as ponds, streams, river banks, and river mudflats - It blooms in May and June and fruits from July to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by wetland development, habitat loss and disturbance due to environmental changes, and indiscriminate harvesting. It is currently rated as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: restricted to some areas of Gangwon-do Province - International: distributed in Russia, China, Japan, etc.

name: Jeju fern ally
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Plants in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It is 10 to 15 centimeters tall. The underground stem is black-brown, about 0.5 cm in diameter, growing sideways and bearing 1 to 2 leaves. The petioles are 8 to 12 cm long, hairless, and green. The leaf bodies run perpendicular to the petioles, are light green or greenish, slightly hard, and have serrated edges. The leaf body splits into three and then into two, giving the appearance of five or six posterior segments. Sporophylls are spikelet-shaped, with one to three emerging from the petiole tip. The sporangia are arranged in two rows along the edge of the sporophyll.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It reproduces asexually, mainly by underground stems. The underground stems can grow to more than 1 meter long, making it difficult to determine the number of individuals because adjacent individuals in the same habitat are likely to be the same. It is the only species of Korean endemic genus that preserves the primitive fern form and is known to be restricted to Jeju Island worldwide.- Habitat: An evergreen perennial fern that lives in depressions or bog-like environments where the ground is slightly lower than the surrounding area. Its distribution is limited to Cape Jawal around Jocheon-eup and Gujwa-eup on Jeju Island. - The sporulation period is from October to March of the following year.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Since it was recognized as the only species of its genus endemic to Korea, it has suffered severe habitat disturbance and degradation due to tourism, indiscriminate harvesting, and other activities. It is also threatened with habitat loss due to large-scale development. It is currently rated as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Biological Red List and Critically Endangered (CR) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found only on Jeju Island.

name: Buckbean
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem extends laterally, with 5 to 6 leaves emerging from the end. The leaves are compound, with 3 leaflets, and the leaflets are oblong-oval, 4 to 8 centimeters long and 2 to 5 centimeters wide, with dull or bluntly toothed edges. The flowers are white, borne in racemes of 20 to 40 cm long pedicels that emerge from the leaf axils. The sepals and pedicels are 5-pronged, with long hairs on the inside of the pedicels. There are 5 stamens and 1 pistil. The fruit is a drupe, round, 6 to 7 millimeters in diameter.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: The name comes from the word for drowsy waterweed.
