The roots and leaves are edible and were used in the past to treat scurvy.- Habitat: This perennial, northern aquatic plant lives in ponds, streams, and wetlands. It is known to be a trophic reproducer without flowering, especially in the less deep ponds of Daesam Mountain, where it is not known to flower.- Blooms in April and May, fruiting in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: A northern wetland species, some of its habitat has been completely destroyed, and what remains is threatened by development. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Known to be distributed only in Gangwon and Gyeongsangbuk-do, but the original habitats in Uljin-gun, Gyeongsangbuk-do and Pyeongchang-gun, Gangwon-do are now thought to have been completely destroyed.- International: Distributed throughout North America, Asia, and Europe.

name: Glabrous sarcandra
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems are green, clustered, 1.0 to 1.5 meters tall, thickly nodded. Leaves are opposite, broadly lanceolate, 5 to 16 centimeters long and 4 to 6 centimeters wide, with sharp serrations on the margins. The flowers are yellow-green, borne in spikelet inflorescences at the ends of the branches; there are no petals, the pistil is egg-shaped, light green, and the stamens are horizontally spreading from the pistil, yellow, with anthers on both sides. The fruit is a drupe, round, 3-5 mm in diameter.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: stem nodes develop like bamboo, and are indiscriminately harvested for their ornamental value due to the red berries that ripen in winter.- Habitat: evergreen quaking tree in evergreen broadleaf forests in humid climates where emergent plants are sparse and the understory is well developed.- Flowering in June and July, fruiting from October to February of the following year.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes and a narrow geographic distribution range. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of Critically Endangered, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Native to Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, Malaysia, etc.

name: Centipede orchid
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are slender, elongated, sparsely branched, with roots emerging from the nodes. The leaves are opposite, narrowly lanceolate, plump, 7 to 10 mm long. The flowers are bright red, borne in leaf axils, single, on pedicels 2 to 3 millimeters long. The lip petals swell at the bottom to form a short pedicel, which splits into 3 prongs: the lateral prongs are earlobe-shaped, and the center prongs are triangular and white. The fruit is a drupe, club-shaped, 6 to 7 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Named for its centipede-like appearance as it grows attached to rocks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate collection and tourism for ornamental purposes and by its narrow geographic distribution. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, on the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed along the southern coast of Jeju Island and Jeollanam-do, but has a limited range - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Chinese surprise lily
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground scaly stems are long, egg-shaped, 3.5 to 5.2 centimeters long, and blackish-brown in color. The leaves are 4 to 8 leaflets, 30 to 40 centimeters long and 1.5 to 2.5 centimeters wide, broadly linear. The flower stems are upright, 40 to 70 centimeters long, and bear 4 to 7 deep yellow flowers in umbellate inflorescences at the end. The petals are 2-petaled, papery, translucent, membranous, lanceolate, and 3 to 4 centimeters long. The edges of the petals are wavy and corrugated. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Leaves are present from February to May, and flowers appear from mid-July after the leaves have fallen. The flowers are yellow in color, unlike those of the sanguinaceae.- Habitat: It is found in forests with perennial grasses and gravelly soil. It is found in clusters on the lower slopes of mountains and in the valleys around the valleys. - After the leaves wither in July and August, the flower stalks emerge and bloom, and the flowers bear fruit in September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Lycoris chinensis var. sinuolata is an anthropogenic threat, mainly living near trails around valleys, and is also affected by heavy rainfall. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is found only in the Bulgap Mountain area of Jeollanam-do and Jeju-san area of Jeollabuk-do.

name: Japanese oberonia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are short, 1 to 2 centimeters long, in clusters of several individuals. The leaves are in two rows, glandular-lanceolate, 1-3 cm long, 2-5 mm wide, and wrap around the stem at the base. The flowers are borne in racemes, 2-8 cm long, between the leaves at the end of the stem, and are pale yellow, about 1 mm in diameter. The lip petals are 3-parted and shallowly divided. The fruit is a drupe, obovate.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It was published in 1969 under the name 'Nadajebinan', but the name was already in use for another plant, so it is believed to have been derived from 'car hanger', meaning 'hanger in the car'.- Habitat: This evergreen, perennial epiphytic orchid is found in woody, moist forests at altitudes of 150 to 800 meters above sea level, where it attaches itself to other trees, especially birch trees in birch forests. Jeju Island is considered to be the northern limit of its distribution - Blooms from May to June and fruits from July to August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Oberonia japonica is threatened by overharvesting due to its novelty. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in less than five locations on Jeju Island, including the Biji Forest. - International: Distributed in Japan, Taiwan, and China.

name: Korean halenia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It grows from 10 to 80 centimeters tall and is entirely hairless. The stem is erect or branched, with four ridges and short wings. The leaves are opposite, egg-shaped, 2.4 to 7.6 centimeters long and 0.8 to 2.3 centimeters wide, with dull edges. The flowers are yellowish-white, borne in umbellate inflorescences at the ends of the stems and in leaf axils. The sepals and pedicels are divided into four, and the pedicels develop a pedicel 8 to 11 mm long, giving the entire plant an anchor-like appearance. The fruit is a drupe, oblong-oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: longer peduncle and more curved toward the front of the flower than in anchorwort; leaf tips acute; habitat: An annual or biennial herb that grows in meadows, forest gaps, forest edges, and forest margins in relatively high mountains. It is mainly found at altitudes ranging from 700 to 1,430 meters above sea level. It grows in places with a lot of light, and ash trees, geoje trees, cedar trees, and maples appear together in its growth zone.
					
					
					- It blooms from July to September and fruits from September to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by forest development, such as the construction of forest roads and road repairs, and by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes. It is currently listed as Vulnerable (VU) in the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is found in Gyeonggi-do, Gangwon-do, and Jeju-do.

name: Korean quillwort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem splits into 3 parts and is about 1 centimeter in diameter. The leaves are gathered from the underground stem and are 9 to 11.5 centimeters long, with septa on both sides. There are 20 macropetalous lobes on the outside and 15 vesicular lobes on the inside. The sporangia do not have a septum; the macrosporangia are 4.8 to 6.2 millimeters long and 2.8 to 3.5 millimeters wide, while the endosporangia are about 0.2 millimeters long. The conidia are spherical, gray when wet and white when dry, with irregular chicken-crested ridges on the surface and spiny projections on the sides. Vesicles are small, grayish-brown in color when wet and white when dry, with sharp spinelike projections on the surface.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: irregular, chicken-crested ridges on the surface of the spores distinguish it from other members of the watercress family.- Habitat: A perennial, perennial fern that lives in the shallow waters of lakes, ponds, and streams. Its distribution and abundance fluctuate greatly with water levels. - Spore season is July through September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by changes in the structure of rivers and reservoirs and development around lakes. It is currently assessed as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is distributed in Gangwon-do, Gyeonggi-do, Gyeongsang-do, Chungcheongbuk-do, and Jeollanam-do.

name: Formosan michelia
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A tall tree that grows up to 20 meters in height. The branches are numerous, branching, and leafy. The leaves are opposite, long elliptical, leathery, 8 to 12 centimeters long and 2 to 4 centimeters wide, with dull edges. The leaves are dark green and glossy on the front, whitish on the back. The petioles are 2 to 3 centimeters long and have tan hairs. The flowers are white, borne in leaf axils at the ends of the branches, and are about 3 centimeters in diameter, with 12 perianths, reddish on the underside. The fruit is a drupe.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: The black sand island colony was declared a natural monument in 1992, but the designation was lifted in 2001 because the trees died in 1994. Successor trees are now growing around the dead tree, which was declared a local monument in 2009. The name Chosŏngryŏngtŏn (招靈木) comes from the meaning of placing branches in Buddhist temples - Habitat: Evergreen tall tree found in humus-rich soils on very gentle slopes near streams - Blooms in February and March, fruiting in October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by overpopulation, degradation of its habitat due to extreme weather events, and indiscriminate collection and tourism for ornamental purposes. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed only on the islands of Jeju and Jeollanam-do; - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Yellow-green metanarthecium
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is short, straight, with many bearded roots. It grows 15 to 55 cm tall. The leaves are 10 to 15 leaflets emerging from the root and spreading in all directions, lanceolate with a pointed tip, 8 to 24 cm long, 1 to 4 cm wide, with dull edges. The flowers are borne in racemes at the end of the stem and are yellowish-green or white-green in color. The fruit is a drupe, egg-shaped.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: first discovered in 1968 at Chilbo Mountain in Suwon, Gyeonggi-do, Korea - Habitat: a perennial herb, found at the edge of moist, sunny grassy areas in forests - Flowers in June and July, fruiting in August and September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Urban development and natural degradation have drastically reduced its population, although some habitats are being restored. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, on the National Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed only in Namhae, Gyeongsangnam-do and Busan Metropolitan City. The population at Chilbosan Mountain in Suwon, Gyeonggi-do, where it was discovered, has been extirpated, but is currently protected by artificial restoration.

name: Bulbophyllum drymoglossum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems 0.5 to 1.0 mm wide, growing laterally, with 1 leaf every 2 to 3 branches, and 1 to 3 roots at the base of the stem. Leaves are elliptical to egg-shaped, 0.7 to 1.3 cm long, 0.5 to 1.0 cm wide, and rounded at the tip. Flowers are borne at the end of the stem, single, light yellow, about 1 cm in diameter. The sepals are 3-petaled, broadly lanceolate, with 2 side petals and 1 lip petal that is long oval. The fruit is a drupe, egg-shaped, about 0.6 centimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Bulbophyllum drymoglossum is a flowering plant, unlike bulbophyllum, which is a fern that reproduces by spores - Habitat: Evergreen perennial epiphytic orchid that grows on old trees or rocks in areas with high air humidity - Blooms in May and June and fruits in July and August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by overharvesting due to its high ornamental value, and some populations are thought to have already disappeared. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in parts of Jeju Island and Jeollanam-do; - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Great willowherb
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Epilobium hirsutum grows 1 to 2 meters tall, with long, spreading glandular hairs on the stems and leaves. The leaves are opposite on the lower part of the stem and divergent on the upper part, long elliptical, 4 to 12 centimeters long and 0.3 to 4.0 centimeters wide, with sharply toothed margins. The flowers are borne in leaf axils at the top of the stem, single, pink, 1.5 to 2.5 centimeters in diameter. The sepals are four-parted, the petals are four-petaled, and the pistil head is deeply divided into four. The fruit is a drupe, needle-shaped, 3 to 9 centimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: In suitable and stable habitats, it reproduces vigorously asexually by underground stems, with sexual reproduction by seeds; - Habitat: It is a perennial herb that grows in clumps on damp, gravelly or sandy ground around streams and valleys; - Flowering in July and August and fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes and habitat loss due to road construction, utility expansion, and cultivation. It is currently rated as Near Threatened (NT) on the National Red List and Least Concern (LC) on the IUCN Red List.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: restricted to parts of Gyeongsangbuk-do and Gangwon-do - International: distributed in Russia, China, Japan, India, Europe, and Central Asia.

name: Japanese gastrochilus
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are short and slanting. The leaves are lanceolate, 2 to 10 centimeters long, running in two rows on the stem. The base of the leaf is somewhat wrapped around the stem, and the leaf body is leathery with a deep central vein. The flowers are light yellow and are borne in racemes of 4 to 10 flowers. The sepals and petals have purple dots, and the lip petals have a semicircular tip. The fruit is a drupe, fusiform.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Similar to the golden orchid, but distinguished by the lack of purple spots on the leaves and the semicircular tip of the lip petals. Jeju Island is considered to be the northern limit of its worldwide distribution.- Habitat: Evergreen epiphytic orchid, epiphytic on evergreen broadleaf trees in some of the dipterocarp forests of Seogwipo City, Jeju Island.- Flowering in July and fruiting in September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes, few individuals are known to occur in the wild, and collection of restored specimens is severe. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (CR), a category of concern for extinction, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number of individuals are known from Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, and elsewhere.

name: Bird's-nest fern
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stem is short and erect. The leaves are borne in clusters from the underground stem and are narrowly lanceolate, 70 to 100 centimeters long and 7 to 15 centimeters wide, with dull edges. The veins in the center of the leaf are rather thick, raised on both sides, and blackish-brown in color. The sporangia are linear, 3 to 4 centimeters long, and the bracteoles are linear, blunt-edged, and brown in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is also known as the 'Ssopseom Illep' because it lives on Ssopseom Island, Jeju Island. Its habitat is designated as a natural monument.- Habitat: Evergreen perennial grass that grows in coastal forests, on damp cliffs and trees.- Spore season: June through September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has been extirpated from its habitat due to overharvesting and is now home to restored populations. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only on Jeju Island, where it is the northern limit of its global range. - International: Distributed in China, Japan, and Taiwan.

name: Stellera chamaejasme
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are woody, thick, and bright red in color. Stems are clustered, 20 to 40 centimeters tall, and hairless. Leaves are opposite, pinnately arranged, lanceolate, 1.7 to 3.0 centimeters long and 0.4 to 0.9 centimeters wide, with dull margins. The flowers are 20 to 25 in head-shaped inflorescences at the end of the stem and are red in color. The sepals are 5-parted, the calyx is 8 to 12 mm long and has 10 stamens. The fruit is a drupe, cone-shaped.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is called bloodroot grass because of the reddish color of its roots, and it is also known as 'Seoheung dak tree'- Habitat: It is a perennial herb, very rarely found in sunny fields or open areas- Blooms from April to May and fruits from July to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has been decimated by overharvesting for ornamental purposes and commercial sale, but also by loss of habitat due to vegetation change in its native range. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Restricted to the eastern foothills of Oreum, Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China, Mongolia, Russia, Nepal, and Central Asia.

name: Halla lousewort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Hairy, spreading all over. The stems are erect, branched at the base, and 10 to 30 centimeters tall. The leaves are 3 to 6 leaflets, oblong-oval, 1 to 4 centimeters long, 5 to 10 millimeters wide, and divided into 5 to 7 pairs of pinnate lobes. The flowers are purple, borne in racemes at the ends of the stems. The sepals are barrel-shaped, shallowly forked at the tip with 5 points, and longitudinally striped. The pedicels are lip-shaped and 1.5 to 2.0 centimeters long. The fruit is a drupe, long and egg-shaped.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: densely hairy throughout, less deeply divided leaves, and a difference in the length of the upper (3.5 to 5.0 mm) and lower (5 to 8 mm) lips of the lip-shaped flower beak compared to the cloudflower.- Habitat: An annual or biennial herb, very rarely found in rocky areas near high mountain ridges.- Blooms in August and September, fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Some of its habitat along the trails is threatened by damage and overharvesting by tourists, as well as soil loss due to natural factors and habitat disturbance due to climate change. It is currently listed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and has been recorded in the Hallasan and Gaya mountains. Recently, there is a view that the Gaya Mountain population is a spikelet grass, so it was excluded.

name: Liparis auriculata
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The false scale stem is ovate-globose, 1 to 2 centimeters long and 1.5 centimeters wide. The leaves are 2-pinnate, broadly ovate, 4 to 12 centimeters long and 3 to 8 centimeters wide, pointed at the base, wrapped around the stem, and wavy at the edges. The flowers are borne in racemes 5 to 30 centimeters long, light green or purple. Sepals and side petals are linear, lip petals are ovate, 5.5-6.5 mm long and 5-6 mm wide, with two triangular fleshy lobes at the base, with irregular serrations on the edges and a brown center vein. The fruit is a drupe, ovate-oval.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Compared to daylily orchids, it is characterized by the presence of a fleshy mass on the lip petals.- Habitat: It is a perennial herb and is found in wetlands at elevations up to 1,100 meters.- Blooms in July and August and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes and by damage. It lives in an extremely restricted habitat, making it relatively vulnerable to threats. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in Hallasan, Jeju Island, Korea - International: Found in Japan, Taiwan, etc.

name: White egret orchid
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: A rounded tuber develops underground. The stems are 15 to 40 centimeters tall and hairless. The leaves are 3 to 6 leaflets, unequal, linear, 5 to 10 centimeters long and 4 to 6 millimeters wide, and cover the stem at the base. The flowers are 3 centimeters long, borne in 1 to 3 clusters at the end of the stem, white. The sepals are green, broadly oval, and the side petals are white, rhombic. The lip petals are white, three-parted, and each segment is finely toothed at the edges. The fruit is a drupe, oval in shape.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: highly ornamental with white flowers reminiscent of a heron. It can germinate itself by sowing around the mother plant.- Habitat: A perennial herb that grows in relatively sunny, moist grassy areas or wetlands. It is also cultivated as an ornamental. - Blooms in July and August, fruiting in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threatened by indiscriminate collection for ornamental purposes and habitat loss due to wetland development. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number are found in some areas of Gyeonggi-do and Sangju, Gyeongsangbuk-do, Korea - International: Distributed in China and Japan.

name: Inconspicuous bulbophyllum
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The roots are threadlike and the stems extend laterally. The stem is egg-shaped, 5 to 8 mm long, with a long, elliptical leaf at the end. The leaves are 1.0 to 3.5 cm long and 6 to 8 mm wide, thick, fleshy, rounded or concave at the tip, with a distinct vein in the center. The flowers emerge from the base of the stem, in clusters of 1 to 3, and are yellow-green in color. The side petals have hairy margins, and the lip petals are narrow, egg-shaped, and tipped back. The fruit is a drupe, obovate.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content:
- Characteristics: Named for the bump-like shape of its false scaly stems. Also known as 'barley orchid'. The herb is also used medicinally as 'macgok'- Habitat: Evergreen perennial herb that lives in lowland forests, attached to trees and stones.
					
					
					- It blooms from May to July and bears fruit from September to November.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is under increasing threat from overharvesting for ornamental purposes and habitat loss. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern, on the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed in certain areas of southern Korea, including Jeju Island and Jeollanam-do; - International: Distributed in Japan.

name: Red bearberry
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005
Endangered Wildlife and Flora and Protected Wildlife and Flora Designations of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1993
Species of Wildlife and Plant Designation 1989

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The stems are 7 to 15 centimeters tall, dark brown in color, with long underground stems. The leaves are obovate, 2 to 5 centimeters long and 0.6 to 1.3 centimeters wide, gradually narrowing at the base to join the petioles, and toothed at the margins. The flowers are borne in 2 to 3 racemes at the end of the stem and are light yellow in color. The pedicels are clustered, 4 to 5-parted at the tip, with 10 stamens and hairy stamens. The fruit is a drupe, round, about 1 centimeter in diameter, and ripens red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Larger leaves than bilberry; leaves turn red in fall and fall off. The berries are edible and have a sour flavor. Habitat: A small tree, found in rocky areas or grassy meadows at high elevations.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Its geographically narrow range and occupied area are the main threats, along with overexploitation and harvesting. It is currently assessed as Endangered (EN), a category of threatened, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: very limited distribution in parts of Seoraksan, Gangwon-do, Korea - International: distributed in eastern Russia, Manchuria, China, and Japan.

name: Green bubble seaweed
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Dictyosphaeria cavernosa looks like a greenish beaded mass of small, brownish bubbles. Initially, it is a tightly packed ball, but as it grows, it becomes a hollow ball, with irregular protrusions or ruptures that become the first layer of cells. They are 1 to 3 centimeters in diameter and have a firm texture. The cells of plants are short, thick, and cylindrical in shape, with tentacles between the cells of the tissues that make up the cells, which hold them firmly to their neighbors. The short base cells serve to attach to the ground.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: can be observed year-round, but is generally seen in the warmer months - Habitat: lives in groups on rocks in the intertidal zone, the area between the shoreline at high tide and the shoreline at low tide, and below the low tide line, the boundary between sea and land.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to development and pollution in its native range.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Observed in the intertidal zone of Jeju Island (Gapado, Dajeong, Brothers Island, Saseo, Jiguido, Seongsan, Udo) - International: Widely distributed in tropical waters of Central and South America (Mexico, Cuba, Brazil, etc.), Southeast Asia (Indonesia, Philippines, etc.), Hawaii, etc.

name: Coccophora langsdorfii
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This marine brown algae plant attaches itself to rocks with a bumpy, hump-shaped attachment. It produces many stalks from the attachment, which can be 40 to 50 centimeters long. Cylindrical stems emerge and grow straight up. The secondary leaves are densely scaly and resemble cedar leaves. The leaves are threadlike at first, then they overlap, become straggly, and split and grow apart. As they grow, the lower leaves gradually fall off, leaving behind small, hump-shaped marks. The stomata are spindle-shaped and occur in groups of one to three on each leaf.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: can be observed year-round - Habitat: lives in the subtidal zone, a coastal area from the low tide line to 40 to 60 meters deep that is always under water, even at low tide - Forms reproductive organs from May to August. The gametophyte, the branch or leaf part on which the seeds are clustered, develops from several leaves at the apex and is characterized by a hollow sulcus that is watery and fleshy. They are very conspicuous, especially with their golden color.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to the loss of its native habitat due to coastal development such as harbor expansion and tourism.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly distributed in Gangwon-do and the east coast tidal zone, also found in parts of the south coast - International: Distributed in Japan, Russia, etc.

name: Omphalotus guepiniiformis
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Class II Endangered Wildlife Designation in 2017
Class Ⅱ Endangered Wildlife Listing in 2012

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The lampshade grows from 6 to 25 centimeters in length and has a semicircular to clam-like shape. The surface of the shield has small purplish-brown or yellowish-brown lamellae, and the color of the shield is ivory, later changing to pebbly or blackish-brown. The tissue of the phloem is white and thick. The fruiting layer is white to pale yellow with a downward furrow 2-3 cm wide. The stem has a protruding, incomplete bib, which is shorter than that of the loquat. The stalks are characterized by purplish-black spots when cut.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: bluish-white phosphorescence at night or in the absence of light, with many cream-colored spores (powdery) around the fruiting body when mature - Habitat: a summer to fall fungus that occurs on dead branches of broadleaf trees or dead wood such as hornbeam.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The degradation and loss of coastal dunes has destroyed its habitat, leading to a decline in population.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: It has been observed in some areas of Gyeonggi-do (Gwangneung Forest Park) and Jangseong-gun, Jeollanam-do, Gyeryongsan, Seoraksan, Odaesan, Jirisan, and Jumbongsan in Jeollanam-do, South Jeolla Province.

name: Bar-tailed godwit
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 37 to 39 centimeters long, weighs between 200 and 720 grams, and has a long beak and legs. The bill is curved upwards, pink at the base and black towards the tip. The winter plumage is grayish-brown with a blackish-brown pattern on the top of the body and grayish-white on the underside. The rump has several thin, dark brown horizontal stripes. Females are larger than males and have a longer bill. The male's summer plumage is reddish-brown from head to belly, and the upperparts of the body are blackish-brown with reddish-brown spots. Females are lighter in color than males, with a darker upperparts. They have a dark brown stripe on the underside of the body. The irises are brown and the legs are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: when flying, it flies in a horizontal line, and when descending, it circles the sky two or three times before landing on its back.- Habitat: lives on coastal sandy beaches, mudflats, river mouths, waterlogged rice fields, and streams. During the breeding season, it uses lowland shrublands, forests, hillsides, and river valleys in the tundra.- Food: It feeds on a variety of invertebrates, including crustaceans, midges, and aquatic insects. During the breeding season, it eats berries, snails, insects, and spiders, and young birds are fed mainly insects.- Usually lays four eggs at a time in May and June, which are incubated by both sexes. The incubation period is 20 to 21 days. The hatchlings can run or swim from 1 to 2 days after hatching.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The reclamation and development of tidal flats along the Yellow Sea coast of South Korea and China, which has reduced the number of stopover sites where large numbers of individuals congregate during migration, is thought to be the main cause of the population decline. Other factors such as urbanization, marine pollution, poaching, invasive species, and climate change are also contributing to the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A migratory bird that passes through Korea in spring and fall, using the west and south coasts as stopovers. In particular, it is found in large numbers at the Geumgang Estuary, Yubu Island, Incheon Metropolitan City tidal flats, Namyang Bay, Cheonsu Bay, etc.- Overseas: It breeds in northern Eurasia and western Alaska, and overwinters in Europe, Africa, the Middle East, Southeast Asia, and Australia.

name: Little tern
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: At about 22 to 28 centimeters long and weighing 47 to 63 grams, it is the smallest of the terns that visit Korea. The beak is yellow with a black tip, and both males and females have a white forehead, with a short white line extending above the eyes. The top of the head and back of the head are black, and the collar, back, and waist are pale gray. The underside of the body is white. The legs are orange-yellow, and the claws are black. The winter plumage is black with a black bill, white from forehead to crown, and yellowish brown legs. The top of the young bird's head is black with white edges on each feather. The upperparts of the body are cream-colored with black half-moon blotches on each feather. The underside of the body is white.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: Breeds in groups, and when predators or humans approach the breeding grounds, they fly en masse in a collective defense. The city of Andong, Gyeongsangbuk-do, and a civic organization have created an artificial sand island in Andong Lake to provide breeding sites for terns.- Habitat: Breeds on sandy and gravelly beaches along coasts, rivers, lakes, and reservoirs. During the non-breeding season, they use lagoons, salt flats, and tidal flats, and may venture offshore to feed.- Prey: They feed mainly on fish, but also on crustaceans, insects, and mollusks 3 to 6 centimeters long.- Nests: They build concave nests on the ground. The breeding season is from April to August, and they lay two to three eggs at a time from late April to July, with an incubation period of 21 to 24 days. The incubation period, the period during which the hatchlings are raised, is 20 to 24 days. The eggs are sandy or gravelly and have a protective coloration, with black blotches and spots.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to habitat loss, including the loss of coastal dunes and river dredging.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Limitedly observed on sandy islands in rivers, coasts, and estuaries nationwide from spring to fall. There is a population that passes through Korea during migration, and breeding has been recorded in Asan Bay, Sihwa Lake, Nakdong River estuary, and Andong Lake (artificial island) in Yubu Island. - International: Breeds in Europe, Africa, the Middle East, India, Asia, Australia, the eastern United States, and the Caribbean coast, and winters in the Philippines, New Guinea, Australia, Indochina, India, and Sri Lanka.

name: Black-capped kingfisher
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This species is about 28.0 to 31.5 centimeters long and weighs 67 to 94 grams. The male's head is a matte, dark black color, with white under the chin and muzzle. The irises are dark brown. The bill is reddish-coral in color, long and pointed, with a straight back and a slight curve at the base. The back, shoulder collar, loin, upper coverts, and rump are glossy cobalt blue. The belly, flanks, and underparts are orange, and the color fades toward the center of the belly. Females are similar to males, but the edges of the feathers on the chest are always pale black. The legs are bright red.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: In Korea, the distribution decreased by 95% in 2010 compared to 1990 - Habitat: In temperate regions, it is found in broadleaf forests around inland lakes, rivers, and streams. In tropical and subtropical regions, it is found in forested coastal areas in addition to inland habitats.- Prey: In inland habitats, it feeds mainly on insects such as dragonflies and dragonfly larvae, amphibians and reptiles, and along the coast, it feeds mainly on fish and crabs.- Breeding: It breeds by drilling deep holes in the soil around streams and lakes. The breeding season is from May to August, and they lay 4 to 6 eggs starting in mid-May.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Changes and loss of habitat, including rivers, streams, and wetlands, and a decline in breeding sites, such as earthen cliffs along streams, are thought to be the main causes of the population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A summer migratory bird that occurs throughout Korea, once common, but the population has been declining in recent years. - International: Breeds in central, eastern, and southern China, northern Indochina, and parts of India. Winters in Indochina, the Malay Peninsula, the Philippine Islands, and India. Declining populations have been observed in Korea, Hong Kong, and Singapore. The total population is estimated to be less than 10,000 individuals.

name: Baer's pochard
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This small duck, 41 to 47 centimeters long and weighing about 880 grams in males and 680 grams in females, is characterized by a distinct white band on its wing feathers when in flight. The male's head and neck are black with a greenish sheen, white eyes, and a white spot under the bill. The chest and flanks are reddish-brown, and the underside is white. The first and second wing feathers are dark brown and white, with a black band with a coppery-green sheen at the tip. The female's head, neck, chest, and flanks are all dark brown, and her eyes are brown. The lower tail feathers and belly are white with a reddish-brown spot between the bill and eye.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: During the wintering season, it is common to see it mixed in flocks of white plovers or dusky white plovers.- Habitat: It overwinters in wetlands such as estuaries, reservoirs, and coastal lagoons. During the breeding season, it prefers small lakes or slow-moving rivers with few trees or areas of aquatic vegetation and reeds.- Food: It is both a surface and diving feeder, eating aquatic vegetation, grass roots, plant seeds, and occasionally fish and shellfish.- Breeds on the ground or in dense grass. They spawn from May to July, laying 6 to 13 eggs at a time. In captivity, the incubation period is about 27 days.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Due to habitat loss, hunting, and other factors, its global population has plummeted in the last 30 years. It is an internationally endangered species with an estimated global population of less than 1,000 individuals.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Wintering bird, observed nationwide in the lower Nakdong River, lower Mankyong River, Paldang Lake, Ganghwa County, and Topjeong Reservoir in Nonsan, Chungcheongnam-do, but in very small numbers - International: Breeds in northeastern China, eastern Mongolia, and Eastern Russia, and overwinters in eastern and southern China, Bangladesh, Hong Kong, northeastern India, Japan, and Myanmar.

name: Siberian white crane
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is about 140 centimeters long, weighs between 4.9 and 8.6 kilograms, and has a wingspan of 2.1 to 2.3 meters. Males and females are similar in appearance, so it's hard to tell them apart, but males are slightly larger than females. They have exposed red skin around their eyes, and their eyes are red or light yellow. The first wing feathers are black, but are covered by a long white third wing feather, making the entire body feathers appear white when not in flight. The legs and feet are a bluish-pink color. Juveniles are covered in feathers with no reddish patches on the head, and the head and upperparts of the body are tan in color.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: They are not very social and live within their own territory both when breeding and when not breeding. In captivity, they are known to live up to 62 years. The remaining population is estimated to be between 3,500 and 4,000 birds.- Habitat: This is the most wetland-dependent member of the crane family, living in marshes, rice paddies, and other areas where the water is shallow, clean, and calm.- Diet: In winter, they feed mainly on plant foods, while in summer they eat a more varied diet of insects, fish, and rodents.- Breeding: In marshes, they build mounds of grasses and sedges. The breeding season is usually from late May to mid-June. It lays 2 eggs at a time. The incubation period is about 29 days and the rearing period, the period of raising the hatched young, is 70 to 75 days. They don't reach sexual maturity until three years old.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to the conversion of wintering and stopover areas to agricultural land, land development for oil fields, dam construction, and the degradation and loss of wetland habitat due to drought. Other threats include poisoning and hunting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Occasional winter visitor to Korea, observed in Suncheon Bay, Goheung Wetland, Paju-si, Cheorwon-gun, Cheonsu Bay, Black Mountain Island, Jeju Island, etc.- Overseas: Localized, isolated population, breeding in Russia, China, Mongolia, Iran, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, etc. Small lakes around Poyang Lake in northern Jiangxi Province, China, are known to be its main wintering grounds. Small populations are found in Hong Kong, Japan, and Jordan.

name: Korean sculpin
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Endangered Wildlife Class II Delisting in 2012
Designated as Class II Endangered Wildlife and Flora in 2005

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is 8 to 15 centimeters long, with a cylindrical body and a flattened tail. The head is relatively large and slightly flattened at the top and bottom, with a large, wide mouth. The upper and lower jaws are about the same length. The lateral rows are complete, and the pectoral fins of males are noticeably longer than those of females. The body color is yellowish brown overall, lightening towards the belly. The body is free of scales and has five to six wide black-brown horizontal stripes on each side. The male's belly fin is yellow with several rows of circular gray patterns, which turn yellow during the spawning season and are interspersed with large white spots.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: In the past, it has been recorded in the Manyeong, Geumgang, and Seomjin river systems, but it is currently unconfirmed.- Habitat: It is a cold-water fish that lives in the upper reaches of rivers with high flow velocities and large stones and gravel. It prefers waters with water temperatures below 20°C. - Food: It feeds mainly on aquatic insects. - Spawning season is March and April, and water temperatures are known to be around 10°C during spawning. They spawn under large stones at the edge of fast-moving streams, and the male protects the eggs. Each female lays 650 to 900 eggs.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Populations are declining due to habitat loss and environmental degradation caused by river modifications and rising water temperatures due to climate change.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is restricted to the upper reaches of the Han River, Nakdong River, and some rivers flowing into the East Sea (Daesongcheon, Samcheok-osipcheon, Jusucheon, Yangyangnamdaecheon, Baebongcheon, etc.

name: Korean doty barbel
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022
Endangered Wildlife and Plants and Protected Wildlife and Plants Act of 1998
Designation of certain wildlife and plants in 1996

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Hemibarbus mylodon is 20 to 40 centimeters long, with a cylindrical body that tapers toward the back. The snout is long and blunt, with the upper jaw slightly longer than the lower, and the lips are not thick. The edges of the mouth have a pair of whiskers. Its overall body color is silver, with a brownish back and a silvery-white belly. On the sides of its body, it has seven or eight rows of small dots. The pectoral and belly fins are light in color, and the dorsal and caudal fins have three or more black stripes.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is highly sensitive to environmental changes and has a limited distribution area. It is considered scientifically important due to its unusual shape and behavior. It is protected by the Cultural Heritage Administration as Natural Monument No. 259. In the Geumgang water system, fry recently released as part of a species multiplication and restoration project have been confirmed in Muju-gun area.- Habitat: It mainly lives in the middle and upper reaches of rivers where the water is clear and deep with gravel.- Food: It is a carnivore and mainly eats aquatic insects, crustaceans, and worms.- Spawning season is April to May, and the female lays eggs on gravel, fertilizes them, and collects gravel to build a spawning tower. Females have 1,500 to 3,000 eggs, which hatch in 4 to 5 days at a water temperature of 20℃. During the spawning season, males turn black on the belly and develop bumps on the top of the snout and around the eyes.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to habitat loss and environmental degradation caused by river maintenance and development, water pollution from agricultural and livestock wastewater, and decreasing food sources.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea, inhabiting the middle and upper reaches of the Imjin River and the North Korean river basins of Hwacheon-gun, Yang-gu-gun, Inje-gun, and Hongcheon-gun in the Han River system, and Pyeongchang-gun and Jeongseon-gun in the South. It is also known to be distributed in the Yeosung River region of North Korea, and has recently been observed in Bonghwa-gun and Taebaek-si in the upper reaches of the Nakdong River.

name: Taczanowski's gudgeon
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This animal is 10 to 14 centimeters long, with a long, flattened body. The head is also flattened sideways, and the mouth is small and straight, located at the base of the snout. The edges of the mouth have a pair of whiskers. The lateral stripes are complete and are located almost in a straight line in the middle of the body. Its body color is light brown with a silvery-white belly. It has a wide dark brown band running down the middle of its sides and a broad black band in the middle of its dorsal fin.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinctive features: During the spawning season, males have reddish bands on the anterior margin of the pectoral, anal, and caudal fins, and the dorsal fin is yellowish in color. During the spawning season, males develop bumps on the top of the snout and around the eyes. Sammy is a cold-water fish that is likely to become increasingly scarce due to climate change.- Habitat: Schooling in clear water in pools with large boulders and gravel in the upper reaches of streams and mountain streams.- Food: They feed mainly on attached algae and aquatic insects.- Spawning season is known to be from May to August.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to habitat loss, environmental degradation, and water pollution caused by river construction.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecological Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Distributed mainly in rivers flowing westward from the Yalu River to the Han River, including the Imjin River, the Han River, and the Samcheok Five Rivers; - International: Found in the Amur River and Heilongjiang River systems in China.

name: Yoon's ground beetle
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Acoptolabrus leechi yooni is 23 to 25 millimeters long and morphologically similar to the gourd beetle, but has an elongated and larger thorax than the gourd beetle. The head and pronotum are usually reddish in color, and the pronotum, the posterior part of the head and pronotum, is bright green. The scutellar wings on the pronotum are tan or golden-green in color, sometimes with a reddish tinge. The scutellum is rough with oblong spines, and the spines are relatively close together.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Hibernates as an adult; overwintered adults emerge the following spring and can be observed from March through September. It has longer legs than other beetles and moves quickly at night in search of food. - Habitat: rocky terrain on the ridges of relatively high mountains. - Food: earthworms, snails, and other insects.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: The population is declining due to illegal harvesting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Ecology Center (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: This species is endemic to Korea and is found in the mountains of Seoraksan, Odaesan, Gyebangsan, and Taebaeksan in Gangwon-do Province.

name: Chalinga pratti
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan is 57 to 60 millimeters, and the upper surface of the wings is blackish-brown with tan spots and red stripes. The red stripes on the outer wings give the butterfly its name. The underside of the wings is generally darker in color. The pattern is the same as on the upper surface, but it's brighter due to the large number of yellow patterns throughout. The hindwing bases have three black dots on a yellow background.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Occurs once a year, adults are observed from June to August. It overwinters as a third instar and becomes active again in spring. It grows up to 5 adults and pupates around June. Habitat: It lives mostly in forests close to natural forests with both coniferous and broadleaf trees. It prefers the center of the forest rather than the edges and has a small home range. Food: The caterpillars are known to eat pine leaves, a coniferous tree that is unique among Korean butterflies. Males can also be found in rotten fruits and animal feces, and females can be found in catnip, fishweed, etc.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This cold-tolerant insect is distributed in the northeastern part of Gangwon Province and is affected by the increase in average annual temperature due to climate change. Its narrow range makes it difficult to migrate from one area to another, which is a factor in its population decline.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Mainly inhabits mountainous areas such as Seoraksan and Odaesan in Gangwon-do Province - International: Distributed in China and Russia.

name: Garden tiger moth
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The wingspan ranges from 58 to 86 mm, and the head is light brown or yellowish green with black spots. The antennae are brown, bilobed in males and serrated in females. The forewings are brown or bronze-colored with irregular bold patterns. The triangular pattern on the forewing is blurred, and the basal pattern in the middle is black or pale gray. The hindwing is orange-yellow with black dots along the outer line, but this varies greatly among individuals. A large black-blue pattern runs vertically down the center of the dorsum, and the anterior part of the venter is densely covered with orange hairs.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: Adults are known to be active from June to September, but are usually observed in September. It overwinters as a larva. It is characterized by its habit of flying towards the fire while maintaining a certain angle.- Habitat: Inhabits mountainous areas and fields, preferring broadleaf forests near agricultural fields - Food: The larvae feed on legumes, rosaceae, mulberries, brambles, and nettles.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: A boreal insect with a localized distribution due to climate change, attracted to fire. Disturbed by increased nighttime lighting due to urbanization, their populations are plummeting.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: formerly distributed throughout the country, now localized in some areas - International: distributed in Japan, China, Russia, India, Mongolia, North America, and Western Europe.

name: Siberian death camas
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It is 10 to 30 centimeters tall. The lowest leaves are scaly, wrapping around the stem and growing glandular-lanceolate from the second leaf, 10 to 20 centimeters long. The flowers are borne in racemes 3 to 12 centimeters long at the end of the stem, light yellow-green in color, about 1 centimeter in diameter. The fruit is a drupe, cone-shaped, narrow at the top, with a pistil.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing characteristics: It is distinguished from other members of the genus by its underground stems, lack of hairs on the inflorescence, and the presence of a hull at the base of the petals. It prefers to live on rocks and rocky slopes on sunny ridges with soil accumulated between the rocks and stones, where humidity is always maintained, the daily temperature difference is relatively large, and there is good ventilation and drainage.- It blooms in July and August and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Zigadenus sibiricus has a narrow geographic range and only a few individuals have been identified in Korea. Accessible populations have been largely destroyed, and inaccessible populations are threatened by overexploitation and illegal harvesting. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found in the Baekdu-daegan area, with a confirmed distribution in Jeongseon-gun, Gangwon-do; - International: Distributed in eastern China, Russia, and Japan.

name: Chinese crested tern
conservation_history: Endangered Wildlife Class I designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: This bird is 38 to 43 centimeters long and weighs 240 to 320 grams. Its bill is orange-yellow with a black tip. During the breeding season, it's black from the forehead, below the eye line, to the back of the head, with a mane-like horn on the back of the head. After the breeding season, the forehead and crown turn white. The back is pale gray, and the legs are black. Young birds have scattered gray spots on their backs and wings, and their legs are yellow.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: It is currently estimated that there are less than 100 individuals worldwide, so it is in urgent need of conservation.- Habitat: It breeds mainly on uninhabited islands off the coast, and Yuksan Island in Korea is the fifth confirmed breeding site in the world.- Food: Adults forage within 5 kilometers of the breeding site and feed small fish to young birds.- Arrives in Korea in mid to late March and spawns in April, and in China in June. They lay a single egg, with an incubation period of 22 to 28 days and a rearing period of 31 to 35 days for the hatched chicks.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Other threats include habitat degradation, disturbance, fish overfishing, and failure of colonies to reproduce due to typhoons.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Since 2016, breeding has been confirmed on Yuksan Island, Glory-gun, Jeollanam-do, South Korea.- International: A small number of individuals breed on four uninhabited islands in China and Taiwan. In 2000, four pairs of breeding individuals were rediscovered on an island in southern China, and in 2018, 77 adult birds were confirmed at breeding sites in China. The current global population is estimated to be around 100 individuals.

name: Asplenium wrightii
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are thick, oblique, and the leaves are clustered together. The petioles are 20 to 40 centimeters long, light green with a purplish tinge and a blackish-brown base with scales. Leaf blades are broadly lanceolate, 30 to 50 centimeters long, 1-pinnately divided, and pointed at the tip. Leaflets are 13 to 20 pairs, lanceolate, sickle-shaped, with a sharply toothed edge. The sporangiophore clusters are arranged in two rows close to the midvein of the posterior vein and are slightly curved and linear; the sporangia are 3 to 15 mm long and 1 to 1.2 mm wide, with a rugose margin.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Features: It is a representative southern plant distributed in Jeju Island, Korea. It is said to be snowy and dying because the shape of the post looks like an eyebrow.- Habitat: It is an evergreen perennial fern that lives in small colonies in the cliffs of valleys in the evergreen broadleaf forests of Jeju Island. It lives mainly in shady places with high air humidity.- Spore season is from July to October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Only a few individuals have been observed in a very limited geographic range. With an estimated population size of one to five individuals, and only one to two individuals in each habitat, it is in need of active conservation. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only on Jeju Island - International: Distributed in China, Japan, Taiwan, Vietnam, and the Philippines.

name: Adenophorat erecta
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It grows 30 to 50 centimeters tall above ground, with elongated main roots. The stems are upright and hairless. The leaves that emerge from the stem are opposite, egg-shaped, with long petioles. The base of the leaves is cordate or rounded, and the leaf tips are pointed, with irregular, sharp teeth on the edges. The inflorescence is a raceme, the peduncle is 3 to 20 centimeters long. The flowers are pale light blue or almost white and bloom in bell-shaped racemes. The fruit is a drupe, cone-shaped, elongated and open with a hole at the base.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: first collected in Ulleungdo in 1994 and reported as a new species in 1997 - Habitat: a perennial herb, native to the montane forests of Ulleungdo and steep slope grasslands along the coast - Flowering in August and September and fruiting in October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Only a few individuals have been identified in a very small area. It is threatened by habitat loss due to natural disasters and development activities. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Endemic to Korea, found only on Ulleungdo Island.

name: Halla catchfly
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: Stems arising from fusiform, thick roots are erect, growing up to 10 to 20 centimeters tall, and hairless. Leaves are opposite, pointed, linear, 4 to 7 centimeters long and 3 to 5 millimeters wide, with dull edges. The flowers are white, borne in cymes at the ends of the stems or in leaf axils. The sepals are cylindrical, 1 centimeter long, 5-parted, and have 10 veins. The petals are 5-petaled, 2-parted, and have 10 stamens. The fruit is a drupe, long and oval.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: similar to the spiny stigma, but differs in that all 10 stamens extend out of the calyx, whereas in the spiny stigma only 5 of the 10 stamens extend out of the calyx.- Habitat: a perennial herb that grows rooted in crevices of sun-exposed rocks around craters on the summit of Hallasan Mountain in Jeju Island (over 1,900 meters above sea level).- Blooms July through September and fruits in September and October.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: Threats include a very narrow geographic distribution and occupied area, and vegetation change due to climate change. It is currently listed as Critically Endangered (CR) in the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Korea: Endemic to the Korean Peninsula, with a confirmed distribution in North Korea, this species is restricted to the crater area around the summit of Mount Hallasan.

name: Naked mitrewort
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: It is 15 to 25 centimeters tall. The underground stem is slender and long. The leaves that emerge from the root are cordate or ovate-circular. They have a few hairs on both sides and indistinct serrations on the edges. Petioles are 5 to 10 centimeters long and glandular. The flowers are light green in color, borne on stems in racemes. The sepals are barrel-shaped with 5 split ends and feathery petals between each split. The fruit is a drupe and the seeds are black.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A boreal plant that probably expanded southward during the last ice age and remained in the alpine zone due to warming during the interglacial period. It has one or two localities in Korea and is of great phytogeographical importance.- Habitat: It is a perennial grass, found in subalpine and relatively high elevation areas, and grows in shady places. In Korea, it is found in the Taebaek area of Gangwon-do Province and grows in cooler areas on the edges of valleys and under mountainous areas in moist places.- It blooms from May to June and fruits from July to September.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species has a very small area and a small population, but some individuals have been lost when their habitat was disturbed by the construction of a trail. It is currently assessed as Critically Endangered (EN), a category of endangered, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Wildlife Federation (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Found only in Taebaek City, Gangwon Province - International: Distributed in Northeast China, Mongolia, Far Eastern Russia, North Korea, and North America.

name: Staghorn clubmoss
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The main stem is shallowly buried in the ground or creeping over the ground, irregularly branched, and more or less densely leafy. The lateral branches are upright to 50 cm and branch continuously to form a tree. The leaves are of two types: the ones on the lateral branches are arranged in a spiral, glandular-lanceolate, with blunt edges, and the ones on the branches are densely attached, needle-like. The sporangia are broadly ovate with a tufted margin. Sporangia are 1 or 2 at the end of the branch, cylindrical with a drooping tip.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Characteristics: A tropical fern. It is distinguished from other taxa in the family by its horizontal creeping stems, distinct sporangia at the tips of the branches, and drooping or bending sporangia.- Habitat: A perennial fern, it is found in small clusters in damp areas of lowland mountains or around bogs in the South Sea Islands region. It occurs on sunny, moist ground, and is also found in some damp areas on hillsides and forest edges.- Spore season is September through December.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is threatened by a geographically narrow range and a high number of invasive species, habitat development, and overharvesting. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU), a category of concern for extinction, on the National Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: Recently confirmed in Wando-gun, Jeollanam-do, South Jeolla Province, with a small number of individuals also found in the Xin'an Island area - International: Distributed in Japan, Taiwan, Myanmar, and Australia.

name: Arctic yellow violet
conservation_history: Class Ⅱ endangered wildlife designation in 2022

extra_sections.title: Appearance
extra_sections.content: The underground stems are short and densely nodded. The stems are 2 or more and grow 5 to 20 centimeters tall. Leaves are borne on the underground stems and stems, and the leaves from the stems are opposite. The leaves are broadly lobed, 1 to 3 centimeters long, and have wavy serrations on the edges. The flowers are yellow, borne in leaf axils at the top of the stem. The petals are 5-petaled with purple stripes, the inner side petals are hairless, and the pedicels are 0.5 to 2.5 millimeters long. The fruit is a drupe, egg-shaped, 4 to 7 millimeters long.

extra_sections.title: Ecology
extra_sections.content: - Distinguishing features: The lack of hairs on the inside of the lateral petals compared to similar yellow violets - Habitat: This perennial is native to the northern alpine region of Seoraksan, Gangwon-do. A small number of populations are found in two areas of Seoraksan Mountain. The habitat is a shady, humid place with high rock exposure and partial sunlight blocked by large rocks.- It blooms in May and June and fruits in June and July.

extra_sections.title: Threats
extra_sections.content: This species is native to alpine areas and is highly vulnerable to environmental changes due to climate change. It is currently assessed as Vulnerable (VU) in the Red List of Threatened Species.

extra_sections.title: Source
extra_sections.content: National Park Service (2023), Endangered Wildlife at a Glance

extra_sections.title: Distribution
extra_sections.content: - Domestic: A small number of individuals live in Seoraksan, Gangwon-do, Korea - International: Widely distributed in Eurasia, including China and Russia.
